headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to United Continental Holdings Earnings Conference Call for the Fourth Quarter of 2015. My name is Brandon, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded and is copyrighted. Please note
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to United Continental Holdings Earnings Conference Call for the Fourth Quarter of 2015. My name is Brandon, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded and is copyrighted. Please note that no portion of the call may be recorded, transcribed or rebroadcast without the company's permission. Your participation implies your consent to our recording of this call. If you do not agree with these terms, simply drop off the line. 
I will now turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Jonathan Ireland. You may begin, sir.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brandon. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to United's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. This morning, we issued our earnings release and separate investor update. Both are available on our website at ir.united.com
componenttext:
Thank you, Brandon. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to United's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. 
This morning, we issued our earnings release and separate investor update. Both are available on our website at ir.united.com. Information in this morning's release and investor update and remarks made during this conference call may contain forward-looking statements, which represent the company's current expectations or beliefs concerning future events and financial performance. All forward-looking statements are based upon information currently available to the company. A number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from our current expectations. Please refer to our press release, Form 10-K and other reports filed with the SEC by United Continental Holdings and United Airlines for a more thorough description of these factors. 
Also, during the course of our call, we will discuss several non-GAAP financial measures. For a reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures to GAAP measures, please refer to the tables at the end of our earnings release and investor update, copies of which are available on our website. 
Unless otherwise noted, special charges are excluded as we walk you through our numbers for the quarter. These items are detailed in our earnings release. 
Joining us here in Chicago to discuss the results are President and CEO, Oscar Munoz; acting CEO, Brett Hart; Vice Chairman and Chief Revenue Officer, Jim Compton; Executive Vice President and Chief Operations Officer, Greg Hart; and Senior Vice President, Finance and Acting Chief Financial Officer, Gerry Laderman. Oscar will begin with some overview comments followed by Brett's discussion of 2015 performance. Next, Greg will provide an update on our operations. Jim will follow the discussion on revenue and capacity. Gerry will review our costs, fleet and capital structure, after which we will open the call for questions, first from analysts and then from the media. [Operator Instructions] 
And now I'd like to turn the call over to Oscar.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jonathan, and thank you for joining us today. I'm certainly glad to be here, and I look forward to reengaging with you across our stakeholder network. But today let me start frankly by extending my thanks for all the well-wishes I've received
componenttext:
Thank you, Jonathan, and thank you for joining us today. I'm certainly glad to be here, and I look forward to reengaging with you across our stakeholder network. 
But today let me start frankly by extending my thanks for all the well-wishes I've received from across my United family during my situation. I'm pleased to report that I feel great. My recovery is progressing very nicely. Already this week, in fact, over the course of the last month, I'm beginning to participate in meetings and starting to plan to increase my role in each week going forward. As far as expectation of full return, I certainly will be back full-time by the first quarter, if not sooner, and I'm incredibly energized by that prospect. So again, look forward to seeing all of you out on the road. 
Thank you, people. I want to thank Brett and the entire United team for their excellent work implementing our shared purpose and vision for United. We really have made significant progress in both our operation and our financial performance. And I'm frankly excited to be here today as we announce record profits for the fourth quarter and full year 2015. And this I tell you cannot have been done without engagement, excitement and energy that exists with [indiscernible] employees. I'm very proud of what we do each and every day, and we are going to leverage and use this same level of engagement to continue the momentum into 2016 and beyond. 
So with that, let me turn the call over to Brett.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Oscar, and thank you all for joining us on our fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings call. The entire United family is very pleased to have Oscar in the room with us today. And like him, we're all looking forward to his full-time return. In
componenttext:
Thanks, Oscar, and thank you all for joining us on our fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings call. The entire United family is very pleased to have Oscar in the room with us today. And like him, we're all looking forward to his full-time return. 
In the meantime, I and the management team want to thank our employees for making 2015 a great year for United. We achieved record financial and operational performance, made meaningful strides toward enhancing the customer experience and is fully committed to continuously earning the trust of customers and employees. While they are -- where we still have more work to do, I am proud of the tangible measures of success we've already demonstrated, none of which could have been accomplished without the work and commitment from the entire United team. Over the last 3 months, I visited each of our hubs, and I'm consistently impressed by our employees' enthusiasm, dedication and strong desire to win, and it is an honor to work alongside them as we take the next steps towards improving United. 
Today, we reported 2015 pretax earnings of $4.5 billion, our highest level of earnings in United's history. I am pleased to announce that through our profit sharing program, employees will be able to share in the success as we pay out $698 million, our largest distribution ever. For the year, we achieved a return on invested capital of 21%, also marking the highest growth ever reported by the United. These numbers represent a meaningful improvement year-over-year as well as progress closing the gap of financial performance of our 2 closest competitors. 
A major contributor to our strong financial performance is improvement in our operation. When compared to last year, our completion rate improved by more than 1 point and on-time performance was 6 points better for the full year 2015. This was particularly evident in the fourth quarter as our on-time performance and completion factor were at best since the merger. A well-run operation is a top priority for customers, and we are working extremely hard to become the consistently reliable airline our customers can depend on. 
We also want to be a great place to work for our employees. We have a responsibility to provide them with contracts they deserve. And this fall, we made significant progress to do just that. Evidence of this progress can be found in the 2 new agreements covering both our pilots and technicians that are current in the ratification process. Additionally, we reached an agreement to open negotiations on new contracts for our airport and customer service work groups, more than 1 year in advance of the amendable date. We're also continuing negotiations with our flight attendants and are hopeful that we reach an agreement with them this year. I want to thank these union groups for their commitment to reaching agreements with our workforce in the years to come. 
I am pleased with the progress we made in 2015. We took significant actions that have led to vote strong financial and operational performance. We are excited for the opportunities in 2016 as we focus in making the changes necessary to become the airline that we, our customers and our shareholders expected to be. 
Now I'll turn it over to Greg.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brett, and thank you to everyone for joining the call this morning. I'd like to take this opportunity to thank our employees for their efforts this year, particularly during the busy holiday travel season. And as Brett mentioned, we have made mean
componenttext:
Thanks, Brett, and thank you to everyone for joining the call this morning. I'd like to take this opportunity to thank our employees for their efforts this year, particularly during the busy holiday travel season. And as Brett mentioned, we have made meaningful improvements to our operation, and we couldn't have done it without the continued hard work and dedication of our employees. Due to the great work of the United team, in 2015, we had best on-time arrival performance since the merger. Additionally, we had a better completion rate than our network competitors in both New York and Chicago, a better completion in Houston than our network competitor in Dallas. We also continued to deliver well on that performance. In fact, during 2015, we achieved record performance for 7 of the 12 months in the year. As reflection of our commitment to operational excellence, we recently launched the new United Global Performance Commitment for corporate customers in 2016. With this program, we will compensate eligible corporate accounts if we fail to meet our operational targets for the year. This clearly demonstrates our level of confidence and commitment to continue to improve United's operational performance. 
Looking forward to 2016, we have a number of opportunities to further improve the operation. One change we implemented earlier this month was an increase in the amount of backsliding we do. Said differently, we are increasing the amount of flight that begins at the hub and then travels to another station before returning directly back to the originating hub. In 2015, approximately 35% of our flights [indiscernible] in that path. At the beginning of this year, we transitioned to approximately 70% of our flights that now follow this pattern, which is more consistent with that of our peers. 
This does two things for us. First, it dramatically reduces the complexity of the operation. In addition, it helps to isolate the impact of weather and aircraft-control-related events to the impacted hub and mitigating impact on our other hubs. We believe that reducing this complexity and limiting the impact of weather on our operations will drive improved reliability and efficiency and provide a better experience for our customers and our employees. 
In closing, I want to thank the entire operations team for all their hard work in 2015. I am proud of the significant progress we made this year, and I look forward to building on these successes in 2016. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jim.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. I would also like to thank our customers for their business in 2015. As Brett indicated earlier, we want to be our customers' first choice on every trip they take, and we will achieve this by continually building their trust. Accomplishing t
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. I would also like to thank our customers for their business in 2015. As Brett indicated earlier, we want to be our customers' first choice on every trip they take, and we will achieve this by continually building their trust. Accomplishing this won't be easy and won't happen overnight, but the entire team is committed to this goal. 
In the fourth quarter, our consolidated unit revenue declined 6%. The 4 primary factors we identified at the beginning of the quarter impacted our revenue performance as expected. A strong U.S. dollar, the effects of lower oil prices, pressure as a result of margin-accretive initiatives and competitive pricing actions. However, we also faced some unanticipated headwinds during the quarter. First, the attack in Paris put pressure in bookings across the Atlantic during the weeks that followed event. Second, our strong operational performance resulted in more completed flights than initially planned. While this is beneficial to margin and excellent for our customers, the additional capacity provided a tailwind to unit cost, headwinds to PRASM. Additionally, in the quarter, we saw oil prices continue to fall. We've provided incremental pressure to our Houston hub and corporate energy business, while ultimately being a tailwind to our fuel expense and overall earnings. Finally, demand declined throughout the quarter as demonstrated by downward provisions for fourth quarter GDP expectations. 
Turning to the first quarter. We expect our unit revenue to decline approximately 6% to 8% year-over-year with domestic PRASM down approximately 4% to 6% and international PRASM down approximately 8% to 10%. The major drivers for the first quarter revenue performance are expected to be largely the same as the fourth quarter. For the consolidated system, we expect foreign exchange impacts will account for 1 point of year-over-year PRASM pressure. 
Given further decline in oil prices, we anticipate continued pressure on lower surcharges, particularly in Japan, which we expect will account for approximately 1 point of weakness. Lower oil prices have reduced revenue from our corporate energy customers, and we are also beginning to see a decline in revenue from the broader [indiscernible] Houston market. The combined revenue pressure from both these energy contracts and the Houston hub is anticipated to be approximately 1 point.  Finally, we also expect the current competitive pricing actions will drive approximately 1.5 points of decline in the quarter. 
As we've mentioned before, while PRASM is an important metric, there are other metrics at United that are equally or even more, principally profit margin and earnings. As we construct our network and apply our assets across it, our primary goal is to increase earnings and margin. To that end, there are service decisions that may be dilutive to unit revenue but margin accretive for the business. Over the next several years, we have specific initiatives in place that may have just that effect. Our updating initiative is one such example. Our reducing departures and increasing the average age of our airplanes, we will grow our capacity very efficiently, which will be a tailwind for CASM while putting pressure on our PRASM performance. I would add that it in the case where we replace a single-cabin 50-seat aircraft with a 2-cabin regional small mainline aircraft, there is additional revenue that we can generate from having Economy Plus and First Class seats. In 2016, we anticipate increasing our average age by approximately 5% and reducing our average departures by approximately 1% compared to 2015. 
Another opportunity to grow earnings comes from further improvements to our pricing and segmentation capabilities. As we have seen in 2015, this has become an increasingly important component to revenue management. The more we segment our fares, the better opportunity we will have to minimize revenue dilution. The first place is the rollout of our bundled fare offerings this month. This allows customers to purchase a collection of products suited to their travel as opposed to a more manual process from selecting from an ala carte menu. The second phase, which we expect to launch in the second half of this year, will complement this bundled structure by introducing an entry-level fare that will appeal to the purely price-sensitive customer. We believe this sleight of offerings will allow further segmentation across United's customer base, while also avoiding some levels of revenue dilution built into our pricing structures today. 
Another way we intend to improve our revenue performance is through continuing to improve the reliability of the operation. Reliability is a top priority for our customers. And over the last several years, our revenue have suffered for the inconsistency in our operation. As Greg mentioned, the operation has made significant strides forward, and we expect over time for this to generate additional revenue. Earning the trust of our customers is critical for long-term earnings improvement, and the great work of Greg and his team are cornerstone for that success. 
With respect to capacity, and as a result of reduced planned Atlantic flight, we will reduce our expectations for first quarter capacity and now anticipate growing approximately 1.5% to 2.5%. For the full year, we still expect to grow 1.5% and 2.5%. As we all know, there are certain pockets of the globe that are experiencing economic slowdowns. We are thoughtfully addressing these issues by repositioning capacity to the areas that are experiencing the most economic growth. An example of this is what we are doing in Houston. Due to the decline in the energy business, as we have discussed, our Houston hub has experienced a significant yield pressure. Consequently, we are shifting capacity away from Houston and into other growing markets like Denver and San Francisco. We will remain disciplined in allocating our capacity in the markets that will generate the highest profitability. 
In conclusion, we are continuing to implement margin-accretive initiatives, product improvement and other initiatives across the commercial organization to attract and retain more high-value business customers. In 2016, we anticipate sequential quarter-over-quarter improvement and expect that the actions we are taking, along with an improving operation, will further earn the trust of our customers. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Gerry.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. I would also like to thank our employees for helping to make 2015 a record year for United. Their hard work led to our success this year, and I know they will bring the same energy and dedication to our efforts in 2016. For the fourth quart
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. I would also like to thank our employees for helping to make 2015 a record year for United. Their hard work led to our success this year, and I know they will bring the same energy and dedication to our efforts in 2016. 
For the fourth quarter, we reported net income of $934 million or $2.54 per share, excluding special items. This is double what we earned in the fourth quarter of 2014 and marks the seventh straight quarter of record earnings. For the full year 2015, we reported $4.5 billion of net income or $11.88 per share, excluding special items, and we achieved a pretax margin of 11.9%, a 6.8 point increase versus last year and the highest in United's history. 
Disciplined cost management has been a key contributor to our results this year. For the full year, our unit cost, excluding fuel, profit sharing and third-party expenses decreased 0.7%, more than 1 point lower than our initial 2015 guidance, despite nearly 0.5 point of capacity reduction from our regional plans. As Jim mentioned, our upgauging strategy was a meaningful contributor to our CASM performance in 2015, and we expect this contribution will continue as we ramp up the program to 2019. 
Looking forward to 2016, we expect our CASM, excluding the impact of new labor deals, to increase approximately 1%. The new labor agreements with our pilots and technicians, currently open for vote, would add approximately 2.5 points of CASM for the year. This is consistent with our commitment to maintain CASM growth below inflation over a planning cycle. 
Two years ago, we set a goal to achieve $1 billion in annual nonfuel savings by 2017. We now expect to achieve this goal in 2016, a full year in advance of our original time line. This focus on continuous improvement and durable savings will not end as we still have opportunities to improve efficiency and manage cost prudently. 
Turning to fuel expense. For 2016, we are 17% hedged and are on a loss position of approximately $225 million. Our portfolio allows us to participate 98% of any future declines. We are currently evaluating the structure of our hedged program. And in the meantime, we have not added any new hedges since July of 2015. 
Based on the guidance we have provided for cost and revenue in the first quarter of 2016, we expect our pretax margin to be between 8% and 10% in the first quarter. 
Moving on to cash flow. In 2015, we generated $6 billion of operating cash flow and $2.5 billion of free cash flow. In deciding how best to allocate capital, I also look at cash flow net of aircraft financing, since the decision to lease versus purchase an aircraft can have a material impact on the traditional calculation of free cash flow. When incorporating proceeds from long-term aircraft financing, we generated over $4 billion in adjusted free cash flow for 2015. I am pleased that we continue to generate significant cash flow in excess of both what we need to run our business and what we need to secure our future. Taking all that into account, in the fourth quarter, we spent approximately $520 million repurchasing United stocks, about double the amount we spent in the prior quarter. For the full year 2015, we spent $1.2 billion in share buyback program. Looking forward, I expect that we will spend at least $750 million repurchasing stock in the first quarter and now plan to complete our current $3 billion program substantially earlier than originally anticipated. 
One of the tools we use is the 10b51 plan, which allows us to purchase stock throughout the quarter even during periods when we might otherwise be unable to be in the market. As an example, we purchased shares in every trading day so far this month. We also used our cash to fulfill one of my primary missions of ensuring that we continue to make all appropriate investments in our business. In 2016, we expect to spend $2.7 billion to $2.9 billion for capital investments, including approximately $1.1 billion of non-aircraft CapEx. This would be roughly $100 million more than 2015 for non-aircraft CapEx. This increase is driven almost entirely by incremental technology investments. We believe that further investment in our technology is critical for our ability to compete in the years to come. 
We also expect to invest approximately $1.7 billion on our fleet in 2016. We plan to take delivery of 17 737s, 5 787-9s, our first 777-300ER and 9 used A319s. We will also add 40 Embraer E175 to our regional fleet. Our fleet investments this year also included predelivery deposit associated with the [indiscernible] announced today for 40 737-700 aircraft to be delivered beginning mid-2017. As we have stated in the past, we are continuing to shift more towards the mainline operation as our regional flying is being reduced It is our expectation that our current seat of approximately 250 50-seat aircraft will be reduced by more than half by the end of 2019. While this new 737 order does provide capacity to partially offset the reduction in the regional operation, we are continuing to pursue additional aircraft to continue upgauging and meet our capacity plans. 
We are also utilizing our cash to continue to secure our future. In 2015, we prepaid $1.2 billion of debt, including $300 million in the fourth quarter. As of the end of the year, our gross debt balance, including capitalized operating leases, was $17 billion, $1.1 billion less than the end of the prior year. 
In 2015, we also contributed more than $800 million to our pension plans. And as of year-end, our underfunded pension liability is now $1.5 billion, a $700 million reduction from the prior year. As we head towards well-funded status for our pensions, we anticipate contributing approximately $400 million to our pension plans in 2016. 
In conclusion, 2015 was a very good year for United as seen in nearly every financial metric. Moving into 2016, we look forward to delivering strong earnings performance and demonstrating disciplined capital allocation. I believe that the investments we are making in our people and our product will lead to a strong future that will benefit our employees, customers and investors. 
I'll now turn it back over to Jonathan.

componenttext: Joe, this is Jim. Yes, as you look at first quarter, our guidance is obviously based on the information that we have today both on a yield perspective and a bookings perspective. What I would say is that the pressures that we saw in the fourth quarter, which are mainly yield, continue in the first quarter, so we see strong demand. I have to always [indiscernible] a little about what Houston and the energy certain sectors that in high-yield demand we're seeing weakness. But overall, our bookings, load factors look where they were last year in terms of load factor point of viwe is the yield pressure that we see in the first quarter.

componenttext: Hey, Helane. We haven't released that. It's one of those we talked about in the past growing our pay of the load factor, and we continue to do that. I'll tell you, we're also focused on making sure that we keep that in balance with our loyalty customers. There's a lifetime value with our last miles. Both customers is very important to the overall economics as we go forward. So it's a balance. And so internally, we continue to debate what that is, whether it's paired products to offer the in first class, lower price points in first class, but also balancing that with the upgrades to our loyal customers.

componenttext: This is Oscar. Let me just add mine and I travel on our network and system. I spend a lot of time in our aircraft, and I spend a lot of time with some of our high-value customers, and that is a particular sore subject with them. And so that balance that Jim speaks about, I think, is very important line that we have to strike.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: From Wolfe Research, we have Hunter Keay on line.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Gerry, it's nice to see the buyback pick up, and thank you for the update. But if we assume you guys have significantly more cash of which to dispose this year, which I'm putting at about $6 billion to $7 billion, factoring in pension contributions, as
componenttext: So Gerry, it's nice to see the buyback pick up, and thank you for the update. But if we assume you guys have significantly more cash of which to dispose this year, which I'm putting at about $6 billion to $7 billion, factoring in pension contributions, assumptions around CapEx and maybe a little bit of excess cash, should it be fairly obvious decision to make that the level of buybacks this year exceeds your capital spending, given the immediate accretion that you get to EPS, not to mention the signal you send to your long-term shareholders about the trajectory of earnings beyond this year?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hunter, that's a good question. Let me talk about capital allocation generally, just as sort of set the stage. We have really the 3 components to it. So we are very focused on making the investments we have to make. To paraphrase a friend of mine, I know
componenttext: Hunter, that's a good question. Let me talk about capital allocation generally, just as sort of set the stage. We have really the 3 components to it. So we are very focused on making the investments we have to make. To paraphrase a friend of mine, I know what happens when you take the cheese off the pizza. So we will, first and foremost, make the right investment, so they have to drive the value that we expect or we would stop making some of them. Let me turn to the balance sheet and securing the future, we're in a pretty good spot to the balance sheet, so I would not anticipate the level of debt prepayment that you see in the past. Having said that, the way we will continue to manage the balance sheet is through the amount of new aircraft financing. So I would expect this year to finance some, probably not all of the aircraft this year, and that's [indiscernible] use of cash. I would say, first and foremost, I want to see that cash before I spend the cash. But as we continue to manage our cash sort of down to the target range that we feel comfortable with, that sort of $5 billion to $6 billion of liquidity that we've stated as our sort of comfortable target range, there's absolutely the opportunity for additional cash in the buyback. And as I said in my comments, that $750 million is the minimum, so we'll continue to have this dialogue through the year. But I hope you're right. I hope that this is a year that generates those significant cash flows.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Hunter, if I could just -- if you don't mind, if I can just weigh in on that subject as well. I think if you check my history, you'll see the willingness to allocate capital to shareowners in a very broad distributed way, and I don't think that changes with regard to this. I think it would be at least sort of qualified in some [indiscernible] of was added on purpose. And I don't necessarily disagree with the premise and thesis behind the concept, but we do have to strike a balance. And so this is one of the places we happen to be engaged a little bit and increasingly engaged and will get more definitive direction in about 2 months on that going forward.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, I know. Oscar, I'm glad you're here because you do have a bit of a reputation of being a capital deployer, so I think it would be helpful for everybody, including your owners, who have been putting out a pretty difficult year. It's very hard to
componenttext: Okay. Yes, I know. Oscar, I'm glad you're here because you do have a bit of a reputation of being a capital deployer, so I think it would be helpful for everybody, including your owners, who have been putting out a pretty difficult year. It's very hard to buy an airline stock. It's very hard to do that as an investor. And a lot of your owners just kind of been hung out to dry a little bit. So I think you would go a long way Oscar if you would commit that, barring any sort of major change in the environment, which is I think an easy enough to make right here in this call to come out and say barring no major changes in the economy or anything like that, but we will spend more buying back stock than we will on capital spending this year. I think that will go a long way if you will be willing to make that commitment here today.

componenttext: Okay. And so, I guess, just kind of extrapolating forward, is perhaps 2018 the first year you might can conceivably become a taxpayer, if that's the case? Or should we think about cash taxes sooner than that?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I can tell you that we are working hard now that we're in a mode of booking taxes and seeing a future of being a tax -- cash taxpayer. And we are doing some good tax planning. I don't want to tell you when we anticipate being a cash taxpayer. Obviously
componenttext: So I can tell you that we are working hard now that we're in a mode of booking taxes and seeing a future of being a tax -- cash taxpayer. And we are doing some good tax planning. I don't want to tell you when we anticipate being a cash taxpayer. Obviously, that depends on future earnings, but it's reasonable to anticipate if the earnings trends continue, you would see a relatively rapid utilization of those NOLs.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see. Okay. And as a follow-up question here, this one is for Jim. You mentioned sequential quarter-over-quarter revenue improvement, which I believe was on business travel spend. And so is the right way to think about that is 20% of the passenger revenu
componenttext: I see. Okay. And as a follow-up question here, this one is for Jim. You mentioned sequential quarter-over-quarter revenue improvement, which I believe was on business travel spend. And so is the right way to think about that is 20% of the passenger revenue getting sequentially better each quarter? And the reason for the clarification here is we do have some FX headwinds and some competitive headwinds, so I'm just trying to reconcile the comment with other revenue externalities.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, there's a couple of things as we talk about 2016 as we move through the year. We [indiscernible] a couple just now. The currency, obviously, is a big driver of what we'll look going forward. So kind of where currencies are at today, we would begin to
componenttext: Dan, there's a couple of things as we talk about 2016 as we move through the year. We [indiscernible] a couple just now. The currency, obviously, is a big driver of what we'll look going forward. So kind of where currencies are at today, we would begin to lap some of the currency effects in the second quarter this year. When you look at things such as surcharges. And as you know, the past year, we've talked a lot about surcharges, particularly in Japan, that by law are tied to our oil trades. We'll begin to lap those pretty significantly in the third quarter of this year. But again, there are some sort of charges out in Japan that most recently have come down, so the full effect of that will be more toward the end of the first quarter in 2017. Pricing -- the competitive pricing actions we've talked about through the year, based on where they are at today, we'll begin to lap those in the third quarter of 2016. And then lastly, oil, we've reported on our corporate energy portfolio through the year being down 20% the first quarter, 30% in the second quarter, 35% in the third. And we saw it dropped to 40% in the fourth quarter. So that lapping, given where current oil prices are and the expectations that oil prices will stay lower longer, that effect will take longer than what we've talked about in the past. All being said, there are things that as we lap through the year are -- will have less headwind on our RASM performance, and that's why we've talked about quarter-to-quarter improvements based on the items I described. Always qualify it because, as I mentioned in the fourth quarter, we saw GDP expectations come down from our initial expectations, so that and the volatility of oil prices is still that one thing that we don't like to talk about as specific. But I think given what we see lapping throughout the year, we feel good about quarter-over-quarter improvement as we move through 2016.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Deutsche Bank, we have Michael Linenberg on line.
componenttext: From Deutsche Bank, we have Michael Linenberg on line.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome back, Oscar. I mean, to start off, maybe to Jim. Jim, you guys are the biggest carrier to China, and we have seen a more significant devaluation of that currency over the past few months. Is there anything, just given your footprint in that market
componenttext: Welcome back, Oscar. I mean, to start off, maybe to Jim. Jim, you guys are the biggest carrier to China, and we have seen a more significant devaluation of that currency over the past few months. Is there anything, just given your footprint in that market, are you seeing anything, anything on the trends? And I sort of say that within the context of some of your commentary about the revenue weakness you talked about yield softness in international markets as well as domestic. And I didn't know if you were calling out China or other markets in total. What's -- can you address that?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Mike. Yes. I think there are things that we are doing obviously in [indiscernible] that I talked about already, and as you mentioned, our exposure to China. I would tell you, demand in China continues to grow at the pace of industry capacity. We've s
componenttext: Hey, Mike. Yes. I think there are things that we are doing obviously in [indiscernible] that I talked about already, and as you mentioned, our exposure to China. I would tell you, demand in China continues to grow at the pace of industry capacity. We've seen a little bit lower yield, but we're actually seeing -- obviously, it's been very profitable for us and that profitability maintained. So from a demand perspective, we're seeing demand keep pace with the capacity that we talked about over the past several quarters. Again, in the first quarter, we see about 19% industry capacity from China to the U.S., but yet we also seeing bookings for the industry going at that rate. You put that with our strength in San Francisco, the best gateway to Asia, we feel really good about our current position, and quite frankly, our long-term position for China going forward.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just a second question, when you look at your overall revenue performance and you compare yourself versus notably the other big 2, American and Delta, and you look at yourselves on unit revenue basis, I appreciate the fact that obvio
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just a second question, when you look at your overall revenue performance and you compare yourself versus notably the other big 2, American and Delta, and you look at yourselves on unit revenue basis, I appreciate the fact that obviously there are some initiatives that you're pursuing that are obviously margin accretive and ROIC accretive and therefore one consequence is that they may be RASM or PRASM dilutive. But I think there's another view out there, at least, the perception that strategically you're falling a bit behind your peers. And whether it's on the alliance Front or the joint venture front, you look at some of the announcements and some of the relationships and some of your competitors have grown those relationships. And yet when you look at United, you have a strong -- or at least I believe you have a strong relationship with Lufthansa, and you have a good relationship with Air China, and you also have a relationship with ANA. But a lot of times, we don't hear much commentary on it, and it doesn't look like it's showing up in the numbers. I mean, is that perception real? Or are there things that over the next year or so that you plan to roll out that maybe will help mitigate some of those revenue sort of differences?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Mike. Well, a couple of thoughts. One is, you mentioned Lufthansa, and Lufthansa a terrific partner for us and our performance in the fourth quarter, albeit down with the 2% [ph] RASM decline was really industry-leading performance -- relative perfor
componenttext: Hey, Mike. Well, a couple of thoughts. One is, you mentioned Lufthansa, and Lufthansa a terrific partner for us and our performance in the fourth quarter, albeit down with the 2% [ph] RASM decline was really industry-leading performance -- relative performance trans-Atlantic with our peers. We widened our RASM premium versus our peers in that. That's a great work of our team in terms of balancing the network, and quite frankly, working very closely with Lufthansa. So that JV for us, in that particular, is obviously very much [indiscernible] to the 1990s of the relationship. We had great success in that. If you look -- and so -- and then if you look at the Pacific, which is really a growth market for us, ANA plays a big part of that, and that relationship, from a JV, a little bit younger, but we've made great strides. We've talked about some of the Tokyo when you're flying to places in Asia that we now connect into ANA, which has allowed us to grow our San Francisco hub long-haul. So I think we have used the JVs to help leverage our market and grow our relative performance both in the trans-Atlantic as well as into Asia. Recently, our investment and our commercial agreement with Azure Brazil is a challenged market right now. Over the long term, we think that's going to play terrific. And it's already generating connecting traffic at numbers that are exceeding our expectations, albeit at lower yields, given what's happening in Brazil as well as the currency situation. So I think we're very focused on the alliance side to make sure we have the right partners to extend our network, and we'll do it in a way that obviously allows our customers to have more choice and more opportunities.

componenttext: From JPMorgan, we have Jamie Baker on line.

Or are there still incremental expenses that are required that might not be captured in the labor line, whether that's, I don't know, better tools for employee, new uniforms, that sort of thing that will pressure CASM a little bit further?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, it's probably more early for me to actually quantify what the impacts of these are, but my commitment is to balance both our commitment to our employees and make the appropriate investments and prioritize investment while understanding the way broa
componenttext: Jamie, it's probably more early for me to actually quantify what the impacts of these are, but my commitment is to balance both our commitment to our employees and make the appropriate investments and prioritize investment while understanding the way broader stockholder basis, maybe balance between those 2. And again, the more time I spend out in the field understanding the needs, the needs aren't as great as you think expense-wise. So certainly, comp is one. But beyond that, I think building right system tools, uniforms and things like coffee and peanut and all that add up, but they're just appropriate level investments that will strike a balance with. But again I can't quantify at this point in time.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Jamie, let me just add that, that process is started. And the CASM guidance you see for this year includes some of that already. Some of the tools and some of the other investments, we're making that's rolling into the CASM guidance that you see. And let me just, by the way, I need to clarify to Dan on the NOL. As of 12/31/15, the remaining NOL is a little closer to $8 billion and $9 billion. Sorry to interrupt you.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, no. That's fine. Actually for follow-up, while I have you, Gerry, the 73-700 is longer gauge than I thought you were looking at in terms of potential bridging that gap between 76 CRGs, and I guess, the A319. So what shifted in terms of the decisi
componenttext: Yes, no, no. That's fine. Actually for follow-up, while I have you, Gerry, the 73-700 is longer gauge than I thought you were looking at in terms of potential bridging that gap between 76 CRGs, and I guess, the A319. So what shifted in terms of the decision-making process? Does this entirely eliminate the need for something smaller than the 319 at the mainline? How do the price of fuel impact the calculus? Any additional color there?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. The price of fuel really doesn't impact our decisions on long-term fleet orders, but I would say that for this batch of aircraft, where we look at all of the variations, in fact, the 319 as well as the 737 and the 100-seat opportunities from both Em
componenttext: Sure. The price of fuel really doesn't impact our decisions on long-term fleet orders, but I would say that for this batch of aircraft, where we look at all of the variations, in fact, the 319 as well as the 737 and the 100-seat opportunities from both Embraer and Boeing, for this batch of aircraft, the 700 is the winner. As I mentioned, we will continue to look at aircraft, and we will continue to look at each of those aircraft types going forward.

componenttext: So it depends on the type. So for pension funding, it -- we have a fair amount of flexibility. So I would assume right now relatively even through at at least the first 3 quarters. On aircraft CapEx, we have some in the first quarter. There's a bit of a lag, and then some in the back half of the year. And everything else is fairly flat through the year.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

You noticed any changes in competitive pricing actions either domestically or internationally? And do you worry that those worsen in the lower fuel environment?

componenttextpreview: Julie, I don't want to comment on competitive pricing. It's obviously this business is very competitive, and we obviously match capacity in our demand, given the pricing structures out there, but I don't want to make any comments on the other competitive
componenttext: Julie, I don't want to comment on competitive pricing. It's obviously this business is very competitive, and we obviously match capacity in our demand, given the pricing structures out there, but I don't want to make any comments on the other competitive pricing actions. We will, as I mentioned in the script, that given where competitive pricing actions are today that the hypothetical assumption that's [indiscernible] where we are today. We begin to lap some of that effect by the time we hit the third quarter.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we look forward to doing that. That segmentation talk about we've been working hard at it in 2015, and so we're excited about rolling it out going forward. What that will do for us is a couple of things. One it will allow us to compete with ultra-low
componenttext: Yes, we look forward to doing that. That segmentation talk about we've been working hard at it in 2015, and so we're excited about rolling it out going forward. What that will do for us is a couple of things. One it will allow us to compete with ultra-low-cost carrier much more effectively, which means more product for customers that are looking for just that price point. And it also, as I mentioned, help us remove some of the dilution that we have in our pricing structure today. And so I'm not ready yet to kind of quantify, but as we roll out the second half of the year, I look forward to updating you on that.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions for me. We get a lot of questions from investors about closing the gap from a margin perspective to the industry. It looks like based on the 1Q guidance, and certainly 1Q is not the year, and you've got some hedged impact there,
componenttext: Just a couple of questions for me. We get a lot of questions from investors about closing the gap from a margin perspective to the industry. It looks like based on the 1Q guidance, and certainly 1Q is not the year, and you've got some hedged impact there, but it looks like that gap actually widens in the March quarter. So is closing that gap still a goal for the company? What should we be advising investors in that regard? And if so, over what time frame?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Duane, I'll start. It's Gerry. So it's still a goal. We haven't put a time frame on it, but we're very focused on doing what we can do both on the cost side and the revenue side to continue to maximize our margin, but we haven't, at this point, put a
componenttext: Hey, Duane, I'll start. It's Gerry. So it's still a goal. We haven't put a time frame on it, but we're very focused on doing what we can do both on the cost side and the revenue side to continue to maximize our margin, but we haven't, at this point, put a time frame on it. Greg?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think on the network side, we are focused on growing efficiently. And so that we talked about upgauging a lot over the past year, and 2015 was the first phase of that where we see growth for the use of [indiscernible] as Gerry mentioned contributed
componenttext: Yes, I think on the network side, we are focused on growing efficiently. And so that we talked about upgauging a lot over the past year, and 2015 was the first phase of that where we see growth for the use of [indiscernible] as Gerry mentioned contributed to the CASM side, comes at a lower RASM and but had significant contribution to the CASM side. We'll continue to do that as we also look at frequency reduction and upgauging into the mainline aircraft and the regional aircraft, and we can do that in [indiscernible] margins. As we upgauge that and will drive slow departures actually efficient growth, and it comes with efficient fuel costs. And so it all kind of works together, and we're very much focused on driving that this year.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duane, if I could just maybe [indiscernible] more definitive on the issue of industry comparisons and all of that, it's a competitive industry, and I'm a competitive guy. And so lest anything else we said, we always have our eyesight and focus that are ma
componenttext: Duane, if I could just maybe [indiscernible] more definitive on the issue of industry comparisons and all of that, it's a competitive industry, and I'm a competitive guy. And so lest anything else we said, we always have our eyesight and focus that are maybe, at this point in time, sort of performing better than us. I'll tell you what the most critical question around that is do you have the potential? Do you have the capacity? Do you have the ability with your network with your people with all of that? And one of the things I've seen in the relatively short time I've been here is tremendous amount of all of those things is starting with energy, excitement of our front-line employee, frankly, it's where it really starts. So at the end of the day, over the long term, we certainly believe our relative earnings profile will improve, and we will [indiscernible] that's the work that kind of get done here over the next few months.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Duane, on upgauging, remember that 2016 is a year where there's a dip in that process from 2015. It's just the cadence of new aircraft orders. That ramps up again in 2017 and continues nicely through 2019.
componenttext: And Duane, on upgauging, remember that 2016 is a year where there's a dip in that process from 2015. It's just the cadence of new aircraft orders. That ramps up again in 2017 and continues nicely through 2019.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that. And Oscar, we're amazed that you're on this call and wish you strong recovery. Just on the network side, had just one question. Please check on this. But we went back and looked at utilization changes, aircraft hours per day over the co
componenttext: I appreciate that. And Oscar, we're amazed that you're on this call and wish you strong recovery. Just on the network side, had just one question. Please check on this. But we went back and looked at utilization changes, aircraft hours per day over the course of 2015. And many had a nice year-on-year improvement in that. And frankly, that was what's driving capacity growth. In the case of United, looks like utilization is actually modestly down. We assume this is an effort to improve reliability, maybe more spares. Can you just talk about it just this case and the reasons behind it if there's any cost opportunity there longer term?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The -- one of the things we're driving is our seat per aircraft are going up, so we're driving growth that way. But clearly, as we reinvested in reliability, we want to make sure that the network is driving the right results from our reliability stag
componenttext: Yes. The -- one of the things we're driving is our seat per aircraft are going up, so we're driving growth that way. But clearly, as we reinvested in reliability, we want to make sure that the network is driving the right results from our reliability stage. In addition, part of our strategy of growing seats is to lower our stage line. And so some of that utilization to drive improved network is from a lower stage which is just driving [indiscernible] them. So it's a combination of couple of things. We'll invest in reliability as well as our network strategy going forward to grow efficiently.

Good morning, and welcome to United Continental Holdings Earnings Conference Call for the Fourth Quarter of 2015. My name is Brandon, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded and is copyrighted. Please note that no portion of the call may be recorded, transcribed or rebroadcast without the company's permission. Your participation implies your consent to our recording of this call. If you do not agree with these terms, simply drop off the line. 
I will now turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Jonathan Ireland. You may begin, sir.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brandon. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to United's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. This morning, we issued our earnings release and separate investor update. Both are available on our website at ir.united.com
componenttext:
Thank you, Brandon. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to United's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. 
This morning, we issued our earnings release and separate investor update. Both are available on our website at ir.united.com. Information in this morning's release and investor update and remarks made during this conference call may contain forward-looking statements, which represent the company's current expectations or beliefs concerning future events and financial performance. All forward-looking statements are based upon information currently available to the company. A number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from our current expectations. Please refer to our press release, Form 10-K and other reports filed with the SEC by United Continental Holdings and United Airlines for a more thorough description of these factors. 
Also, during the course of our call, we will discuss several non-GAAP financial measures. For a reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures to GAAP measures, please refer to the tables at the end of our earnings release and investor update, copies of which are available on our website. 
Unless otherwise noted, special charges are excluded as we walk you through our numbers for the quarter. These items are detailed in our earnings release. 
Joining us here in Chicago to discuss the results are President and CEO, Oscar Munoz; acting CEO, Brett Hart; Vice Chairman and Chief Revenue Officer, Jim Compton; Executive Vice President and Chief Operations Officer, Greg Hart; and Senior Vice President, Finance and Acting Chief Financial Officer, Gerry Laderman. Oscar will begin with some overview comments followed by Brett's discussion of 2015 performance. Next, Greg will provide an update on our operations. Jim will follow with the discussion on revenue and capacity. Gerry will review our costs, fleet and capital structure, after which we will open the call for questions, first from analysts and then from the media. [Operator Instructions] 
And now I'd like to turn the call over to Oscar.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jonathan, and thank you all for joining us today. I'm certainly glad to be here, and I look forward to reengaging with all of you across all our stakeholder network. But today, let me start frankly by extending my thanks for all the well wish
componenttext:
Thank you, Jonathan, and thank you all for joining us today. I'm certainly glad to be here, and I look forward to reengaging with all of you across all our stakeholder network. 
But today, let me start frankly by extending my thanks for all the well wishes I've received from across my United family during my situation. I'm pleased to report that I feel great. My recovery is progressing very nicely. Already this week, in fact, over the course of the last month, I've begun to participate in meetings and certainly plan to increase my involvement each week going forward. As far as expectation on full return, I certainly will be back full time by the end of the first quarter, if not sooner, and I'm incredibly energized by that prospect. So again, I look forward to seeing all of you out on the road. 
As I'm thanking people, I want to thank Brett and the entire United team for their excellent work in implementing our shared purpose and vision for United. We really have made significant progress in both our operation and our financial performance. And I'm frankly excited to be here today as we announce record profits for the fourth quarter and full year 2015. And this, I tell you, cannot have been done without the renewed engagement, excitement and energy that exist with our frontline employees. I'm very proud of what they do each and every day, and we are going to leverage and use this increased level of engagement to continue the momentum into 2016 and beyond. 
So with that, let me turn the call over to Brett.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Oscar, and thank you all for joining us on our fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings call. The entire United family is very pleased to have Oscar in the room with us today. And like him, we're all looking forward to his full-time return. In
componenttext:
Thanks, Oscar, and thank you all for joining us on our fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings call. The entire United family is very pleased to have Oscar in the room with us today. And like him, we're all looking forward to his full-time return. 
In the meantime, I and the management team want to thank our employees for making 2015 a great year for United. We achieved record financial and operational performance, made meaningful strides towards enhancing the customer experience, and this fall, we committed to continuously earning the trust of customers and employees. While we are -- while we still have more work to do, I am proud of the tangible measures of success we have already demonstrated, none of which could have been accomplished without the hard work and commitment from the entire United team. Over the last 3 months, I have visited each of our hubs, and I'm consistently impressed by our employees' enthusiasm, dedication and strong desire to win, and it is an honor to work alongside them as we take the next steps toward improving United. 
Today, we reported 2015 pretax earnings of $4.5 billion, our highest level of earnings in United's history. I am pleased to announce that through our profit-sharing program, employees will be able to share in this success as we pay out $698 million, our largest distribution ever. For the year, we achieved a return on invested capital of 21%, also marking the highest ROIC ever reported by United. These numbers represent a meaningful improvement year-over-year as well as progress closing the gap in financial performance with our 2 closest competitors. 
A major contributor to our strong financial performance is improvement in our operation. When compared to last year, our completion rate improved by more than 1 point and on-time performance was 6 points better for the full year 2015. This was particularly evident in the fourth quarter as our on-time performance and completion factor were the best since the merger. A well-run operation is a top priority for customers, and we are working extremely hard to become the consistently reliable airline our customers can depend on. 
We also want to be a great place to work for our employees. We have a responsibility to provide them with contracts they deserve, and this fall, we made significant progress to do just that. Evidence of this progress can be found in the 2 new agreements covering our pilots and technicians that are currently in the ratification process. Additionally, we reached an agreement to open negotiations on new contracts for our airport and customer service work groups more than 1 year in advance of the amendable date. We are also continuing negotiations with our flight attendants and are hopeful that we reach an agreement with them this year. I want to thank these union groups for their commitment to reaching agreements that will lead our workforce in the years to come. 
I am pleased with the progress we made in 2015. We took significant actions that have led to both strong financial and operational performance. We are excited for the opportunities in 2016 as we focus on making the changes necessary to become the airline that we, our customers and our shareholders expected to be. 
Now I'll turn it over to Greg.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brett, and thank you to everyone for joining the call this morning. I'd like to take this opportunity to thank our employees for their efforts this year, particularly during the busy holiday travel season. And as Brett mentioned, we have made mean
componenttext:
Thanks, Brett, and thank you to everyone for joining the call this morning. I'd like to take this opportunity to thank our employees for their efforts this year, particularly during the busy holiday travel season. And as Brett mentioned, we have made meaningful improvements to our operation, and we couldn't have done it without the continued hard work and dedication of our employees. 
Due to the great work of the United team, in 2015, we had best on-time arrival performance since the merger. Additionally, we had a better completion rate than our network competitors in both New York and Chicago and better completion in Houston than our network competitor in Dallas. We also continue to deliver well on bag performance. In fact, during 2015, we achieved record bag performance for 7 of the 12 months in the year. As reflection of our commitment to operational excellence, we recently launched a new United Global Performance Commitment for corporate customers in 2016. With this program, we will compensate eligible corporate accounts if we fail to meet our operational targets for the year. This clearly demonstrates our level of confidence and commitment to continue to improve United's operational performance. 
Looking forward to 2016, we have a number of opportunities to further improve the operation. One change we implemented earlier this month was an increase in the amount of out-and-back flying we do. Said differently, we are increasing the amount of flying that begins at a hub and then travels to another station before returning directly back to the originating hub. In 2015, approximately 35% of our flights followed an out-and-back pattern. At the beginning of this year, we transitioned to approximately 70% of our flights that now follow this pattern, which is more consistent with that of our peers. 
This does 2 things for us. First, it dramatically reduces the complexity of the operation. In addition, it helps to isolate the impact of weather and air traffic control-related events to the impacted hub while mitigating the impact on our other hubs. We believe that reducing this complexity and limiting the impact of weather on our operations will drive improved reliability and efficiency and provide a better experience for our customers and our employees. 
In closing, I want to thank the entire operations team for all their hard work in 2015. I am proud of the significant progress we made this year, and I look forward to building on these successes in 2016. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jim.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. I would also like to thank our customers for their business in 2015. As Brett indicated earlier, we want to be our customers' first choice on every trip they take, and we will achieve this by continually building their trust. Accomplishing t
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. I would also like to thank our customers for their business in 2015. As Brett indicated earlier, we want to be our customers' first choice on every trip they take, and we will achieve this by continually building their trust. Accomplishing this won't be easy and won't happen overnight, but the entire team is committed to this goal. 
In the fourth quarter, our consolidated unit revenue declined 6%. The 4 primary factors we identified at the beginning of the quarter impacted our revenue performance as expected: a strong U.S. dollar, the effects of lower oil prices, pressure as a result of margin-accretive initiatives and competitive pricing actions. However, we also faced some unanticipated headwinds during the quarter. First, the attacks in Paris put pressure on bookings across the Atlantic during the weeks that followed the event. Second, our strong operational performance resulted in more completed flights than initially planned. While this is beneficial to margin and excellent for our customers, the additional capacity provided a tailwind to unit cost but a headwind to PRASM. Additionally, in the quarter, we saw oil prices continue to fall, which provided incremental pressure to our Houston hub and corporate energy business while ultimately being a tailwind to our fuel expense and overall earnings. Finally, demand declined throughout the quarter, as demonstrated by downward revisions for fourth quarter GDP expectations. 
Turning to the first quarter. We expect our unit revenue to decline approximately 6% to 8% year-over-year, with domestic PRASM down approximately 4% to 6% and international PRASM down approximately 8% to 10%. The major drivers for the first quarter revenue performance are expected to be largely the same as the fourth quarter. For the consolidated system, we expect foreign exchange impact to account for 1 point of year-over-year PRASM pressure. Given further decline in oil prices, we anticipate continued pressure on lower surcharges, particularly in Japan, which we expect will account for approximately 1 point of weakness. Lower oil prices have reduced revenue from our corporate energy customers, and we are also beginning to see a decline in revenue from the broader non-energy Houston market. The combined revenue pressure from both these energy contracts and the Houston hub is anticipated to be approximately 1 point. Finally, we also expect the current competitive pricing actions will drive approximately 1.5 points of decline in the quarter. 
As we've mentioned before, while PRASM is an important metric, there are other metrics at United that are equally or even more important, principally profit margin and earnings. As we construct our network and deploy our assets across it, our primary goal is to increase earnings and margins. To that end, there are certain decisions that may be dilutive to unit revenue but are margin accretive for the business. Over the next several years, we have specific initiatives in place that may have just that effect. Our upgauging initiative is one such example. By reducing departures and increasing the average gauge of our airplanes, we will grow our capacity very efficiently, which will be a tailwind for CASM while putting pressure on our PRASM performance. I would add that in the case where we replace a single-cabin 50-seat aircraft with a 2-cabin regional small mainline aircraft, there is additional revenue that we can generate from having Economy Plus and first-class seats. In 2016, we anticipate increasing our average gauge by approximately 5% and reducing our average departures by approximately 1% compared to 2015. 
Another opportunity to grow earnings comes from further improvements through our pricing and segmentation capabilities. As we have seen in 2015, this has become an increasingly important component to revenue management. The more we segment our fares, the better opportunity we will have to minimize revenue dilution. The first phase is the rollout of our bundled fare offerings this month. This allows customers to purchase a collection of products suited to their travel as opposed to a more manual process of selecting from an ala carte menu. The second phase, which we expect to launch in the second half of this year, will complement this bundled structure by introducing an entry-level fare that will appeal to the purely price-sensitive customer. We believe this slate of offerings will allow further segmentation across United's customer base while also avoiding some levels of revenue dilution built into our pricing structures today. 
Another way we intend to improve our revenue performance is through continuing to improve the reliability of the operation. Reliability is a top priority for our customers, and over the last several years, our revenue has suffered from the inconsistency in our operation. As Greg mentioned, the operation has made significant strides forward, and we expect over time for this to generate additional revenue. Earning the trust of our customers is critical for long-term earnings improvement, and the great work from Greg and his team are cornerstone for that success. 
With respect to capacity and as a result of reduced transatlantic flying, we will reduce our expectations for first quarter capacity and now anticipate growing approximately 1.5% to 2.5%. For the full year, we still expect to grow 1.5% and 2.5%. 
As we all know, there are certain pockets of the globe that are experiencing economic slowdowns. We are thoughtfully addressing these issues by repositioning capacity to the areas that are experiencing the most economic growth. An example of this is what we are doing in Houston. Due to the decline in the energy business, as we have discussed, our Houston hub has experienced significant yield pressure. Consequently, we are shifting capacity away from Houston and into other growing markets like Denver and San Francisco. We will remain disciplined in allocating our capacity in the markets that will generate the highest profitability. 
In conclusion, we are continuing to implement margin-accretive initiatives, product improvement and other initiatives across the commercial organization to attract and retain more high-value business customers. In 2016, we anticipate sequential quarter-over-quarter improvement and expect that the actions we are taking, along with an improving operation, will further earn the trust of our customers. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Gerry.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. I would also like to thank our employees for helping to make 2015 a record year for United. Their hard work led to our success this year, and I know they will bring the same energy and dedication to our efforts in 2016. For the fourth quart
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. I would also like to thank our employees for helping to make 2015 a record year for United. Their hard work led to our success this year, and I know they will bring the same energy and dedication to our efforts in 2016. 
For the fourth quarter, we reported net income of $934 million or $2.54 per share, excluding special items. This is double what we earned in the fourth quarter of 2014 and marks the seventh straight quarter of record earnings. For the full year 2015, we reported $4.5 billion of net income or $11.88 per share, excluding special items, and we achieved a pretax margin of 11.9%, a 6.8 point increase versus last year and the highest in United's history. 
Disciplined cost management has been a key contributor to our results this year. For the full year, our unit cost, excluding fuel, profit sharing and third-party expenses, decreased 0.7%, more than 1 point lower than our initial 2015 guidance, despite nearly 0.5 point of capacity reduction from our original plans. As Jim mentioned, our upgauging strategy was a meaningful contributor to our CASM performance in 2015, and we expect this contribution will continue as we ramp up the program through 2019. 
Looking forward to 2016, we expect our CASM, excluding the impact of new labor deals, to increase approximately 1%. The new labor agreements with our pilots and technicians, currently open for vote, would add approximately 2.5 points of CASM for the year. This is consistent with our commitment to maintain CASM growth below inflation over a planning cycle. 
Two years ago, we set a goal to achieve $1 billion in annual nonfuel savings by 2017. We now expect to achieve this goal in 2016, a full year in advance of our original timeline. This focus on continuous improvement and durable savings will not end as we still have opportunities to improve efficiency and manage cost prudently. 
Turning to fuel expense. For 2016, we are 17% hedged and are in a loss position of approximately $225 million. Our portfolio allows us to participate in 98% of any future declines. We are currently evaluating the structure of our hedge program, and in the meantime, we have not added any new hedges since July of 2015. 
Based on the guidance we have provided for cost and revenue in the first quarter of 2016, we expect our pretax margin to be between 8% and 10% in the first quarter. 
Moving on to cash flow. In 2015, we generated $6 billion of operating cash flow and $2.5 billion of free cash flow. In deciding how best to allocate capital, I also look at cash flow net of aircraft financing since the decision to lease versus purchase an aircraft can have a material impact on the traditional calculation of free cash flow. When incorporating proceeds from long-term aircraft financing, we generated over $4 billion in adjusted free cash flow for 2015. I am pleased that we continue to generate significant cash flow in excess of both what we need to run our business and what we need to secure our future. Taking all that into account, in the fourth quarter, we spent approximately $520 million repurchasing United stock, about double the amount we spent in the prior quarter. For the full year 2015, we spent $1.2 billion in the share buyback program. Looking forward, I expect that we will spend at least $750 million repurchasing stock in the first quarter and now plan to complete our current $3 billion program substantially earlier than originally anticipated. 
One of the tools we use is a 10b5-1 plan, which allows us to purchase stock throughout the quarter even during periods when we might otherwise be unable to be in the market. As an example, we purchased shares on every trading day so far this month. We also use our cash to fulfill one of my primary missions of ensuring that we continue to make all appropriate investments in our business. In 2016, we expect to spend $2.7 billion to $2.9 billion for capital investments, including approximately $1.1 billion of non-aircraft CapEx. This would be roughly $100 million more than 2015 for non-aircraft CapEx. This increase is driven almost entirely by incremental technology investments. We believe that further investment in our technology is critical for our ability to compete in the years to come. 
We also expect to invest approximately $1.7 billion on our fleet in 2016. We plan to take delivery of 14 737s, 5 787-9s, our first 777-300ER and 9 used A319s. We will also add 40 Embraer E175s to our regional fleet. Our fleet investments this year also include predelivery deposits associated with the order we announced today for 40 737-700 aircraft to be delivered beginning mid-2017. As we have stated in the past, we are continuing to shift more flying towards the mainline operation as our regional flying is being reduced. It is our expectation that our current fleet of approximately 250 50-seat aircraft will be reduced by more than half by the end of 2019. While this new 737 order does provide replacement capacity to partially offset the reduction in the regional operation, we are continuing to pursue additional aircraft to continue upgauging and meet our capacity plans. 
We are also utilizing our cash to continue to secure our future. In 2015, we prepaid $1.2 billion of debt, including $300 million in the fourth quarter. As of the end of the year, our gross debt balance, including capitalized operating leases, was $17 billion, $1.1 billion less than the end of the prior year. 
In 2015, we also contributed more than $800 million to our pension plans, and as of year-end, our unfunded pension liability is now $1.5 billion, a $700 million reduction from the prior year. As we head towards well-funded status for our pensions, we anticipate contributing approximately $400 million to our pension plans in 2016. 
In conclusion, 2015 was a very good year for United, as seen in nearly every financial metric. Moving into 2016, we look forward to delivering strong earnings performance and demonstrating disciplined capital allocation. I believe that the investments we are making in our people and our product will lead to a strong future that will benefit our employees, customers and investors. 
I'll now turn it back over to Jonathan.
