headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And for Oscar, you've talked with us about winning back the frontline. Do these increases in wages accomplish this in your mind? Or are there still incremental expenses that are required that might not be captured in the labor line, whether that's,
componenttext: Okay. And for Oscar, you've talked with us about winning back the frontline. Do these increases in wages accomplish this in your mind? Or are there still incremental expenses that are required that might not be captured in the labor line, whether that's, I don't know, better tools for employees, new uniforms, that sort of thing that could pressure CASM a little bit further?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, it's probably a little early for me to actually quantify what the impacts of these are, but my commitment is to balance both our commitment to our employees and make the appropriate investments and prioritize investments while understanding that we
componenttext: Jamie, it's probably a little early for me to actually quantify what the impacts of these are, but my commitment is to balance both our commitment to our employees and make the appropriate investments and prioritize investments while understanding that we have a broader stakeholder basis, so it's a delicate balance between those 2. And again, the more time I spend out in the field understanding the needs, the needs aren't as great as you think, expense-wise. So certainly, comp is one, but beyond that, I think building the right systems, tools, uniforms, things like coffee and peanuts and all that, all add up, but they're just the appropriate-level investments that we'll strike a balance with. But again, I can't quantify anything at this point in time.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, let me just add that, that process has started. It started last year. And the CASM guidance you see for this year includes some of that already. Some of the tools and some of the other investments we're making, that's rolling into the CASM guidance
componenttext: Jamie, let me just add that, that process has started. It started last year. And the CASM guidance you see for this year includes some of that already. Some of the tools and some of the other investments we're making, that's rolling into the CASM guidance that you see. And let me just -- by the way, I need to clarify to Dan on the NOL. As of 12/31/15, the remaining NOL is a little closer to $8 billion than $9 billion. Sorry to interrupt you.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, that's fine. Actually, for follow-up, while I have you, Gerry, the 73-700 is a larger gauge than, at least, I thought you were looking at in terms of potentially bridging that gap between 76 CRJs and, I guess, the A319. So what shifted in terms o
componenttext: Yes. No, that's fine. Actually, for follow-up, while I have you, Gerry, the 73-700 is a larger gauge than, at least, I thought you were looking at in terms of potentially bridging that gap between 76 CRJs and, I guess, the A319. So what shifted in terms of the decision-making process? Does this entirely eliminate the need for something smaller than the 319 in the mainline? How did the price of fuel impact the calculus? Any additional color there?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would say the price of fuel really doesn't impact our decisions on long-term fleet orders, but I would say that for this batch of aircraft, where we looked at all the variations, in fact, the 319 as well as the 737 and the 100-seat opportunities f
componenttext: Sure. I would say the price of fuel really doesn't impact our decisions on long-term fleet orders, but I would say that for this batch of aircraft, where we looked at all the variations, in fact, the 319 as well as the 737 and the 100-seat opportunities from both Embraer and Bombardier, for this batch of aircraft, the 700 was the winner. As I mentioned, we will continue to look at aircraft and we will continue to look at each of those aircraft types going forward.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then Jim, one for you. You noted competitive capacity actions at about 1.5 point of headwind again in the first quarter. Are you noticing any changes in competitive pricing actions either domestically or internationally? And do you worry that those worsen in a lower fuel environment?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julie, I don't want to comment on competitive pricing. Obviously, this business is very competitive, and we obviously match capacity and our demand given the pricing structures that are out there. But I don't want to make any comments on competitive prici
componenttext: Julie, I don't want to comment on competitive pricing. Obviously, this business is very competitive, and we obviously match capacity and our demand given the pricing structures that are out there. But I don't want to make any comments on competitive pricing actions. We will, as I mentioned in the script that given where competitive pricing actions are today, that the hypothetical -- the assumption that that's where we are today, we begin to lap some of that effect by the time we hit the third quarter.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then just on the phases of cabin segmentation, that was certainly helpful. At some point, do you anticipate being able to put some quantification around what that can add in terms of revenues?
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then just on the phases of cabin segmentation, that was certainly helpful. At some point, do you anticipate being able to put some quantification around what that can add in terms of revenues?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we look forward to doing that. That segmentation that I've talked about, we've been working hard on it in 2015, and so we're excited about rolling it out going forward. What that will do for us is a couple of things. One, it will allow us to compete
componenttext: Yes, we look forward to doing that. That segmentation that I've talked about, we've been working hard on it in 2015, and so we're excited about rolling it out going forward. What that will do for us is a couple of things. One, it will allow us to compete with ultra-low-cost carriers much more effectively, which means more fare product for customers that are looking for just that price point. And it will also, as I mentioned, help us remove some of the dilution that we have in our pricing structure today. So I'm not ready yet to kind of quantify, but as we roll it out in the second half of the year, I look forward to updating you on that.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Evercore ISI, we have Duane Pfennigwerth on line.
componenttext: From Evercore ISI, we have Duane Pfennigwerth on line.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple questions from me. We get a lot of questions from investors about closing the gap from a margin perspective to the industry. It looks like based on the 1Q guidance, and certainly, 1Q is not the year, and you've got some hedge impact there, b
componenttext: Just a couple questions from me. We get a lot of questions from investors about closing the gap from a margin perspective to the industry. It looks like based on the 1Q guidance, and certainly, 1Q is not the year, and you've got some hedge impact there, but it looks like that gap actually widens in the March quarter. So is closing that gap still a goal for the company? What should we be advising investors in that regard? And if so, over what time frame?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Duane, I'll start. It's Gerry. So it is still the goal. We've never put a time frame on it, but we're very focused on doing what we can do both on the cost side and the revenue side to continue to maximize our margin. But we haven't, at this point, p
componenttext: Hey, Duane, I'll start. It's Gerry. So it is still the goal. We've never put a time frame on it, but we're very focused on doing what we can do both on the cost side and the revenue side to continue to maximize our margin. But we haven't, at this point, put a time frame on it.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duane, I think from the network side, we're very focused on growing efficiently. And so that -- we've talked about upgauging a lot over the past year, and 2015 was the first phase of that, where we -- our seat growth with the use of slimline, as Gerry men
componenttext: Duane, I think from the network side, we're very focused on growing efficiently. And so that -- we've talked about upgauging a lot over the past year, and 2015 was the first phase of that, where we -- our seat growth with the use of slimline, as Gerry mentioned, contributed to the CASM side, comes at a lower RASM but had significant contribution to the CASM side. We'll continue to do that as we also look at frequency reduction and upgauging into the mainline aircraft from the regional aircraft, and we can do that seat-neutral in certain markets. As we upgauge that and it drives lower departures, it actually is really efficient growth, and it comes with efficient fuel cost. And so it all kind of works together, and we're very much focused on driving that this year.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duane, if I could just be maybe slightly more definitive on the issue of industry comparisons and all of that, it's a competitive industry, and I'm a competitive guy. And so lest anything else be said, we will always have our eyesight on folks that are ma
componenttext: Duane, if I could just be maybe slightly more definitive on the issue of industry comparisons and all of that, it's a competitive industry, and I'm a competitive guy. And so lest anything else be said, we will always have our eyesight on folks that are maybe, at this point in time, sort of performing a little better than us. I'll tell you what the most critical question around that is: Do you have the potential? Do you have the capacity? Do you have the ability with your network, with your people, with all that? And one of the things I've seen in the relatively short time I've been here is a tremendous amount of all of those things, starting with energy and excitement of our frontline employees. Where, frankly, it's where it really starts. So at the end of the day, over the long term, we certainly believe our relative earnings profile will improve, and when and how and all that, that's the work that I've got to get done here over the next few months.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Duane, I want to just -- Duane, on upgauging, remember that 2016 is a year where there's a dip in that process from 2015. It's just the cadence of new aircraft orders. That ramps up again in 2017 and continues nicely through 2019.
componenttext: And Duane, I want to just -- Duane, on upgauging, remember that 2016 is a year where there's a dip in that process from 2015. It's just the cadence of new aircraft orders. That ramps up again in 2017 and continues nicely through 2019.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that comment. And Oscar, personally, we're all amazed that you're on this call and wish you a continued strong recovery. Just on the network side, I had one question. Please check us on this. But we went back and looked at utilization changes
componenttext: I appreciate that comment. And Oscar, personally, we're all amazed that you're on this call and wish you a continued strong recovery. Just on the network side, I had one question. Please check us on this. But we went back and looked at utilization changes, aircraft hours per day over the course of 2015. And many had a nice year-to-year improvement in that, and frankly, that was what was driving capacity growth. In the case of United, it looks like utilization was actually modestly down. We assume this is an effort to improve reliability, maybe more spares. Can you just talk about it if this is the case and the reasons behind it and if there's any cost opportunity there longer term?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. One of the things or drivers [ph] is our seats per aircraft are going up, so we're driving growth that way. But clearly, as we reinvested in reliability, we want to make sure that the network is driving the right results from a reliability stage. In
componenttext: Yes. One of the things or drivers [ph] is our seats per aircraft are going up, so we're driving growth that way. But clearly, as we reinvested in reliability, we want to make sure that the network is driving the right results from a reliability stage. In addition, part of our strategy of growing seats is to lower our stage length. And so some of that utilization to drive improved network is from a lower stage length, which is driving block down. So it's a combination of couple of things, both investment in reliability as well as our network strategy going forward to set us up to grow efficiently.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could elaborate a bit on where you're cutting capacity out of Houston and where you plan to grow in San Francisco and Denver for the network side.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Edward, this is Jim. I think if you think about what we're looking at for Houston in 2016, we're going to grow Houston approximately slightly up, about 2%. I think given what we're seeing in the market and as my comments on the energy and what's happening
componenttext: Edward, this is Jim. I think if you think about what we're looking at for Houston in 2016, we're going to grow Houston approximately slightly up, about 2%. I think given what we're seeing in the market and as my comments on the energy and what's happening in the Houston hub, we'll probably keep that relatively flat for the year. And so that capacity, as we looked at places of strength, San Fran and Denver to the East Coast are what we're focused on to fill in some holes that we don't serve today. They'll be clearly focused on business markets, and you'll see the strong commitment in Houston just adjusted slightly to use that capacity in markets that are performing better right now.

componenttext: Okay. And that's -- you're keeping growth in Houston at 2% this year. That's correct?

componenttext: No, our plan was to grow at about 2%. I think you'll see it relatively flat in 2016 given the market.

componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to United Continental Holdings Earnings Conference Call for the First Quarter of 2016. My name is Brandon, and I'll be your conference facilitator today. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded and is copyrighted. Please note that no portion of the call may be recorded, transcribed or rebroadcast without the company's permission. Your participation implies your consent to our recording of this call. If you do not agree with these terms, simply drop off the line. 
I will now turn the presentation to your host for today's call, Jonathan Ireland, Managing Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brandon. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to United's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Yesterday, we issued our earnings release and separate investor update. Additionally, this morning, we issued a presentation to accompany
componenttext:
Thank you, Brandon. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to United's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. 
Yesterday, we issued our earnings release and separate investor update. 
Additionally, this morning, we issued a presentation to accompany this call. All three of these items are available on our website at ir.united.com. 
Information on yesterday's release and investor update and remarks made during this conference call may contain forward-looking statements, which represent the company's current expectations or beliefs concerning future events and financial performance. All forward-looking statements are based upon information currently available to the company. A number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from our current expectations. Please refer to our press release, Form 10-Q and other reports filed with the SEC by United Continental Holdings and United Airlines for more thorough discussion of these factors. 
Also during the course of this call, we will discuss several non-GAAP financial measures. For a reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures to GAAP measures, please refer to the tables at the end of our earnings release and investor update, copies of which are available on our website. 
Unless otherwise noted, special charges are excluded as we walk you through our numbers for the quarter. These items are detailed in our earnings release. 
Joining us here in Chicago to discuss our results are President and CEO, Oscar Munoz; Vice Chairman and Chief Revenue Officer, Jim Compton; and Senior Vice President, Finance and Acting Chief Financial Officer, Gerry Laderman. We also have Chief Operating Officer and Executive Vice President, Greg Hart, in the room to assist in the Q&A. 
And now, I'd like to turn the call over to Oscar.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jonathan, and thank you all for joining us this morning. For the first quarter, we recorded a pretax profit of $688 million, excluding special items, our eighth consecutive quarter of profitability and our highest first quarter pretax profit
componenttext:
Thank you, Jonathan, and thank you all for joining us this morning. 
For the first quarter, we recorded a pretax profit of $688 million, excluding special items, our eighth consecutive quarter of profitability and our highest first quarter pretax profit ever. 
We achieved diluted  earnings per share of $1.23, excluding special items, a 28% increase versus last year when adjusting for taxes and as you all know, we repurchased $1.5 billion of common stock. 
As I think back on the quarter, I'm particularly proud of our operational performance, which, again, showed significant improvement. Our first quarter consolidated on-time performance was more than 12 points better year-over-year, and we had 3,600 fewer cancelations, a 20% reduction versus the first quarter last year. 
This improvement demonstrates the dedication, fashion and hard work of United aviation professionals. I know as I cover the system, I see the renewed engagement, excitement and energy that our nearly 86,000 employees around the world are bringing to work every day.  I'd like to thank them for their efforts and dedication, particularly as they work through this winter season. 
This quarter's results showed great strides forward and with our sense of shared purpose and the investments we continue to make people, processes and systems, we are positioned for even greater success in the months ahead. 
On the commercial side of the business, we launched our global performance guarantee, which makes our corporate contracts to operational performance, trying both our confidence and commitment to running a consistently reliable operation. 
With respect to our network as part of our industry-leading Pacific strategy, we announced an enhanced partnership with Air China and a joint venture with Air New Zealand, both of which are expected to expand our global reach. 
We also announced several routes that further strengthen our global footprint, including the the first-ever nonstop service by a U.S. carrier to Hangzhou, our sixth Chinese destination. 
We also became first U.S. airline to service Israel nonstop from the West Coast, connecting 2 of the world's most influential technology leaders. 
Now having said this, we know we are facing some revenue challenges. We're making good progress on a number of initiatives to improve revenue, but some of them like a more reliable operation, improved customer satisfaction, as you know, have a lighting effect. I expect these improvements, along with other commercial initiatives, will drive improved revenue performance as we move into the back half of this year. 
Now turning to our people. As I've said many times, reaching new agreements with our representative employee is one of my highest priorities. We've already made great progress as our pilot, dispatchers and IAM representative workers all ratifying contract expansion this year. This represents half of our union as workforce. 
We remain focused on getting contracts like these for our flight attendants and technicians, and we will working closely with the unions to make that happen. 
Lastly, as you heard, yesterday, we announced additional changes to our board. I want to welcome the 2 new board members and I look forward to working alongside them and our other recently elected members over the upcoming years. 
Now I'd like to turn it over the call over to Jim and Gerry. Jim?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Oscar. As you can see on Slide 6, through the first quarter, our consolidated unit revenue declined to 7.4%. The 4 primary drivers were identified at the beginning of the quarter impacted our CASM performance in line with initial expectations. I
componenttext:
Thanks, Oscar. As you can see on Slide 6, through the first quarter, our consolidated unit revenue declined to 7.4%. The 4 primary drivers were identified at the beginning of the quarter impacted our CASM performance in line with initial expectations. 
In addition, while we had anticipated that the timing of Easter would have some impact on close-in business travel, it proves to be greater than we had expected. 
While we have seen total bookings return to pre-Easter levels, we are closely monitoring the mix of business and leisure bookings. 
Turning to the second quarter. We expect our passenger unit revenue to decline approximately 6.5% to 8.5% year-over-year, with domestic PRASM expected to be down approximately 3.5% to 5.5% and international PRASM expected to be down approximately 11% to 13%. 
While the primary drivers of this decline are consistent with the first quarter, we are beginning to lap some of the effects from last year, somewhat muting the impact on a year-over-year basis. 
For the consolidated system, we expect the strong dollar, lower surcharges, the Houston and energy market weakness and competitive pressures to drive approximately 3.25 points of softness. 
While these drivers explain a portion of the unit revenue decline, they don't capture all of it. As can be seen on Slide 7, the remaining headwinds unit revenue is largely driven by passenger demand using GDP as a proxy, not keeping pace with capacity. While any supply versus demand relationship, this is creating downward pressure on pricing. This is particularly evident in the international markets where United is more exposed than any other U.S. carrier. 
While United has consistently grown at/or below the rate of GDP, this dynamic is creating a unit revenue headwinds to United of approximately 2.5 points. 
Turning to Slide 8. We are taking specific actions in each markets to improve our unit revenue performance in this environment with the focus on maximizing near-term profitability, while also positioning ourselves to a longer-term success. 
In the domestic market, this includes redirecting capacity to capitalize on changing demand patterns, introducing entry-level fares to increase segmentation and reduce dilution, launching marketing and sales initiatives that leverage our improving liability and further rolling out 2-cabin service in top business markets. 
We expect that these actions, along with improving reliability and customer satisfaction, will drive domestic unit revenue to be flat to positive in the fourth quarter. 
With respect to the international markets, we expect lapping PRASM to turn positive by the fourth quarter, benefiting from reduced Brazil flying. 
While we are currently experiencing softness in the Atlantic due to recent events, we see strong summer bookings and expect to get close to flat PRASM by the fourth quarter. 
Unit revenue recovery in the Pacific will take more time and surcharges and a strong U.S. dollar continue to impact our performance. 
In spite of this, we are very optimistic that the Pacific entity, one of our true competitive differentiators, will see sequential quarter-over-quarter improvement this year despite continued pressure from the industry growth, which is not uncommon in developing high opportunity markets like China. 
We are also prepared to reduce overall capacity where appropriate. We have made some targeted reductions to our schedule, pulling down flying in Houston, Brazil and the Middle East. 
And as you can see, on Slide 9, we now expect our 2016 capacity to grow 1% to 2%, 0.5-point  reduction from our reviews full year capacity guidance. 
In conclusion, during the first quarter, we continue to generate high levels of profitability despite the unit revenue pressures we experienced across our system. We are taking very deliberate actions within our network and will continue to adjust our flying with a goal to maximize long-term profitability and return to positive unit revenues. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Gerry.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. Good morning, everyone. A summary of our financial performance for the quarter can be seen on Slide 11. Our net income declined by approximately $200 million year-over-year as this quarter was the first quarter in a number of years in which
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. Good morning, everyone. A summary of our financial performance for the quarter can be seen on Slide 11. 
Our net income declined by approximately $200 million year-over-year as this quarter was the first quarter in a number of years in which we booked significant federal taxes. 
Pretax earnings improved by approximately $100 million due to lower oil prices, partially offset by lower revenue and higher nonfuel expense. 
Our pretax margin was 8.4%, a meaningful improvement compared to last year. 
More significantly, when adjusted for taxes, our earnings per share of $1.23 increased 28% versus last year. 
Details on our fuel expense, which decreased by almost $700 million year-over-year, are shown on Slide 12. This decrease was driven by lower fuel prices, improved fuel efficiency and reduced hedge losses. 
Looking forward, while we have not added to our hedge book since July of 2015, we are still 12% hedged for the remaining 9 months of 2016, and as of yesterday, are on loss position of approximately $80 million, including premium expense. 
Moving to Slide 13. Nonfuel unit cost for the quarter grew 1.3% when excluding special charges, profit sharing and third party expenses. We continue to manage air cost to improve the efficiency and cost structure of the airline. 
For the second quarter, we expect nonfuel unit cost to grow 2.5% to 3.5%, and for the full year, we now expect unit cost to grow 2% to 3%. This guidance includes the benefit of annual efficiency savings initiatives totaling over $1.1 billion. These savings initiatives were achieved full year in advance around our initial expectation and are providing over $100 million more in sustainable savings than our original goal. 
Our guidance also includes the impact of the 3 recently ratified labor agreement. We expect the newly ratified IAM agreement have a marginal impact on 2016 expenses. For 2017, we expect the impact of 3 contracts to be approximately 0.75-point to CASM. 
Based on the guidance we had provided for cost and revenue, we expect our pretax margin to be between 13% and 15% for the second quarter. 
With respect to cash, in the first quarter, we generated approximately $1.2 billion of operating cash flow and $376 million of free cash flow. 
As you can see on Slide 14, during the quarter, we invested approximately $820 million in the business. We took delivery of 3 787s, 2  737 and 1 used A319, and we added 6 Embraer 175 to our original fleet. 
We also announced additional aircraft orders to 65 Boeing 737-700 aircraft. These aircraft will allow us to reduce the size of our 50-seat regional fleet to address the regional pilot shortage, while providing customers with larger 2-cabin aircraft with great amenities. 
Importantly, as we transition out of 50-seat aircraft and into a larger gauge Dreamliner aircraft, we expect to begin generating structural cost benefits of upgauging and reducing departures. 
During the quarter, we also announced plans to accelerate deliveries of certain wide-body aircrafts to facilitate the early retirement of our 747 as the 747's cost and complexity to operate continues to be a burden. This decisions does not represent an increase to overall CapEx capacity or total fleet size. 
Our sustained cash generation over the last few quarters and the discounted value of our stock led us to repurchase $1.5 billion worth of stock in the first quarter, representing 8% per shares outstanding. 
Based on the progress we've made to date and cash flow expectations for the rest of the year, we now anticipate completing our $3 billion share repurchase authorization by the end of the third quarter this year. 
In conclusion, we showed, once again, the first quarter solid cost discipline on investing our business and returning significant cash to shareholders. 
Going forward, we will continue to execute on our plan to improve our financial performance and secure a strong future for our employees, customers and shareholders. 
I'll now turn it back over to Oscar.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, sir. So while I'm pleased with all the accomplishments within the quarter, I got to say, it's a future that has seeing us excited. Thus, after spending time with many of you, our share owners over the last few months, I know there's a strong de
componenttext:
Thank you, sir. So while I'm pleased with all the accomplishments within the quarter, I got to say, it's a future that has seeing us excited. Thus, after spending time with many of you, our share owners over the last few months, I know there's a strong desire to bring more about certain initiatives we have under way and of course, their impact the the bottom line. 
To that end, we'll be holding an investor call on June 21 to describe in more detail many of these initiatives and their contributions to earnings over the next several years. I look forward to that conversation. 
But before opening up to questions, I'd like to thank our customers for choosing United, [indiscernible] we have a choice. We appreciate your business. 
So with that that, I'll turn it over back to Jonathan.

componenttext: So there's no mistake you met our various airlines domestically are built differently, and we clearly have our own strength and challenges, our higher cost hubs, our construction early a little less reliable. I think of it from the standpoint. If we have I believe better business markets and certainly better international gateways. They're a little bit more competitive than others, but as we think about building a playbook, our only playbook, not copying others, is I think the strategic work that we have to continue to do. And so, as I think of your question, I think we have certain double down on these areas of strategic focus. Certainly, we need to win on revenue, and it's just not markets and scheduling price for the products and service. Execution, which we're doing a good job already, reliability certainly product as Gerry talked about that significant way. Cost, of course, including that and then technology, which we haven't talked about, and we look forward to sharing some of that in June. And then people, they always kind of wink when we say this, but winning on trust with our employees and then speaking to them and then through to our customers and of course, our share owners. So we're still in the early innings, the momentum is building and the system across all these areas, but it's a combination of all of those, David.

componenttext: This is Jim. The way on the international side is clearly -- depending on the regions of the world, take China, for instance, where our passage demand is growing at a fast pace even in that high-class segment win. So we believe that over the long term, that, that capacity demand will come online. We're excited about is that our uniqueness as to how we're participating in China. It's unique in a sense that -- as Oscar mentioned 2 new secondary cities in China. That growth that I mentioned out of China after that will come from secondary cities. But the fleets that we have and the flexibility of the 787, it's really allowing us to play in that market at a very early-stage in a very profitable entity that runs at a high profitability and frankly our profitability that's no different than our domestic. So we believe that as demand catches up, the capacity level out there, we'll be able to close that year-over-year RASM and I mentioned in my comments, we actually see closing much of that during the year as we move to the fourth quarter.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oscar, there's little question that you delivered a pretty unimpressive guide for the second quarter. I realize that with everything going on with the board, that may have been a distraction, you're getting involved with the flight attendant negotiations.
componenttext: Oscar, there's little question that you delivered a pretty unimpressive guide for the second quarter. I realize that with everything going on with the board, that may have been a distraction, you're getting involved with the flight attendant negotiations. Nobody is accusing you of not having a full plate here. But traditionally, when companies start falling further and further behind their competitors and based on the guide that is what you expect in the second quarter, they're faced with 3 choices. You can do nothing, you can simply try harder or you can come up with a new plan. So my question is simple, does mediocrity suffice, is fixing United as simple as rolling up your sleeves and relying on easier comps? Or is something significantly more radical, a change in course ultimately required?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is that a leading question, Jamie? I'm going to go with mediocrity for $200 please. I think it's one of the things that is important to know is that we didn't conceded in anything on anyone. And so what we've been is declining profitably, I watch it and m
componenttext: Is that a leading question, Jamie? I'm going to go with mediocrity for $200 please. I think it's one of the things that is important to know is that we didn't conceded in anything on anyone. And so what we've been is declining profitably, I watch it and monitor how that works. We need to be, in my mind, bit more disruptive in the marketplace. I think we've been outstanding by a little bit too much, not exactly what that means and how we do it thoughtfully and from a shareholder of sort value-creating perspective, is the work we're getting to do. Interestingly not, I have a couple board new board members of a lot of knowledge in that space. I will lean hard on them with that regard. But no, it definitely has to change,  accepting the same things comes to me over and over especially in those markets [indiscernible] The decreasing demand overall global economic make sure increasing expenses on the labor side and all those things, we have to do things differently to many, many factors. And so you will see some of that thrust here over the next few months as far as the initiatives, some of the value of those initiatives will be there, but again, there is a lagging effect. But no, there is no one standing by here just waiting for things to clear up and hopefully, we'll get better. We got to take some action.

componenttext: Yes. Well, I'll just correct one thing. I think my family here has been energized already, so we got good hard step on that. How and long it will take? The way I see it and monitor it and presented it very transparent to you, every little step we take forward, we're going to highlight for you and how long it's going to take, it's hard to tell. We didn't get here overnight and we're  likely not to get out overnight. But I want to have initiatives that have a more immediate sort of value that you can see. I really believe in this concept of prove, not promises. Again, my history is leading with that. And that's what we're going to work through. Again, as far as timing, Jamie, it's too early for me to tell you any specific time frame.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Helane, this is Jim. You're right, seasonally, our first quarter is our more difficult quarter, and we're working hard in terms of that sequential RASM to improve that. Now I do want to emphasize international exposure. The domestic RASM from the first qu
componenttext: Helane, this is Jim. You're right, seasonally, our first quarter is our more difficult quarter, and we're working hard in terms of that sequential RASM to improve that. Now I do want to emphasize international exposure. The domestic RASM from the first quarter, the second quarter does with our guidance show as sequential improvement. So we are focused very much on international side, in particular, and we've made some capacity, that's part of our guidance down to 1% to 2% capacity guidance. Net canceling drop from our previous guidance is all international. So what is to react to the market out there on the international side and to make sure that our capacity was more in line with demand. As we move through -- particularly, it's still the second quarter a shoulder period, for instance, in trans-Atlantic, we see strong bookings in the summertime in trans-Atlantic that will help with that sequential RASM as we move through the year. We've made initiatives in Latin America that beginning in the second quarter, our capacity to the rest of the years is basically flat after doing seasonality adjusted capacity to capture demand in each markets, for instance, that drove our capacity up. Very strong margins but put pressure on RASM. So our focus is on international side. The initiatives to move capacity and to write places as well as to drive the initiatives. And in addition, the great work by the operations team and reliability given that work, we're beginning to see already in our hubs signs of our share beginning to improve, and we think that will continue and spread and drive that RASM as we go through the year.

Those 50-seater itself don't become a plus, they don't  have a first class cabin, and we continue to see great up-sell in the first class cabin as well as strong economies there, plus sales.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Dan, thanks for the question. I think Pacific is quite frankly, the biggest sequential driver on unit revenue impact to us. And as I mentioned, -- as I mentioned some of the capacity reduction, actually all of that 0.5 points reduction on the guidanc
componenttext: Hey, Dan, thanks for the question. I think Pacific is quite frankly, the biggest sequential driver on unit revenue impact to us. And as I mentioned, -- as I mentioned some of the capacity reduction, actually all of that 0.5 points reduction on the guidance is on the international. So we'll stay really focused on the demand environment relative to capacity we have. I will say about the Pacific is also impacted but we'll start to lap some of the foreign exchange and the surcharge impact is most dramatic in the Pacific, so we'll lap some of that. So we believe even in that entity that will continue to close, move toward a flat RASM in the Pacific as we move through the year. The Pacific, as I mentioned, even markets we're adding, as Oscar mentioned, through the secondary cities, when you think about San Fran to Singapore, a very unique and innovative for us is the first nonstop market to the U.S. from Singapore. San Fran-Auckland, building on our relationships and and growing our relationships with Air New Zealand. San Fran-Tel Aviv that we launched on March 30, off to a great start and that make 2 high-tech communities and seeing great bookings there. So all of those I'd say that uniqueness of our expansion we think serves as well comes at a high level of profitability. All that being said, we've been consistent, we'll keep traffic demand and make sure that we're keeping them in line, but also remembering that we're -- international is off to a longer term play that we're really excited about.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very good, I appreciate that, Jim. I guess, just staying on the Pacific for a second here. United did find a multi-year agreement to strengthen its partnership with Air China up with a further release. I'm just wondering how that is exactly and how and wh
componenttext: Very good, I appreciate that, Jim. I guess, just staying on the Pacific for a second here. United did find a multi-year agreement to strengthen its partnership with Air China up with a further release. I'm just wondering how that is exactly and how and when that might that tie to say, increased revenue contribution on that entity?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dan. We recently signed an enhanced agreement with them that are quite frankly builds that relationship over a longer number of years. I want to be clear, it's based on the concept of the alliance world, it's not a JV world. China is not open skies,
componenttext: Yes, Dan. We recently signed an enhanced agreement with them that are quite frankly builds that relationship over a longer number of years. I want to be clear, it's based on the concept of the alliance world, it's not a JV world. China is not open skies, and so it doesn't come with antitrust immunity. But we think we have a lot of ability to grow together both relationship wise as we learn about the market from each other, both Air China learning about the U.S. market and also quite frankly, learning a lot about the Chinese market. That will bring us closer together in marketing. It will bring us closer together in marketing, that will allows us to understand the marketplace, and we think that enhance our connections through the market as we build. Not only Beijing, but as we build in some of the secondary cities. So we can increase the connecting opportunities that we have with Air China. We connect close to 200 a day over the Air China network in Beijing today, and we think there's upside that relationship within the alliance world, we're bringing much more higher level of executive attention to it. The team of senior executives will much more frequently meet with senior executives of Air China to work on those initiatives that I talked about.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Wolfe Research, we have Hunter Keay online.
componenttext: From Wolfe Research, we have Hunter Keay online.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So when we talk about the structural margin gap, I think everybody just talks about market share and hubs. And I think that's important, but I think that gets focused on a little bit too much. So much of the gap is attributable to the fact that you have a
componenttext: So when we talk about the structural margin gap, I think everybody just talks about market share and hubs. And I think that's important, but I think that gets focused on a little bit too much. So much of the gap is attributable to the fact that you have a 1500 miles stage length versus about 1,000 miles stage length to your 2 biggest peers. So that seems to me that is a structural of anything. And given that or a change in that, wouldn't that be unreasonable to assume that you have any possibility of closing the margin gap, particularly now that your cost are going to be higher. Should we expect this margin gap to permanently structural, if for no other reason than the stage length alone?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hunter, it's Oscar. I'm going to let Jim answer the stage length question specifically as we have discussed it. I'm not sure we'll give you some additional facts there to warrant maybe a different opinion. With regards to again the concept of -- from a lo
componenttext: Hunter, it's Oscar. I'm going to let Jim answer the stage length question specifically as we have discussed it. I'm not sure we'll give you some additional facts there to warrant maybe a different opinion. With regards to again the concept of -- from a long-term perspective in effect continue with that margin gap will be there forever. As I've stayed in market and the industry over the last decade even before, I know that things can change very quickly in one way or another. So not quite ready concede anything in that regard, and we'll continue to work initiatives to close or certainly narrow that margin gap in the near term. But with regard to the stage length, Jim, why don't  you cover some of that?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Oscar. Hey, Hunter, there are structural differences between network and I think of them as mainly driven by geographies. We clearly have 2 east-west coast hubs that by definition is going to indicate longer stage length. It's also those coastal h
componenttext: Thanks, Oscar. Hey, Hunter, there are structural differences between network and I think of them as mainly driven by geographies. We clearly have 2 east-west coast hubs that by definition is going to indicate longer stage length. It's also those coastal hubs are tremendous international gateways, which is why our network is really built for strong international presence and growth over time in that international flying. Our hubs are also very business-centric markets, which also means there's a lot of competition. And I think we're referring to seat chair and so forth. That result of those competition large business-centric markets. We don't have a dominant hub, they're very competitive. And again, the geography of the coastal hubs, large business Central markets drive more competition and by definition, drives more stage length. So we haven't evidence that correlates stage length directly to profitability. Stage length is somewhat a result of the geography and the strength of our hubs and again -- we think that, that have structure works for us really well, for instance, in New York, it is the [indiscernible] in New York. It allows us to make revenue management decisions on high yield flow traffic versus low-yield traffic that's unique to us. All of those things was driving national length [indiscernible].

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I would add to that really quickly, Hunter. As we begin discussion on this, certainly that's one area, but there are a lot of other factors that in effect affect our network and to optimize that network, that's discussions we're having in earnest
componenttext: I think I would add to that really quickly, Hunter. As we begin discussion on this, certainly that's one area, but there are a lot of other factors that in effect affect our network and to optimize that network, that's discussions we're having in earnest with regards to moving forward. So many factors there.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and look, I appreciate the commentary and PRASM providing trajectory. The market doesn't appear to believe you. Your stock is actually sold off more since guys provided that. So I think it has been sort of one step forward and one step back with Unit
componenttext: Yes, and look, I appreciate the commentary and PRASM providing trajectory. The market doesn't appear to believe you. Your stock is actually sold off more since guys provided that. So I think it has been sort of one step forward and one step back with United for the last 4 years. And as you talk about this margin gap closure, it becomes like all people are going to focused on. Said actually the fact is widening your operational metrics improving arguably even more concerning. So the existent -- the argument against the existing of structural disadvantage seems more feasible as time goes on. So is there a conclusion that you might draw here if that doesn't happen and you don't close the margin gap to PRASM gap that maybe there's a conclusion that that United is just too big. Is there a scenario where a couple of years down the road, if you're getting to where you need to be that we're talking about major surgery here to the network involving asset divestitures or real estate divestitures or something like that? Is there a scenario where we see structural overhaul to the network evolving shrinking the size of this company?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's way too early for anyone and particularly me, to answer the question. And so stand by. I understand your viewpoint, I understand the market's reaction, I understand the situation we're in, and that's what I'm here to do, and that's what we'll
componenttext: I think it's way too early for anyone and particularly me, to answer the question. And so stand by. I understand your viewpoint, I understand the market's reaction, I understand the situation we're in, and that's what I'm here to do, and that's what we'll get at very quickly.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, in your prepared remarks, you noted strong summer bookings, particularly in the trans-Atlantic and one of your peers last week highlighted strength in advance summer yield domestically. Are you seeing similar dynamics on the domestic market?
componenttext: Jim, in your prepared remarks, you noted strong summer bookings, particularly in the trans-Atlantic and one of your peers last week highlighted strength in advance summer yield domestically. Are you seeing similar dynamics on the domestic market?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Julie. As we talk about -- as you look at the demand environment in the second quarter, from a business travel point of view we saw softness in margin to continue into April. We do see signs kind mid-May and into June that positive signs that would p
componenttext: Hey, Julie. As we talk about -- as you look at the demand environment in the second quarter, from a business travel point of view we saw softness in margin to continue into April. We do see signs kind mid-May and into June that positive signs that would point to strengthening the deals that we did, closer to the time, a little bit really on the business traffic window, but where our yield right now, we feel pretty good that we see some demand picking up as we move towards the summer, beginning in mid-May. I would emphasize corporate is still a little bit soft. But we saw our corporate portfolio in the first quarter down 3%. This will count energy, it's down about 2%. So the energy sector is impacting us. We expect that to continue to the second quarter given where oil prices are. So the corporate sector -- the energy sector as well as the overall Houston hub will continue to put pressure on us. So we see good demand. We see strong demand, but quite frankly, it's at lower yields. And then I'll point to the slide I showed in the presentation, and we do have some supply and demand dynamics affecting and diluting yield as we think about the near term. But close what we see demand picking up kind of mid-May, June with some signs of stronger yields.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And is there an additional color you can offer on the trans-Atlantic, and the dynamic causing the weakness there? The sequential deterioration in PRASM in Q1 was a little bit than I would have expected given the action you're taking on seasonal shap
componenttext: Okay. And is there an additional color you can offer on the trans-Atlantic, and the dynamic causing the weakness there? The sequential deterioration in PRASM in Q1 was a little bit than I would have expected given the action you're taking on seasonal shaping. Is there lingering impact of Paris and Brussels that's going to impact Q2 as well? What are some of the dynamics there?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the recent events and the tragedy in Brussels has impacted bookings. What we generally see is a slowdown in bookings after events like that. Those begin to pick back up, but quite frankly, it looms days, into weeks of the booking curve, and t
componenttext: Yes, I think the recent events and the tragedy in Brussels has impacted bookings. What we generally see is a slowdown in bookings after events like that. Those begin to pick back up, but quite frankly, it looms days, into weeks of the booking curve, and that's impacting the second quarter, which is why the trans-Atlantic as you move towards the summer period, that booking curve still has plenty of time to fill up, and we see that demand. So I tie it more to the recent events that -- particularly in Brussels that's affecting the overall travel in trans-Atlantic.

componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Oscar. And then my second question is to Gerry. With respect to the fleet, when we look at the fleet and how it's evolved, it looks like -- versus the last update, there is a larger reduction in this number of CRJs 700s. And as I think abou
componenttext: Great. Thanks, Oscar. And then my second question is to Gerry. With respect to the fleet, when we look at the fleet and how it's evolved, it looks like -- versus the last update, there is a larger reduction in this number of CRJs 700s. And as I think about it, I would have maybe anticipated a bigger decline in 50 seaters rather than 70 seaters. I'm just curious, is that reduction is a function of the fact that you're bringing in a lot of 175s, the Embraer aircraft, that may be you're up against scope and so as 175 coming, you got to take out of 700. So if you could just provide an explanation for that, that would be great.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a combination of think of two things. One as you said, the scope implementation that we dictate some of the swapping out of the CRJs for the 175. And also, timing on when the 50-seat aircraft leases expires. We try not to exit aircraft that we're sti
componenttext: It's a combination of think of two things. One as you said, the scope implementation that we dictate some of the swapping out of the CRJs for the 175. And also, timing on when the 50-seat aircraft leases expires. We try not to exit aircraft that we're still paying for. So between the 2, that will drive what we're seeing.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, I wonder, you gave a lot of stats there pretty quickly. I wonder if you could just repeat by regional entity where you think we'll be in the fourth quarter and what gets us there?
componenttext: Jim, I wonder, you gave a lot of stats there pretty quickly. I wonder if you could just repeat by regional entity where you think we'll be in the fourth quarter and what gets us there?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Jim. As I said, on domestic, we expect given our initiatives improved reliability, we're seeing that translate into some of the highest customer -- the highest customer satisfaction scores that we've seen. And as we build on that momentum, co
componenttext: Yes, this is Jim. As I said, on domestic, we expect given our initiatives improved reliability, we're seeing that translate into some of the highest customer -- the highest customer satisfaction scores that we've seen. And as we build on that momentum, coupled with the initiatives I talked about entry level fare that comes from the second half of the ability to up-sell into first class as we put more 2-cabin aircraft into the domestic system and other marketing initiatives that will leverage that reliability that we're seeing in our system, we think those initiatives put us on a path to flat to positive RASM into the consolidate domestic systems in the fourth quarter. And we also believe we have a path to progression to hit the flat Latin American PRASM by the fourth quarter as well as in the the trans-Atlantic. The one area that will probably lag it because of things that are --- particularly, the strong dollars, the RMB, the Chinese currency, it's relative -- the dollar relative strength to that currency has a longer tail to it, for lack of better words, than what we saw with the yen and the euro. So we think Pacific will take a little bit longer to get to flat RASM by the fourth quarter. But we're really excited about it. We have a good path to it. We understand the importance of PRASM and what it means to drive top line revenue and the team is very much focused on it.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So flat to positive in domestic, Atlantic and Latin, which you can feel like given the relative size of those, it feels like a consolidated flat to positive despite Pacific. Is that a reasonable way to think about it?
componenttext: So flat to positive in domestic, Atlantic and Latin, which you can feel like given the relative size of those, it feels like a consolidated flat to positive despite Pacific. Is that a reasonable way to think about it?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I put it kind of consolidated closer to flat. Again, the domestic, we think we have a path to flat to positive. The other international entities given the capacity of growth will move closer to flat so you weigh those together, I would want to call
componenttext: Well, I put it kind of consolidated closer to flat. Again, the domestic, we think we have a path to flat to positive. The other international entities given the capacity of growth will move closer to flat so you weigh those together, I would want to call it consolidated positive at this point.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then just for my second question, as we think about losing a bunch of these 50 seaters, can you give us some basic building blocks? So maybe a ratio for every 3 50 seaters that goes away. You take away one of these mainline deliveries associated with that order. And then just the inputs to profit improvement to help us sort of build up to what this fleet transition could mean for you over the next couple of years.

componenttext: Well, look, I'll jump in -- this is Gerry. As you think about from a network perspective, you can think of kind -- you're right, the 3-ish 50 seaters, 2 to 3, kind of in line with each of those 737s that come in to replace those. And so, we think concepts of in markets where they're seat neutral and where we can work with frequency and use that mainline aircraft, that's all in the pattern that previously had much more frequency of 50 seaters. We can kind of think of that 2 to 3 range in terms of that replacement.

componenttext: And can you give us any sense for profit improvement for each of these that goes away?

componenttext: We have, but I really want to stress the ability to drive ancillary revenue first hand given the economy plus section that comes with that. It's a great first class cabin. It comes with Wi-Fi, it comes with our personal device entertainment system, so it has a lot of the actions that customers are looking for. And it will come with increased reliability, so we think from a customer point of view will drive great benefit. I think it's one of the things Oscar mentioned in our investor call in June, we can highlight kind of some of the specific steps on that.

In terms of what the market dynamics or what the results mean, we just don't have a sense of that right now.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe to follow-on some of the other questions that we've heard, I guess, what might help is this you could give us some reassurance perhaps to the level of commitment to actually getting to a positive unit revenue trajectory. Meaning, I've
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe to follow-on some of the other questions that we've heard, I guess, what might help is this you could give us some reassurance perhaps to the level of commitment to actually getting to a positive unit revenue trajectory. Meaning, I've heard some people ask you if should get smaller and I think that's a fair question. And I've heard some people ask you how confident really are you that you can get to a flat or modestly positive RASM trajectory in some of these markets by the end of the year. So just wondering you have the ability to get the positive unit revenue and just about any demand environment it just depends on smaller you want to get. So would you be willing to provide a commitment to the investment community to achieve a flat unit revenue trajectory by the end of the year?

[indiscernible] profit slide the way we and United lay with our current network. And over some point in time, if that needs to change, we'll adjust accordingly. We make those changes, but we'll make thoughtfully, lots and lots of research, internal analysis, and those are not sort of shooting from hit kind of conversations that I want to have on the call. So allow me a little more patience now that we're getting back to work. We'll talk a little bit about this in June.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay, that's a great. And then when it comes to thinking about fuel hedging, could you guys give us an update on your thought process around perhaps increasing your foreign hedging given the volatility to the upside we'll be seeing in fuel over the
componenttext: Okay, okay, that's a great. And then when it comes to thinking about fuel hedging, could you guys give us an update on your thought process around perhaps increasing your foreign hedging given the volatility to the upside we'll be seeing in fuel over the last several months?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Hedging is just one tool that can help provide better certainties as we try to achieve our business plan. It's no longer for us a hedging in the near-term volatility, that's a very expensive insurance policy that we can just stop, ensure that risk.
componenttext: Sure. Hedging is just one tool that can help provide better certainties as we try to achieve our business plan. It's no longer for us a hedging in the near-term volatility, that's a very expensive insurance policy that we can just stop, ensure that risk. So it's just one tool. There are a number of factors that we'll look at, including our net exposure to fuel. One of the benefits of the Houston hub work from the other way that as fuel prices rise, there's a correlation on revenue particularly in Houston. So it would be the next exposure that we would focus on. The competitive landscape, what others are doing that could impact the industry and the overall economic environment. So we'll be thoughtful about our hedging. As I mentioned in my prepared remarks, we have not done any hedging since last summer and while there has been some volatility in fuel recently, from a historical perspective, it's still a very low fuel environment.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: From Raymond James, we have Savanthi Syth online.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the CapEx program, could you discuss a little bit about your thoughts on financing. Just -- I know you mentioned about maybe 50% of aircraft sort of debt financed this year. But as you look forward, thoughts on operating leases or debt financing a
componenttext: Just on the CapEx program, could you discuss a little bit about your thoughts on financing. Just -- I know you mentioned about maybe 50% of aircraft sort of debt financed this year. But as you look forward, thoughts on operating leases or debt financing and how should we think about liquidity and debt target?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. On leasing first. I would absolutely love to lease some of these aircraft, but it's got to make economic sense. There are a number of factors but let me give you 3. One is just the cost of money, cost of debt. As you know, we can finance -- debt fin
componenttext: Sure. On leasing first. I would absolutely love to lease some of these aircraft, but it's got to make economic sense. There are a number of factors but let me give you 3. One is just the cost of money, cost of debt. As you know, we can finance -- debt finance aircraft at the very low cost, factor rate the high [indiscernible] to leasing companies to overcome and historically there have been do that, they are better able to today surpass through their lower cost to fund to us, that's one factor. Probably the bigger one is residual value. Unique to make leasing work, the situation where the leasing company is going to be more optimistic on residual value than we are. And then sort of tenant think of it like buying on a deal. You're going to trade in your auto deal every 2 or 3 years. Leasing has to make sense. If you're going to keep that auto through its useful life, leasing becomes very expensive. So when we booked at these aircraft, these are largely core aircraft that we expect to keep very long term, 25, 30 years and leasing can get expensive. But that's not to say leasing can't work and likely done historically, we will continue to look at leasing opportunities and see if we can make anything work in that space. But that's one of the reasons why when we talk about free cash flow and capital allocation, I already adjusted free cash flow. So for me, I'm going to adjust for the financing. So rather lease, rather we use WTC or other debt financing, that's going to drive the availability of liquidity that we can use in our capital allocation program where top priority is still going to be returning cash to shareholders and as we continue to have strong earnings, we would continue with that program.

That's part of our success in moving towards flat to positive in the fourth quarter.

So while we have some cost savings we're seeing people increase over time.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: And this is Oscar. I'll add one thing as this makes my operational background, nit applies across any industry. As you invest to become more reliable, that investment is clearly a cost line. As you get more reliable, how you reduce that cost or that safety cushion, how quickly you do it, how effectively you do it is a key attribute of will be challenged with very quickly. And again, I think I'm going to do that. We said Denver and Houston over the last couple of weeks have been massively hit. We have 700 people not able to come to work on a day. And so it's all those things and all those different moving parts that you have to address. But that safety cushion that's across the system, we'll have to be managed better and therefore, costs out down. But it starts with having our reliable product. So thank you.
