componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to United Continental Holdings Earnings Conference Call for the First Quarter 2016. My name is Brandon, and I'll be your conference facilitator today. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded and is copyrighted. Please note that no portion of the call may be recorded, transcribed or rebroadcast without the company's permission. Your participation implies your consent to our recording of this call. If you do not agree with these terms, simply drop off the line. 
I will now turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Jonathan Ireland, Managing Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brandon. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to United's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Yesterday, we issued our earnings release and separate investor update. Additionally, this morning, we issued a presentation to accompany th
componenttext:
Thank you, Brandon. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to United's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. 
Yesterday, we issued our earnings release and separate investor update. Additionally, this morning, we issued a presentation to accompany this call. All three of these documents are available on our website at ir.united.com. 
Information on yesterday's release and investor update and remarks made during this conference call may contain forward-looking statements which represent the company's current expectations or beliefs concerning future events and financial performance. All forward-looking statements are based upon information currently available to the company. A number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from our current expectations. Please refer to our press release, Form 10-Q and other reports filed with the SEC by United Continental Holdings and United Airlines for a more thorough description of these factors. 
Also during the course of our call, we will discuss several non-GAAP financial measures. For a reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures to GAAP measures, please refer to the tables at the end of our earnings release and investor update, copies of which are available on our website. 
Unless otherwise noted, special charges are excluded as we walk you through our numbers for the quarter. These items are detailed in our earnings release. 
Joining us here in Chicago to discuss our results are President and CEO, Oscar Munoz; Vice Chairman and Chief Revenue Officer, Jim Compton; and Senior Vice President, Finance and Acting Chief Financial Officer, Gerry Laderman. We also have Chief Operating Officer and Executive Vice President, Greg Hart, in the room to assist with Q&A. 
And now, I'd like to turn the call over to Oscar.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jonathan, and thank you all for joining us this morning. For the first quarter, we recorded a pretax profit of $688 million, excluding special items, our eighth consecutive quarter of profitability and our highest first quarter of pretax profit
componenttext:
Thank you, Jonathan, and thank you all for joining us this morning. For the first quarter, we recorded a pretax profit of $688 million, excluding special items, our eighth consecutive quarter of profitability and our highest first quarter of pretax profit ever. 
We achieved diluted earnings per share of $1.23, excluding special items, a 28% increase versus last year when adjusting for taxes. And as you all know, we repurchased $1.5 billion of common stock. 
As I think back on the quarter, I'm particularly proud of our operational performance, which, again, showed significant improvement. Our first quarter consolidated on-time performance was more than 12 points better year-over-year, and we had 3,600 fewer cancelations, a 20% reduction versus the first quarter of last year. This improvement demonstrates the dedication, passion and hard work of United's aviation professionals. I know as I travel the system, I see the renewed engagement, excitement and energy that our nearly 86,000 employees around the world are bringing to work every day. I'd like to thank them for their efforts and dedication, particularly as they work through this winter season. This quarter's results show great strides forward and with our sense of shared purpose and the investments we continue to make and people, processes and systems, we are positioned for even greater success in the months ahead. 
On the commercial side of the business, we launched our global performance guarantee, which makes our corporate contracts to operational performance, showing both our confidence and commitment to running a consistently reliable operation. 
With respect to our network as part of our industry-leading Pacific strategy, we announced an enhanced partnership with Air China and a joint venture with Air New Zealand, both of which are expected to expand our global reach. 
We also announced several routes that further strengthen our global footprint, including the first-ever nonstop service by a U.S. carrier to Hangzhou, our sixth Chinese destination. 
We also became the first U.S. airline to serve Israel nonstop from the West Coast, connecting 2 of the world's most influential technology communities.
Now having said this, we know we are facing some revenue challenges. We're making good progress on a number of initiatives to improve revenue, but some of them, like a more reliable operation and improved customer satisfaction, as you know, have a lagging effect. I expect these improvements, along with other commercial initiatives, will drive improved revenue performance as we move into the back half of this year. 
Now turning to our people. As I've said many times, reaching new agreements with our representative employees is one of my highest priorities. We've already made great progress as our pilots, dispatchers and the IAM representative work groups all ratify contract extensions this year. This represents half of our unionized workforce. We remain focused on getting contracts like these for our flight attendants and technicians, and we plan to keep working closely with the unions to make that happen. 
Lastly, as you've heard, yesterday we announced additional changes to our board. I want to welcome the 2 new board members, and I look forward to working alongside them and our other recently elected members over the upcoming years. 
Now I'd like to turn it over to -- the call over to Jim and Gerry. Jim?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Oscar. As you can see on Slide 6, through the first quarter, our consolidated unit revenue declined to 7.4%. The 4 primary drivers we identified at the beginning of the quarter impacted our PRASM performance in line with initial expectations. In
componenttext:
Thanks, Oscar. As you can see on Slide 6, through the first quarter, our consolidated unit revenue declined to 7.4%. The 4 primary drivers we identified at the beginning of the quarter impacted our PRASM performance in line with initial expectations. 
In addition, while we had anticipated that the timing of Easter would have some impact on close-in business travel, it proved to be greater than we had expected. While we have seen total bookings return to pre-Easter levels, we are closely monitoring the mix of business and leisure bookings. 
Turning to the second quarter. We expect our passenger unit revenue to decline approximately 6.5% to 8.5% year-over-year, with domestic PRASM expected to be down approximately 3.5% to 5.5% and international PRASM expected to be down approximately 11% to 13%. 
While the primary drivers of this decline are consistent with the first quarter, we are beginning to lap some of the effects from last year, somewhat muting the impact on a year-over-year basis. 
For the consolidated system, we expect the strong dollar, lower surcharges, the Houston and energy market weakness and competitive pressures to drive approximately 3.25 points of softness. While these drivers explain a portion of the unit revenue decline, they don't capture all of it. 
As can be seen on Slide 7, the remaining headwinds unit revenue is largely driven by passenger demand using GDP as a proxy, not keeping pace with capacity. Like any supply versus demand relationship, this is creating downward pressure on pricing. This is particularly evident in the international markets where United is more exposed than any other U.S. carrier. 
While United has consistently grown at/or below the rate of GDP, this dynamic is creating a unit revenue headwinds to United of approximately 2.5 points. 
Turning to Slide 8. We are taking specific actions in each market to improve our unit revenue performance in this environment with the focus on maximizing near-term profitability while also positioning ourselves for longer-term success. 
In the domestic market, this includes redirecting capacity to capitalize on changing demand patterns, introducing entry-level fares to increase segmentation and reduce dilution, launching marketing and sales initiatives that leverage our improving liability and further rolling out 2-cabin service in top business markets. We expect that these actions, along with improving reliability and customer satisfaction, will drive domestic unit revenue to be flat-to-positive in the fourth quarter. 
With respect to the international markets, we expect lapping PRASM to turn positive by the fourth quarter, benefiting from reduced Brazil flying. 
While we are currently experiencing softness in the Atlantic due to recent events, we see strong summer bookings and expect to get close to flat PRASM by the fourth quarter. 
Unit revenue recovery in the Pacific will take more time and surcharges and a strong U.S. dollar continue to impact our performance. 
In spite of this, we are very optimistic that the Pacific entity, one of our true competitive differentiators, will see sequential quarter-over-quarter improvement this year despite continued pressure from industry growth, which is not uncommon in developing high-opportunity markets like China. 
We are also prepared to reduce overall capacity where appropriate. We have made some targeted reductions to our schedule, pulling down flying in Houston, Brazil and the Middle East. And as you can see, on Slide 9, we now expect our 2016 capacity to grow 1% to 2%, a 0.5-point reduction from our previous full year capacity guidance. 
In conclusion, during the first quarter, we continue to generate high levels of profitability despite the unit revenue pressures we experienced across our system. We are taking very deliberate actions within our network and will continue to adjust our flying with a goal to maximize long-term profitability and return to positive unit revenues. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Gerry.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. Good morning, everyone. A summary of our financial performance for the quarter can be seen on Slide 11. Our net income declined by approximately $200 million year-over-year as this quarter was the first quarter in a number of years in which
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. Good morning, everyone. A summary of our financial performance for the quarter can be seen on Slide 11. 
Our net income declined by approximately $200 million year-over-year as this quarter was the first quarter in a number of years in which we booked significant federal taxes. 
Pretax earnings improved by approximately $100 million due to lower oil prices, partially offset by lower revenue and higher nonfuel expense. Our pretax margin was 8.4%, a meaningful improvement compared to last year. More significantly, when adjusted for taxes, our earnings per share of $1.23 increased 28% versus last year. 
Details on our fuel expense, which decreased by almost $700 million year-over-year, are shown on Slide 12. This decrease was driven by lower fuel prices, improved fuel efficiency and reduced hedge losses. 
Looking forward, while we have not added to our hedge book since July of 2015, we are still 12% hedged for the remaining 9 months of 2016, and as of yesterday, are in a loss position of approximately $80 million, including premium expense. 
Moving to Slide 13. Nonfuel unit cost for the quarter grew 1.3% when excluding special charges, profit sharing and third party expenses. We continue to manage air cost to improve the efficiency and cost structure of the airline. For the second quarter, we expect nonfuel unit cost to grow 2.5% to 3.5%. And for the full year, we now expect unit cost to grow 2% to 3%. This guidance includes the benefit of annual efficiency savings initiatives totaling over $1.1 billion. These savings initiatives were achieved a full year in advance of our initial expectations and are providing over $100 million more in sustainable savings than our original goal. 
Our guidance also includes the impact of the 3 recently ratified labor agreements. We expect the newly ratified IAM agreement have a marginal impact on 2016 expenses. For 2017, we expect the impact of the 3 contracts to be approximately 0.75-point CASM. 
Based on the guidance we had provided for cost and revenue, we expect our pretax margin to be between 13% and 15% for the second quarter. 
With respect to cash, in the first quarter, we generated approximately $1.2 billion of operating cash flow and $376 million of free cash flow. 
As you can see on Slide 14, during the quarter, we invested approximately $820 million in the business. We took delivery of 3 787s, 2 737s and 1 used A319, and we added 6 Embraer E175s to our original fleet. 
We also announced additional aircraft orders for 65 Boeing 737-700 aircraft. These aircraft will allow us to reduce the size of our 50-seat regional fleet to address the regional pilot shortage while providing customers with larger, 2-cabin aircraft with greater amenities. Importantly, as we transition out of 50-seat aircraft and into larger-gauge Dreamliner aircraft, we expect to begin generating structural cost benefits of upgauging and reducing departures. 
During the quarter, we also announced plans to accelerate deliveries of certain wide-body aircrafts to facilitate the early retirement of our 747s as the 747's cost and complexity to operate continues to be a burden. This decision does not represent an increase to overall CapEx capacity or total fleet size. 
Our sustained cash generation over the last few quarters and the discounted value of our stock led us to repurchase $1.5 billion worth of stock in the first quarter, representing 8% per shares outstanding. 
Based on the progress we've made to date and cash flow expectations for the rest of the year, we now anticipate completing our $3 billion share repurchase authorization by the end of the third quarter this year. 
In conclusion, we showed, once again, in the first quarter, solid cost discipline on investing our business and returning significant cash to shareholders. Going forward, we will continue to execute on our plan to improve our financial performance and secure a strong future for our employees, customers and shareholders. 
I'll now turn it back over to Oscar.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, sir. So while I'm pleased with all the accomplishments within the quarter, I've got to say, it's the future that has seeing us excited. Thus, after spending time with many of you, our shareowners, over the last few months, I know there's a stro
componenttext:
Thank you, sir. So while I'm pleased with all the accomplishments within the quarter, I've got to say, it's the future that has seeing us excited. Thus, after spending time with many of you, our shareowners, over the last few months, I know there's a strong desire to learn more about certain initiatives we have underway and of course, their impact to the bottom line. To that end, we'll be holding an investor call on June 21 to describe in more detail many of these initiatives and their contributions to earnings over the next several years. I look forward to that conversation. 
But before opening up for questions, I'd like to thank our customers for choosing United. You have a choice. We appreciate your business. 
So with that, I'll turn it over back to Jonathan.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So there's no mistake in that our various airlines domestically are built differently, and we clearly have our own strength and challenges, our higher-cost hubs are constructionally were less -- were a bit -- a little less reliable, but I think of it from
componenttext:
So there's no mistake in that our various airlines domestically are built differently, and we clearly have our own strength and challenges, our higher-cost hubs are constructionally were less -- were a bit -- a little less reliable, but I think of it from the standpoint that we have, I believe, better business markets and certainly better international gateways. Those are a little bit more competitive than others, but as you -- as we think about building a playbook, our own playbook, not copying others, is I think the strategic work that we have to continue to do. And so as I think of your question, I think we have to sort of double down on 3 areas of strategic focus. Certainly, we need to win on revenue, and it's just not markets and scheduling price but its products and service. Execution, which we're doing a good job already. Reliability, certainly. Productivity, we just heard Gerry talk about that in a significant way. Cost, of course, is included in that. And then technology, which we haven't talked about, and we look forward to sharing some of that in June. 
And then -- and this -- people, they always kind of wink at me when we say this, but winning on trust with our employees and then speaking to them and then through to our customers, and of course, invariably to you as shareowners. So we're still in the early innings, the momentum is building and the system across all these areas, but it's a combination of all of those, David.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then when I look at the international RASM outlook, I mean, should we think of those things as just short-term oversupply issues or kind of more of the macro? Or do you think you're, going back to sort of the revenue side, including that gap? I
componenttext: Okay. And then when I look at the international RASM outlook, I mean, should we think of those things as just short-term oversupply issues or kind of more of the macro? Or do you think you're, going back to sort of the revenue side, including that gap? I mean, is this something that you think is more structural in nature that's further devolving?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jim. The way I think on the international side is clearly, depending on the regions of the world, I'll depict China, for instance, where passenger demand is growing at a fast pace even in that high-capacity demand. So we believe that over the long
componenttext:
This is Jim. The way I think on the international side is clearly, depending on the regions of the world, I'll depict China, for instance, where passenger demand is growing at a fast pace even in that high-capacity demand. So we believe that over the long term, that, that capacity demand will come in line.
What we are excited about is that our uniqueness as to how we're participating in China. It's unique in the sense that it's, as Oscar mentioned, 2 new secondary cities in China. That growth that I mentioned out of China, after that will come from secondary cities. But the fleet that we have and the flexibility of the 787, it's really allowing us to play in that market at an early, early stage in a very profitable entity that runs at a high profitability. Quite frankly, at a profitability that's no different than our domestic. So we believe that as demand catches up to the capacity level out there, we'll be able to close that year-over-year RASM. And I mentioned in my comments, we actually see closing much of that during the year as we move to the fourth quarter.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Stifel, we have Joseph DeNardi online.
componenttext: From Stifel, we have Joseph DeNardi online.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, just 2 questions for you. One, just on your -- to what you guys want to call it, but the kind of basic economy fare that you guys plan to roll out, can you -- is there any updated timing on when that's going to be launched. And is the benefit from th
componenttext: Jim, just 2 questions for you. One, just on your -- to what you guys want to call it, but the kind of basic economy fare that you guys plan to roll out, can you -- is there any updated timing on when that's going to be launched. And is the benefit from that factored into your expectation for flat domestic PRASM by 4Q?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- we're targeting second half of the year. So no change to our time line that we've talked about and very excited about. And yes, it's a piece of the -- it's one of the initiatives that, as I've described in my comments, of how we're very much focuse
componenttext: The -- we're targeting second half of the year. So no change to our time line that we've talked about and very excited about. And yes, it's a piece of the -- it's one of the initiatives that, as I've described in my comments, of how we're very much focused on moving PRASM to flat and upward, and that is a big piece of it. The concept of it is to allow us to compete more effectively with low-cost carriers. And the second piece of it, it will allow us to move some of the dilution that happens in the marketplace given the fare structure that we have today. So yes, absolutely. That's part of our path to -- that flat deposit RASM in the fourth quarter.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one for Oscar, actually. I think that the CapEx increase that you guys announced surprised some people. Oscar, I'm just wondering if you could talk about, given how short of a time period you have been there, you don't have a permanent
componenttext: Okay. And then just one for Oscar, actually. I think that the CapEx increase that you guys announced surprised some people. Oscar, I'm just wondering if you could talk about, given how short of a time period you have been there, you don't have a permanent CFO in place at this point, what made you feel comfortable to announce such a big increase to your CapEx profile over the next couple of years?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a combination of things. Certainly, the sort of aging of the 47 fleet that needed to be replaced, plain and simple. And on the 37s, it's actually economically viable and accretive rather than not, and having to jump on those slots with regards
componenttext: Well, it's a combination of things. Certainly, the sort of aging of the 47 fleet that needed to be replaced, plain and simple. And on the 37s, it's actually economically viable and accretive rather than not, and having to jump on those slots with regards to what was available to us. So a combination of those things. I can tell you that, not only myself, but the team was very deeply involved in that conversation, and we didn't do that lightly knowing that the reaction might be with regards to increased CapEx. Jim, would you add anything?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the only thing I would add is, on the 737s, keep in mind, we had a real problem. There is a regional pilot shortage that compelled us to deal with the significant reduction in 50-seats flying, and when we did our analysis to say, okay, what should rep
componenttext: And the only thing I would add is, on the 737s, keep in mind, we had a real problem. There is a regional pilot shortage that compelled us to deal with the significant reduction in 50-seats flying, and when we did our analysis to say, okay, what should replace that, looking in the new and the used market, we took some used aircraft that many have made economic sense. In the new aircraft market, we looked at all of the available options. They're all good aircraft, but the lowest-cost choice for us is the 737-700.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: From JP Morgan, we have Jamie Baker online.
componenttext: From JP Morgan, we have Jamie Baker online.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oscar, there's a little question that you delivered a pretty unimpressive guide for the second quarter. I realized that with everything going on with the board, that may have been a distraction. And you're getting involved with the flight attendant negoti
componenttext: Oscar, there's a little question that you delivered a pretty unimpressive guide for the second quarter. I realized that with everything going on with the board, that may have been a distraction. And you're getting involved with the flight attendant negotiations. Nobody is accusing you of not having a full plate here. But traditionally, when companies start falling further and further behind their competitors, and based on the guide, that is what you expect in the second quarter, they're faced with 3 choices: You can do nothing, you can simply try harder or you can come up with a new plan. So my question is simple. Does mediocrity suffice, is fixing United as simple as rolling up your sleeves and relying on easier comps? Or is something significantly more radical, a change in course, ultimately required?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is that a leading question, Jamie? I'm going to go with mediocrity for $200, please. It's -- I think one of the things that is important to know is that we didn't concede in anything on anyone. And so what we've been doing is decline profitably. I've watc
componenttext: Is that a leading question, Jamie? I'm going to go with mediocrity for $200, please. It's -- I think one of the things that is important to know is that we didn't concede in anything on anyone. And so what we've been doing is decline profitably. I've watched and monitor how that works. We need to be, in my mind, a bit more disruptive in the marketplace. I think we've been outstanding by a little bit too much, know exactly what that means and how we do it thoughtfully and from a shareholder sort of value-creating perspective, is the work we're beginning to do. Interestingly enough, I have a couple of new board members that have a lot of knowledge and ability in that space. I will lean hard on them with that regard. But no, it definitely has to change. Accepting the same thing comes to me over and over, especially in this market -- there have been decreasing demand brought overall, global economic picture, our increasing expenses on the labor side and all those things. We have to do things differently to many, many factors. And so you will see some of that thrust here for the next few months as far as the initiatives. Some of the value of those initiatives will be there, but still, again, there's a lagging effect. But no, there's no one standing by here just waiting for these things to clear up and hopefully, it will get better. We've got to take some action.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that helps. And on that lagging effect, presumably, the investments that you're making in labor aren't driven by a sense of charity, rather they're intended to generate a return at some point, presumably in the form of better RASM or corporate share
componenttext: Okay, that helps. And on that lagging effect, presumably, the investments that you're making in labor aren't driven by a sense of charity, rather they're intended to generate a return at some point, presumably in the form of better RASM or corporate share preference by business travelers to make United their first choice, all that kind of stuff. So in your mind, one flavor is embraced, compensated and energized, how long do you think it's likely to take before you start to generate a financial return on those efforts?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I'll just correct one thing. I think my family here has been energized already. So we've got a good, hard step on that. How long it will take? I don't know that I'm capable at this point in time with projecting that. The way I'll see it and mon
componenttext: Yes. Well, I'll just correct one thing. I think my family here has been energized already. So we've got a good, hard step on that. How long it will take? I don't know that I'm capable at this point in time with projecting that. The way I'll see it and monitor it and present it very transparent to you. Every little step we take forward, we're going to highlight for you. And how long it's going to take, it's hard to tell. I -- we didn't get here overnight, and we're likely not to get out overnight. But I want to have initiatives that have a more immediate sort of value that you can see. I really believe in this concept of proof, not promises. Again, my history is laden with that, and that's what we got to work through. So again, as far as timing, Jamie, I say, no, it's too early for me to tell you any specific time frame.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Cowen and Company, we have Helane Becker online.
componenttext: From Cowen and Company, we have Helane Becker online.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know that the first quarter is generally your toughest quarter anyway, and you generally underperformed your peer group. When you look at the performance in the first quarter to the second quarter, given that the unit revenue guide is kind of flattish t
componenttext: I know that the first quarter is generally your toughest quarter anyway, and you generally underperformed your peer group. When you look at the performance in the first quarter to the second quarter, given that the unit revenue guide is kind of flattish to maybe even a little worse, can you just talk about the dynamics that get that revenue decline continued as opposed to sequential improvement?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jim. The -- you're right. Seasonally, our first quarter is our more difficult quarter, and we're working hard in terms of that sequential RASM to improve that. Now I do want to emphasize the international exposure. The domestic RASM from the first
componenttext: This is Jim. The -- you're right. Seasonally, our first quarter is our more difficult quarter, and we're working hard in terms of that sequential RASM to improve that. Now I do want to emphasize the international exposure. The domestic RASM from the first quarter to the second quarter does, with our guidance, show a sequential improvement. So we are focused very much on that international side, in particular, and we've made some capacity adjustments that's part of our guidance down to 1% to 2% capacity guidance. That 1/2 point drop from our previous guidance is all international. So one is to react to the market out there on the international side and to make sure that our capacity moves more in line with demand. As we move through -- particularly, it's still the second quarter, a shoulder period, for instance, in trans-Atlantic, we see strong bookings in the summer time for trans-Atlantic that will help with that sequential RASM as we move through the year. We've made initiatives in Latin America that beginning in the second quarter, our capacity to the rest of the year is basically flat after doing seasonally adjusted capacity to capture demand in each markets, for instance, that drove our capacity up. Very strong margins but they've put pressure on RASM. So our focus is on that international side, the initiative to move capacity into right places as well as to drive the initiatives. And in addition, the great work by the operations team and reliability. Given that work, we're beginning to see already in our hubs, signs of our share beginning to improve, and we think that will continue and spread and drive that RASM improvement as we go through the year.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks for that very comprehensive answer. I just have a question about in the first quarter, the decline in regional capacity purchase expense. As you shift more capacity to the mainline from the regionals, shouldn't that expense line actually decl
componenttext: Okay. Thanks for that very comprehensive answer. I just have a question about in the first quarter, the decline in regional capacity purchase expense. As you shift more capacity to the mainline from the regionals, shouldn't that expense line actually decline further? And how should we think about the mix between mainline and regional revenue given that your mainline revenue declined more than regional for the first quarter, and maybe that should have been more balanced?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me address the cost piece of it. But clearly as we shift from regional to mainline, you'll see a continued drop in regional expense. Some of that, though, is going to be offset by the increased cost of the regional flying as they have -- the regional
componenttext:
Let me address the cost piece of it. But clearly as we shift from regional to mainline, you'll see a continued drop in regional expense. Some of that, though, is going to be offset by the increased cost of the regional flying as they have -- the regional airlines have their own pressures that they have to deal with, and that becomes more expensive flying. But generally, with the decline of the 50-seat flying, you'll see a drop in regional expense. 
I would just add to that. As we shift to the mainline, remember, it creates revenue opportunity. Those 50-seaters don't have Economy Plus. They don't have a first-class cabin, and we continue to see great upsell in the first-class cabin as well as strong economies there, plus sales.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Buckingham Research, we have Dan McKenzie.
componenttext: From Buckingham Research, we have Dan McKenzie.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, thanks for all the commentary. Appreciate the presentation as well, everybody. But Jim, in your commentary, you talked about being open to adjusting overall capacity. And I'm wondering if you can elaborate a little bit further, specifically, I'm just
componenttext: Jim, thanks for all the commentary. Appreciate the presentation as well, everybody. But Jim, in your commentary, you talked about being open to adjusting overall capacity. And I'm wondering if you can elaborate a little bit further, specifically, I'm just wondering what international entity is driving the biggest sequential revenue deterioration exactly? And I'm wondering what demand trends need to transpire before you buy -- you get more aggressive? And however you might talk about that, whether it be bookings or revenues that might be falling short and how quickly you might be able to respond.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question. I think Pacific is, quite frankly, the biggest sequential driver on unit revenue impact to us. And as I mentioned, we'll -- as I mentioned, some of the capacity reduction, actually all of that 0.5-point reduction in guidance is on
componenttext:
Thanks for the question. I think Pacific is, quite frankly, the biggest sequential driver on unit revenue impact to us. And as I mentioned, we'll -- as I mentioned, some of the capacity reduction, actually all of that 0.5-point reduction in guidance is on the international. So we'll stay really focused on the demand environment relative to capacity we have. I will say about the Pacific is also impacted, but we'll start to lap some of the foreign exchange, and the surcharge impact is most dramatic in the Pacific, so we'll lap some of that. 
So we believe, even in that entity, that we'll continue to close -- move toward a flat RASM in the Pacific as we move through the year. The Pacific, as I mentioned, even the markets we're adding, San -- Oscar mentioned, through the secondary cities. But you think about San Fran to Singapore, very unique and innovative for us. It's the first nonstop market to the U.S. just from Singapore. San Fran-Auckland, building on our relationship and growing our relationship with Air New Zealand. San Fran-Tel Aviv that we launched on March 30, off to a great start, and that make 2 high-tech communities and seeing great bookings there. So all of those would say that uniqueness of our expansion, we think serves us well and comes at a high level of profitability. All that being said, we've been consistent. We'll keep traffic capacity and demand and make sure that we're keeping them in line, but also remembering that we're -- the international is off to a longer-term play that we're really excited about.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very good. I appreciate that, Jim. I guess, just staying on the Pacific for a second here. United did sign a multi-year agreement to strengthen its partnership with Air China per the release. I'm just wondering what is that exactly and how and when might
componenttext: Very good. I appreciate that, Jim. I guess, just staying on the Pacific for a second here. United did sign a multi-year agreement to strengthen its partnership with Air China per the release. I'm just wondering what is that exactly and how and when might that tie to, say, increased revenue contribution on that entity?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dan, we recently signed an enhanced agreement with them that, quite frankly, builds that relationship over a longer number of years. I want to be clear, it's based in the concept of the alliance world. It's not a JV world. China is not open skies, an
componenttext:
Yes, Dan, we recently signed an enhanced agreement with them that, quite frankly, builds that relationship over a longer number of years. I want to be clear, it's based in the concept of the alliance world. It's not a JV world. China is not open skies, and so it doesn't come with antitrust immunity. But we think we have a lot of ability to grow together, both relationship-wise as we learn about the market from each other, both Air China learning about the U.S. market and us, quite frankly, learning a lot about the Chinese market. That will bring us closer together in marketing. It'll bring us closer together in some sales initiatives that allows us to understand the marketplace, and we think that will enhance our connections through the market as we build, not only Beijing, but as we build in some of the secondary cities. 
So we can increase the connecting opportunities that we have with Air China. We connect close to 200 a day over the Air China network in Beijing today, and we think there's upside building that relationship. It's -- within the alliance world, we're bringing much more higher-level executive attention to it. The team of senior executives will much more frequently meet with senior executives of Air China to work on those initiatives that I talked about.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Wolfe Research, we have Hunter Keay online.
componenttext: From Wolfe Research, we have Hunter Keay online.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So when we talk about the structural margin gap, I think everybody just talks about market share and hubs. And I think that's important, but I think that gets focused on a little bit too much. So how much of the gap is attributable to the fact that you ha
componenttext: So when we talk about the structural margin gap, I think everybody just talks about market share and hubs. And I think that's important, but I think that gets focused on a little bit too much. So how much of the gap is attributable to the fact that you have a 1,500 miles stage length versus about 1,000 mile stage length for your 2 biggest peers. And that seems to me like it's a structural of anything. And given that or a change in that, wouldn't it just be unreasonable to assume that you have any possibility of closing the margin gap, particularly now that your costs are going to be higher. And shouldn't we just expect this margin gap to be permanently structural, if for no other reason than the stage length alone?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Oscar. I'm going to let Jim answer the stage length question specifically as we have discussed it. I'm not sure we'll give you some additional facts there to warrant maybe a different opinion. But with regards to, again, the concept of -- from a long
componenttext: It's Oscar. I'm going to let Jim answer the stage length question specifically as we have discussed it. I'm not sure we'll give you some additional facts there to warrant maybe a different opinion. But with regards to, again, the concept of -- from a long-term perspective, in effect conceding that, that margin gap will be there forever, as I've stayed in market and the industry over the last decade on the board, I know that things can change very quickly in one way or another. So not quite ready to concede to anything in that regard, and we'll continue to work the initiatives to close and to narrow that margin gap in the near term. But with regard to the stage length, Jim, why don't you cover some of that with them?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Oscar. Hey, Hunter, yes, there are structural differences between networks, and I think of them as mainly driven by geography. We clearly have 2 east-west coast hubs that, by definition, is going to indicate longer stage length. It's also those co
componenttext: Thanks, Oscar. Hey, Hunter, yes, there are structural differences between networks, and I think of them as mainly driven by geography. We clearly have 2 east-west coast hubs that, by definition, is going to indicate longer stage length. It's also those coastal hubs are tremendous international gateways, which is why our network is really built for strong international presence and growth over time in that international flying. Our hubs are also very business-centric markets, and -- which also means there's lots of competition. And I think you were referring to seat share and so forth. That's a result of those competition's large business-centric markets. We don't have a dominant hub. They're very competitive. And again, the geography of the coastal hubs, large business-centric markets, drives more competition and by definition, drives more stage length. So we haven't evidence that correlates stage length directly to profitability. Stage length is somewhat a result of the geography and the strength of our hubs, and we think that, that hub structure works for us really well. For instance, in New York, it is the only true connecting hub in New York. It allows us to make revenue management decisions on high-yield flow traffic versus low-yield connect traffic that's unique to us. All of those things will drive actual stage length now.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I would add to that really quickly, Hunter. As we begin discussion on this in earnest, certainly that's one area, but there are a lot of other factors that, in effect, affect our network. And to optimize that network, that's the discussions we're
componenttext: I think I would add to that really quickly, Hunter. As we begin discussion on this in earnest, certainly that's one area, but there are a lot of other factors that, in effect, affect our network. And to optimize that network, that's the discussions we're having in earnest with regards to moving forward. So many factors there. Thank you.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And look, I appreciate the commentary and the force [ph] you [ph] PRASM trajectory. The market doesn't appear to believe you. Your stock has is actually sold off more since guys provided that. So I think it has been sort of one step forward and
componenttext: All right. And look, I appreciate the commentary and the force [ph] you [ph] PRASM trajectory. The market doesn't appear to believe you. Your stock has is actually sold off more since guys provided that. So I think it has been sort of one step forward and one step back with United for the last 4 years. And as you talk about this margin gap closure, it becomes, sort of, like all people are going to focused on. So -- and it's actually the fact that it's widening as your operational metrics are improving, it's arguably even more concerning. So the existent -- the argument against the existence of a structural disadvantage seems more feeble as time goes on. So is there a conclusion that you might draw here? If that doesn't happen and you don't close the margin gap or the PRASM gap that maybe there's a conclusion that United is just too big? Is there a scenario where a couple of years down the road, if you're not getting to where you need to be, that we're talking about major surgery here to the network involving asset divestitures or real estate divestitures or something like that? Is there a scenario where we see a structural overhaul of the network involving shrinking the size of this company?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Hunter, I think it's way too early for anyone, and particularly me, to answer that question, and so stand by. I understand your viewpoint. I understand the market's reaction. I understand the situation we're in, and that's what I'm here to do. And th
componenttext: Yes, Hunter, I think it's way too early for anyone, and particularly me, to answer that question, and so stand by. I understand your viewpoint. I understand the market's reaction. I understand the situation we're in, and that's what I'm here to do. And that's what we'll get at very quickly.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Crdit Suisse, we have Julie Yates online.
componenttext: From Crdit Suisse, we have Julie Yates online.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, in your prepared remarks, you noted strong summer bookings, particularly in the trans-Atlantic, and one of your peers last week highlighted strength in advance summer yields domestically. Are you seeing similar dynamics on the domestic market?
componenttext: Jim, in your prepared remarks, you noted strong summer bookings, particularly in the trans-Atlantic, and one of your peers last week highlighted strength in advance summer yields domestically. Are you seeing similar dynamics on the domestic market?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we look about -- as we look at the demand environment in the second quarter, from a business travel point of view, we saw softness in margin that continued into April. We do see signs kind of mid-May and into June, that positive signs that would point
componenttext:
As we look about -- as we look at the demand environment in the second quarter, from a business travel point of view, we saw softness in margin that continued into April. We do see signs kind of mid-May and into June, that positive signs that would point to strengthening in yield as we get closer to that time. It's a little bit early on the business traffic or window, but where our yields are right now, we feel pretty good that we see some demand picking up as we move towards the summer, beginning in mid-May. I would emphasize corporate is still a little bit soft. We saw our corporate portfolio in the first quarter, down 3%. We took out energy, it's down about 2%. So the energy sector is impacting us. We expect that to continue to the second quarter given where oil prices are. So the corporate sector -- the energy sector as well as the overall Houston hub will continue to put pressure on us. 
So we see good demand. We see strong demand, but quite frankly, it's at lower yields. And then I'll point to the slide I showed in the presentation, we do have some supply and demand dynamics affecting and diluting yield as we think about the near term. But I'll close it with, we see demand picking up kind of mid-May, June with some signs of stronger yields.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And is there an additional color you can offer on the trans-Atlantic and the dynamics causing the weakness there? The sequential deterioration in PRASM in Q1 was a little worse than I would have expected given the action just taken on seasonal shapi
componenttext: Okay. And is there an additional color you can offer on the trans-Atlantic and the dynamics causing the weakness there? The sequential deterioration in PRASM in Q1 was a little worse than I would have expected given the action just taken on seasonal shaping. Is there a lingering impact of Paris and Brussels that's going to impact Q2 as well? Or what are some of the dynamics there?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Julie, I think the recent events and the tragedy in Brussels has impacted bookings. What we generally see is a slowdown in bookings after events like that. Those begin to pick back up, but quite frankly, it looms days, even weeks of the booking curve
componenttext: Yes, Julie, I think the recent events and the tragedy in Brussels has impacted bookings. What we generally see is a slowdown in bookings after events like that. Those begin to pick back up, but quite frankly, it looms days, even weeks of the booking curve, and that's impacting the second quarter, which is why the trans-Atlantic, as you move towards the summer period, that booking curve still has plenty of time to fill up, and we see that demand. So I tie it more to the recent events that -- particularly in Brussels, that's affecting the overall travel to the trans-Atlantic.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Deutsche Bank, we have Michael Linenberg online.
componenttext: From Deutsche Bank, we have Michael Linenberg online.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Great. And then -- thanks, Oscar. And then my second question is to Gerry. With respect to the fleet, when we look at your fleet and how it's evolved, it looks like, versus the last update, there is a larger reduction in this number of CRJ-700s. And as I think about it, I would have maybe anticipated a bigger decline in 50-seaters rather than 70-seaters. I'm just curious if that reduction is a function of the fact that you're bringing in a lot of 175s, the Embraer aircraft, and maybe that you're up against scope, and so as 175s come in, you've got to take out CRJ-700. So if you could just provide an explanation for that, that'd be great.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a combination, I think, of 2 things. One, as you said, it's the scope limitations that would dictate some of the swapping out of the CRJs for the 175s. And also timing on when the 50-seat aircraft leases expire. We try not to take that aircraft that
componenttext: It's a combination, I think, of 2 things. One, as you said, it's the scope limitations that would dictate some of the swapping out of the CRJs for the 175s. And also timing on when the 50-seat aircraft leases expire. We try not to take that aircraft that we're still paying for. So between the 2, that would drive what we're seeing.

componenttext: Jim, I'd wonder -- you gave a lot of stats there pretty quickly. I wonder if you could just repeat, by regional entity, where you think we'll be in the fourth quarter and what gets us there.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Jim. As I said, on domestic, we expect, given our initiatives, improved reliability. We're seeing that translate into some of the highest customer -- the highest customer satisfaction scores that we've seen. And as we build on that momentum,
componenttext: Yes, this is Jim. As I said, on domestic, we expect, given our initiatives, improved reliability. We're seeing that translate into some of the highest customer -- the highest customer satisfaction scores that we've seen. And as we build on that momentum, coupled with the initiatives, I'm talking about entry-level fare initiative that comes from the second half of the month, the ability to upsell into first class as we put more 2-cabin aircraft into the domestic system and other marketing initiatives that will leverage that reliability that we're seeing in our system. We think those initiatives put us on a path to flat-to-positive RASM in the domestic -- consolidate domestic system in the fourth quarter. In the Latin, we also believe we have a path to progression to hit the flat Latin American PRASM by the fourth quarter as well as in the trans-Atlantic. The one area that we'll probably lag it, because of things that are --- particularly, the strong dollar, the RMB, the Chinese currency, it's relative -- the dollar relative strength to that currency has a longer tail to it, for lack of better words, than what we saw with the yen and the euro. So we think Pacific will take a little bit longer to get to flat PRASM by the fourth quarter. But we're really excited about it. We have a good path to it. We understand the importance of PRASM and what it means to drive in top line revenue, and the team's very much focused on it.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So flat-to-positive in domestic, Atlantic and Latin, which just feels like, given the relative size of those, it feels like a consolidated flat-to-positive despite Pacific. Is that a reasonable way to think about it?

componenttext: Well, I've put it kind of consolidated closer to flat. Again, the domestic, we think we have a path to flat-to-positive. The other international entities, given the capacity growth, will move closer to flat, so you weight those together. I would want to call it consolidated positive at this point.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Well, look, I'll jump in and let Gerry -- as you think about, from a network perspective, you can think of kind of -- you're right, the 3-ish 50-seaters, 2 to 3, kind of in line with each of those 737s that come in to replace those. We can kind of think of that 2 to 3 range in terms of that replacement.

And so we think from a customer point of view, it will drive great benefit. I think it's one of those things Oscar mentioned on our Investor Call in June. We can highlight and kind of walk you through some specific steps on that.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe to follow on some of the other questions that we've heard, I guess what might help is if you could give us some reassurance perhaps in the level of commitment to actually getting to a positive unit revenue trajectory. Meaning, I've he
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe to follow on some of the other questions that we've heard, I guess what might help is if you could give us some reassurance perhaps in the level of commitment to actually getting to a positive unit revenue trajectory. Meaning, I've heard some people ask you if you should get smaller, and I think that's a fair question. And I've heard some people ask you how confident really are you that you can get to a flat or modestly positive RASM trajectory in some of these markets by the end of the year. But just wondering, you have the ability to get to positive unit revenue in just about any demand environment, it just depends how small you're willing to get. So would you be willing to provide a commitment to the investment community to achieve a flat unit revenue trajectory by the end of the year?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Oscar. I think as far as future guidance, I just -- I want to hold my powder dry a little bit until I understand it a little more thoroughly and get a lot of input from all of you as well as our team here. I think on the June call, I think we'll b
componenttext: This is Oscar. I think as far as future guidance, I just -- I want to hold my powder dry a little bit until I understand it a little more thoroughly and get a lot of input from all of you as well as our team here. I think on the June call, I think we'll be able to give you a sense. I know that's a couple of months and it gives us a little more certainty about the year, but what I don't want to do is begin to commit on these calls, just to things that I know the market wants, I know the optics want to be there. We need to fly profitably. We need to fly the way we at United fly with our current network. And over some point in time, if that needs to change, we'll adjust accordingly. We'll make those changes, but we'll make them thoughtfully with a lot and lot of research and internal analysis. And those are not sort of shooting-from-the-hip kind of conversations that I want to have on the call. So if you'll allow me a little more patience now that we're getting back to work, we'll talk a little bit more about this in June. Thanks, Darryl.

componenttext: Okay. Okay, that's great. And then when it comes to thinking about fuel hedging, could you guys give us some update on your thought process around perhaps increasing your forward hedging, given the volatility to the upside that we've be seeing in fuel over the last several months?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Hedging is just one tool that can help provide better certainty as we try to achieve our business plan. Yes, it's no longer for us a hedging in the near-term volatility. That's a very expensive insurance policy that we can just stop, ensure that ris
componenttext: Sure. Hedging is just one tool that can help provide better certainty as we try to achieve our business plan. Yes, it's no longer for us a hedging in the near-term volatility. That's a very expensive insurance policy that we can just stop, ensure that risk. So it's just one tool. There are a number of factors that we'll look at, including our net exposure to fuel. One of the benefits of the Houston hub working the other way, that as fuel prices rise, there's a correlation on revenue particularly in Houston. So it would be that net exposure that we would focus on, the competitive landscape, what others are doing that could impact the industry and the overall economic environment. So we'll be thoughtful about our hedging. And as I mentioned in my prepared remarks, we have not done any hedging since last summer. And while there's been some volatility in fuel recently, from a historical perspective, it's still a very low-fuel environment.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the CapEx program, could you discuss a little bit about your thoughts on financing. Just -- I know you mentioned about maybe 50% of the aircraft would debt finance this year. But as you look forward, thoughts on operating leases or debt financing,
componenttext: Just on the CapEx program, could you discuss a little bit about your thoughts on financing. Just -- I know you mentioned about maybe 50% of the aircraft would debt finance this year. But as you look forward, thoughts on operating leases or debt financing, and how should we think about liquidity and debt targets?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Savi. Let me talk about leasing first. I would absolutely love to lease some of these aircraft, but it's got to make economic sense. And there are a number of factors, but let me give you 3. One is just the cost of money, cost of debt. As you know,
componenttext:
Sure, Savi. Let me talk about leasing first. I would absolutely love to lease some of these aircraft, but it's got to make economic sense. And there are a number of factors, but let me give you 3. One is just the cost of money, cost of debt. As you know, we can finance -- debt finance aircraft at a very low cost. That's raise a high hurdle for the leasing companies to overcome. And historically, they haven't been able to do that. They're better able to today to pass through their lower cost of funds to us, but that's one factor. Probably the bigger one is residual value. You need to make leasing work, a situation where the leasing company is going to be more optimistic on residual value than we are. And then sort of tenor. Think of it like buying an automobile. If you're going to trade in your automobile every 2 or 3 years, leasing has to make sense. If you're going to keep that auto through its useful life, leasing becomes very expensive. So when we book at these aircraft, these are largely core aircraft that we expect to keep very long term, 25, 30 years, and leasing can get expensive. But that's not to say leasing can't work. And like we've done historically, we will continue to look at leasing opportunities and see if we can make anything work in that space. 
But that's one of the reasons why when we talk about free cash flow and capital allocation, I look at adjusted free cash flow. So for me, I'm going to adjust for the financing. So whether it's a lease, whether we use WTCs or other debt financing, that's going to drive the availability of liquidity that we can use in our capital allocation program where top priority is still going to be returning cash to shareholders. And as we continue to have strong earnings, we would continue with that program.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

And then just from a timing perspective, when do you expect that to kind of manifest itself into the revenue and cost as a benefit?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Greg, Savi. I'll take the first piece and then defer it to Jim and Gerry on the cost and revenue piece. We look at a ton of factors and a ton of measurements in terms of how we're performing, everything from bag delivery and performance to -- 2 di
componenttext: This is Greg, Savi. I'll take the first piece and then defer it to Jim and Gerry on the cost and revenue piece. We look at a ton of factors and a ton of measurements in terms of how we're performing, everything from bag delivery and performance to -- 2 different ways of looking at arrival and departure performance to how quickly we shut doors on aircraft and literally tens and tens of metrics each and every day. And we've managed this quarter through the hard work of the United team and the 86,000 people out in the field working the flights each and every day to actually set record performance across many, many metrics. And as proud of that performance as we are, we're more excited about where we're headed because we feel like we still have a lot of opportunity to improve from there.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jim. I would just add that reliability that we're seeing and the great progress in that area, we actually are seeing in our hubs our share growing and taking hold the beginnings of that. And when I talk about moving towards flat-to-positive RASM b
componenttext: This is Jim. I would just add that reliability that we're seeing and the great progress in that area, we actually are seeing in our hubs our share growing and taking hold the beginnings of that. And when I talk about moving towards flat-to-positive RASM by the fourth quarter in domestic, again a piece of that is the momentum that we're capturing there. So it's hard to put a time line on when that revenue, and Oscar referred to that the earlier, but we're seeing signs in our hubs of that share. We want to obviously expand that to some of the spoke cities and get some traction there, and -- but we're really confident with the reliability, with the initiatives we have out there. That's part of our success in moving towards flat-to-positive in the fourth quarter.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and from the cost side, we're seeing some of that benefit already. You think about disconnects and having to deal with the cost of putting customers up at hotels and meals and whatnot and crude cost as well. So all of that, we see immediately as we r
componenttext: Yes, and from the cost side, we're seeing some of that benefit already. You think about disconnects and having to deal with the cost of putting customers up at hotels and meals and whatnot and crude cost as well. So all of that, we see immediately as we run more reliable operation. But there's still more to come on that as we can gain greater efficiency in the operations. So while we have some cost savings, we're already seeing it will increase over time.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so this is Oscar. I'll add one thing, at least from my operational background that I think applies across any industry. As you invest to become more reliable, that investment is clearly a cost one. As you get more reliable, how you reduce that cost or
componenttext: And so this is Oscar. I'll add one thing, at least from my operational background that I think applies across any industry. As you invest to become more reliable, that investment is clearly a cost one. As you get more reliable, how you reduce that cost or that safety cushion, how quickly you do it, how effectively you do it is a key attribute that Mr. Hart will be [ph] challenged with very quickly. And but again, every time we do that, I mean, we just had Denver and Houston over the last couple of weeks have been massively hit. We have 700 people not able to come to work on a day. And so it's all those things and all those different moving parts that you have to address. But that safety cushion that's across the system will have to be managed better. And then, therefore costs comes out. But it starts with having a reliable product. So thank you.
