componenttext: It's something -- and Mike, this is Jim. It's on profitability analysis. You can thank my boss for the slide.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then -- thanks, Oscar. And then my second question is to Gerry. With respect to the fleet, when we look at your fleet and how it's evolved, it looks like, versus the last update, there is a larger reduction in this number of CRJ-700s. And as I
componenttext: Great. And then -- thanks, Oscar. And then my second question is to Gerry. With respect to the fleet, when we look at your fleet and how it's evolved, it looks like, versus the last update, there is a larger reduction in this number of CRJ-700s. And as I think about it, I would have maybe anticipated a bigger decline in 50-seaters rather than 70-seaters. I'm just curious if that reduction is a function of the fact that you're bringing in a lot of 175s, the Embraer aircraft, and maybe that you're up against scope, and so as 175s come in, you've got to take out CRJ-700. So if you could just provide an explanation for that, that'd be great.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a combination, I think, of 2 things. One, as you said, it's the scope limitations that would dictate some of the swapping out of the CRJs for the 175s. And also timing on when the 50-seat aircraft leases expire. We try not to take that aircraft that
componenttext: It's a combination, I think, of 2 things. One, as you said, it's the scope limitations that would dictate some of the swapping out of the CRJs for the 175s. And also timing on when the 50-seat aircraft leases expire. We try not to take that aircraft that we're still paying for. So between the 2, that would drive what we're seeing.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Evercore ISI, we have Duane Pfennigwerth.
componenttext: From Evercore ISI, we have Duane Pfennigwerth.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, I'd wonder -- you gave a lot of stats there pretty quickly. I wonder if you could just repeat, by regional entity, where you think we'll be in the fourth quarter and what gets us there.
componenttext: Jim, I'd wonder -- you gave a lot of stats there pretty quickly. I wonder if you could just repeat, by regional entity, where you think we'll be in the fourth quarter and what gets us there.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Jim. As I said, on domestic, we expect, given our initiatives, improved reliability. We're seeing that translate into some of the highest customer -- the highest customer satisfaction scores that we've seen. And as we build on that momentum,
componenttext: Yes, this is Jim. As I said, on domestic, we expect, given our initiatives, improved reliability. We're seeing that translate into some of the highest customer -- the highest customer satisfaction scores that we've seen. And as we build on that momentum, coupled with the initiatives, I'm talking about entry-level fare initiative that comes from the second half of the month, the ability to upsell into first class as we put more 2-cabin aircraft into the domestic system and other marketing initiatives that will leverage that reliability that we're seeing in our system. We think those initiatives put us on a path to flat-to-positive RASM in the domestic -- consolidate domestic system in the fourth quarter. In the Latin, we also believe we have a path to progression to hit the flat Latin American PRASM by the fourth quarter as well as in the trans-Atlantic. The one area that we'll probably lag it, because of things that are --- particularly, the strong dollar, the RMB, the Chinese currency, it's relative -- the dollar relative strength to that currency has a longer tail to it, for lack of better words, than what we saw with the yen and the euro. So we think Pacific will take a little bit longer to get to flat PRASM by the fourth quarter. But we're really excited about it. We have a good path to it. We understand the importance of PRASM and what it means to drive in top line revenue, and the team's very much focused on it.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So flat-to-positive in domestic, Atlantic and Latin, which just feels like, given the relative size of those, it feels like a consolidated flat-to-positive despite Pacific. Is that a reasonable way to think about it?
componenttext: So flat-to-positive in domestic, Atlantic and Latin, which just feels like, given the relative size of those, it feels like a consolidated flat-to-positive despite Pacific. Is that a reasonable way to think about it?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I put it kind of consolidated closer to flat. Again, the domestic, we think we have a path to flat to positive. The other international entities, given the capacity of growth, will move closer to flat. So you weigh those together, I would (sic) [ wo
componenttext: Well, I put it kind of consolidated closer to flat. Again, the domestic, we think we have a path to flat to positive. The other international entities, given the capacity of growth, will move closer to flat. So you weigh those together, I would (sic) [ wouldn't ] want to call it consolidated positive at this point.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just for my second question, as we think about losing a bunch of these 50-seaters, can you give us some basic building blocks? So maybe a ratio for every 3 50-seaters that goes away, you take one of these mainline deliveries associated with
componenttext: Okay. And then just for my second question, as we think about losing a bunch of these 50-seaters, can you give us some basic building blocks? So maybe a ratio for every 3 50-seaters that goes away, you take one of these mainline deliveries associated with that order. And then just the inputs to profit improvement to help us sort of build up to what this fleet transition could mean for you over the next couple of years.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I'll jump in and let Gerry -- as you think about, from a network perspective, you can think of kind of -- you're right, the 3-ish 50-seaters, 2 to 3, kind of in line with each of those 737s that come in to replace those. And so we think of con
componenttext: Well, look, I'll jump in and let Gerry -- as you think about, from a network perspective, you can think of kind of -- you're right, the 3-ish 50-seaters, 2 to 3, kind of in line with each of those 737s that come in to replace those. And so we think of concepts of [indiscernible] in markets where there's -- we're seat-neutral and where we can work with frequency and use that mainline aircraft that's holding the pattern that previously had much more higher frequency of 50-seaters. We can kind of think of that 2 to 3 range in terms of that replacement.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can you give us any sense for profit improvement for each of these that goes away?
componenttext: And can you give us any sense for profit improvement for each of these that goes away?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't, but I really want to stress the ability to drive ancillary revenue first hand given the Economy Plus section that comes with that. It's a great first-class cabin. It comes with Wi-Fi. It comes with our personal device entertainment system. So
componenttext: We haven't, but I really want to stress the ability to drive ancillary revenue first hand given the Economy Plus section that comes with that. It's a great first-class cabin. It comes with Wi-Fi. It comes with our personal device entertainment system. So it has a lot of the attributes that customers are looking for. And it will come with increased reliability. And so we think from a customer point of view, it will drive great benefit. I think it's one of those things Oscar mentioned on our Investor Call in June. We can highlight and kind of walk you through some specific steps on that.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just on the cost, I would add, clearly, the larger aircraft is going to be more efficient on a seat-cost basis. And fuel efficiency as well, there will be some meaningful savings there.
componenttext: And just on the cost, I would add, clearly, the larger aircraft is going to be more efficient on a seat-cost basis. And fuel efficiency as well, there will be some meaningful savings there.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: From UBS, we have Darryl Genovesi online.
componenttext: From UBS, we have Darryl Genovesi online.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: With regard to the changes that we're seeing at Newark, in the -- yes, the regulatory changes at Newark, do you have a sense of just how much, if any, additional capacity may be accommodated? And not necessarily your own but, in total, Newark capacity as
componenttext: With regard to the changes that we're seeing at Newark, in the -- yes, the regulatory changes at Newark, do you have a sense of just how much, if any, additional capacity may be accommodated? And not necessarily your own but, in total, Newark capacity as a result of DFA relaxing some of the restrictions there?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Darryl, this is Jim. We don't, and the marketplace will obviously will determine that. Again, our big concern in a highly congested, most congested airspace is the risk of a more congested airspace. And so what that will mean for our customers. In terms o
componenttext: Darryl, this is Jim. We don't, and the marketplace will obviously will determine that. Again, our big concern in a highly congested, most congested airspace is the risk of a more congested airspace. And so what that will mean for our customers. In terms of what the market dynamics or what the results mean, we just don't have a sense of that right now.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe to follow on some of the other questions that we've heard, I guess what might help is if you could give us some reassurance perhaps in the level of commitment to actually getting to a positive unit revenue trajectory. Meaning, I've he
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe to follow on some of the other questions that we've heard, I guess what might help is if you could give us some reassurance perhaps in the level of commitment to actually getting to a positive unit revenue trajectory. Meaning, I've heard some people ask you if you should get smaller, and I think that's a fair question. And I've heard some people ask you how confident really are you that you can get to a flat or modestly positive RASM trajectory in some of these markets by the end of the year. But just wondering, you have the ability to get to positive unit revenue in just about any demand environment, it just depends how small you're willing to get. So would you be willing to provide a commitment to the investment community to achieve a flat unit revenue trajectory by the end of the year?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Oscar. I think as far as future guidance, I just -- I want to hold my powder dry a little bit until I understand it a little more thoroughly and get a lot of input from all of you as well as our team here. I think on the June call, I think we'll b
componenttext: This is Oscar. I think as far as future guidance, I just -- I want to hold my powder dry a little bit until I understand it a little more thoroughly and get a lot of input from all of you as well as our team here. I think on the June call, I think we'll be able to give you a sense. I know that's a couple of months and it gives us a little more certainty about the year, but what I don't want to do is begin to commit on these calls, just to things that I know the market wants, I know the optics want to be there. We need to fly profitably. We need to fly the way we at United fly with our current network. And over some point in time, if that needs to change, we'll adjust accordingly. We'll make those changes, but we'll make them thoughtfully with a lot and lot of research and internal analysis. And those are not sort of shooting-from-the-hip kind of conversations that I want to have on the call. So if you'll allow me a little more patience now that we're getting back to work, we'll talk a little bit more about this in June. Thanks, Darryl.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Stephens, we have Jack Atkins.
componenttext: From Stephens, we have Jack Atkins.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: When it comes to rolling out that basic economy fare later on this year, sort of what are the gating factors that would prevent you guys from getting that out as expected? Sort of what needs to happen internally? Is it IT or something else?
componenttext: When it comes to rolling out that basic economy fare later on this year, sort of what are the gating factors that would prevent you guys from getting that out as expected? Sort of what needs to happen internally? Is it IT or something else?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jack, this is Jim. We're really confident on our timeline. The IT team here is very focused. It's a very collaborative process. Quite frankly, it's collaborative with our operations team because we want to make sure that across the enterprise, the underst
componenttext: Jack, this is Jim. We're really confident on our timeline. The IT team here is very focused. It's a very collaborative process. Quite frankly, it's collaborative with our operations team because we want to make sure that across the enterprise, the understanding of what the customer's purchasing and what their expectations are for that product are really clear. So we're really confident on the timeline. And I don't see any gates or, as you mentioned, in our way. There's a huge collaboration going on and IT is right behind us with it.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay, that's great. And then when it comes to thinking about fuel hedging, could you guys give us some update on your thought process around perhaps increasing your forward hedging, given the volatility to the upside that we've be seeing in fuel ove
componenttext: Okay. Okay, that's great. And then when it comes to thinking about fuel hedging, could you guys give us some update on your thought process around perhaps increasing your forward hedging, given the volatility to the upside that we've be seeing in fuel over the last several months?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Hedging is just one tool that can help provide better certainty as we try to achieve our business plan. Yes, it's no longer for us a hedging in the near-term volatility. That's a very expensive insurance policy that we can just stop, ensure that ris
componenttext: Sure. Hedging is just one tool that can help provide better certainty as we try to achieve our business plan. Yes, it's no longer for us a hedging in the near-term volatility. That's a very expensive insurance policy that we can just stop, ensure that risk. So it's just one tool. There are a number of factors that we'll look at, including our net exposure to fuel. One of the benefits of the Houston hub working the other way, that as fuel prices rise, there's a correlation on revenue particularly in Houston. So it would be that net exposure that we would focus on, the competitive landscape, what others are doing that could impact the industry and the overall economic environment. So we'll be thoughtful about our hedging. And as I mentioned in my prepared remarks, we have not done any hedging since last summer. And while there's been some volatility in fuel recently, from a historical perspective, it's still a very low-fuel environment.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Raymond James, we have Savi Syth online.
componenttext: From Raymond James, we have Savi Syth online.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the CapEx program, could you discuss a little bit about your thoughts on financing. Just -- I know you mentioned about maybe 50% of the aircraft would debt finance this year. But as you look forward, thoughts on operating leases or debt financing,
componenttext: Just on the CapEx program, could you discuss a little bit about your thoughts on financing. Just -- I know you mentioned about maybe 50% of the aircraft would debt finance this year. But as you look forward, thoughts on operating leases or debt financing, and how should we think about liquidity and debt targets?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Savi. Let me talk about leasing first. I would absolutely love to lease some of these aircraft, but it's got to make economic sense. And there are a number of factors, but let me give you 3. One is just the cost of money, cost of debt. As you know,
componenttext: Sure, Savi. Let me talk about leasing first. I would absolutely love to lease some of these aircraft, but it's got to make economic sense. And there are a number of factors, but let me give you 3. One is just the cost of money, cost of debt. As you know, we can finance -- debt finance aircraft at a very low cost. That's raise a high hurdle for the leasing companies to overcome. And historically, they haven't been able to do that. They're better able to today to pass through their lower cost of funds to us, but that's one factor. Probably the bigger one is residual value. You need to make leasing work, a situation where the leasing company is going to be more optimistic on residual value than we are. And then sort of tenor. Think of it like buying an automobile. If you're going to trade in your automobile every 2 or 3 years, leasing has to make sense. If you're going to keep that auto through its useful life, leasing becomes very expensive. So when we book at these aircraft, these are largely core aircraft that we expect to keep very long term, 25, 30 years, and leasing can get expensive. But that's not to say leasing can't work. And like we've done historically, we will continue to look at leasing opportunities and see if we can make anything work in that space. But that's one of the reasons why when we talk about free cash flow and capital allocation, I look at adjusted free cash flow. So for me, I'm going to adjust for the financing. So whether it's a lease, whether we use WTCs or other debt financing, that's going to drive the availability of liquidity that we can use in our capital allocation program where top priority is still going to be returning cash to shareholders. And as we continue to have strong earnings, we would continue with that program.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful color. And for a follow-up, just on the reliability, that's been a very big focus, and there'll be a lot of investments here made to kind of continue to improve reliability, could you discuss like what metrics you're looking to measure
componenttext: That's very helpful color. And for a follow-up, just on the reliability, that's been a very big focus, and there'll be a lot of investments here made to kind of continue to improve reliability, could you discuss like what metrics you're looking to measure, how you're performing on that? And then just from a timing perspective, when do you expect that to kind of manifest itself into the revenue and cost as a benefit?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Greg, Savi. I'll take the first piece and then defer it to Jim and Gerry on the cost and revenue piece. We look at a ton of factors and a ton of measurements in terms of how we're performing, everything from bag delivery and performance to -- 2 di
componenttext: This is Greg, Savi. I'll take the first piece and then defer it to Jim and Gerry on the cost and revenue piece. We look at a ton of factors and a ton of measurements in terms of how we're performing, everything from bag delivery and performance to -- 2 different ways of looking at arrival and departure performance to how quickly we shut doors on aircraft and literally tens and tens of metrics each and every day. And we've managed this quarter through the hard work of the United team and the 86,000 people out in the field working the flights each and every day to actually set record performance across many, many metrics. And as proud of that performance as we are, we're more excited about where we're headed because we feel like we still have a lot of opportunity to improve from there.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jim. I would just add that reliability that we're seeing and the great progress in that area, we actually are seeing in our hubs our share growing and taking hold the beginnings of that. And when I talk about moving towards flat-to-positive RASM b
componenttext: This is Jim. I would just add that reliability that we're seeing and the great progress in that area, we actually are seeing in our hubs our share growing and taking hold the beginnings of that. And when I talk about moving towards flat-to-positive RASM by the fourth quarter in domestic, again a piece of that is the momentum that we're capturing there. So it's hard to put a time line on when that revenue, and Oscar referred to that the earlier, but we're seeing signs in our hubs of that share. We want to obviously expand that to some of the spoke cities and get some traction there, and -- but we're really confident with the reliability, with the initiatives we have out there. That's part of our success in moving towards flat-to-positive in the fourth quarter.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and from the cost side, we're seeing some of that benefit already. You think about disconnects and having to deal with the cost of putting customers up at hotels and meals and whatnot and crude cost as well. So all of that, we see immediately as we r
componenttext: Yes, and from the cost side, we're seeing some of that benefit already. You think about disconnects and having to deal with the cost of putting customers up at hotels and meals and whatnot and crude cost as well. So all of that, we see immediately as we run more reliable operation. But there's still more to come on that as we can gain greater efficiency in the operations. So while we have some cost savings, we're already seeing it will increase over time.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so this is Oscar. I'll add one thing, at least from my operational background that I think applies across any industry. As you invest to become more reliable, that investment is clearly a cost one. As you get more reliable, how you reduce that cost or
componenttext: And so this is Oscar. I'll add one thing, at least from my operational background that I think applies across any industry. As you invest to become more reliable, that investment is clearly a cost one. As you get more reliable, how you reduce that cost or that safety cushion, how quickly you do it, how effectively you do it is a key attribute that Mr. Hart will be [ph] challenged with very quickly. And but again, every time we do that, I mean, we just had Denver and Houston over the last couple of weeks have been massively hit. We have 700 people not able to come to work on a day. And so it's all those things and all those different moving parts that you have to address. But that safety cushion that's across the system will have to be managed better. And then, therefore costs comes out. But it starts with having a reliable product. So thank you.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Savi, and thanks to all of you for joining the call today. Please call Investor Relations if you have any further questions. And we look forward to talking to you next quarter.
componenttext: Thanks, Savi, and thanks to all of you for joining the call today. Please call Investor Relations if you have any further questions. And we look forward to talking to you next quarter.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. This concludes today's conference. You may now disconnect.

I will now turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Jonathan Ireland, Managing Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brandon. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to United's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Yesterday, we issued our earnings release and separate investor update. Additionally, this morning, we issued a presentation to accompany
componenttext:
Thank you, Brandon. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to United's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. 
Yesterday, we issued our earnings release and separate investor update. 
Additionally, this morning, we issued a presentation to accompany this call. All 3 of these documents are available on our website at ir.united.com. 
Information on yesterday's release and investor update and remarks made during this conference call may contain forward-looking statements, which represent the company's current expectations or beliefs concerning future events and financial performance. All forward-looking statements are based upon information currently available to the company. A number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from our current expectations. Please refer to our press release, Form 10-K and other reports filed with the SEC by United Continental Holdings and United Airlines for more thorough description of these factors. 
Also during the course of our call, we will discuss several non-GAAP financial measures. For a reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures to GAAP measures, please refer to the tables at the end of our earnings release and investor update, copies of which are available on our website. 
Unless otherwise noted, special charges are excluded as we walk you through our numbers for the quarter These items are detailed in our earnings release. 
Joining us here in Chicago to discuss our results are President and CEO, Oscar Munoz; Vice Chairman and Chief Revenue Officer, Jim Compton; and Senior Vice President, Finance and Acting Chief Financial Officer, Gerry Laderman. 
We also have Chief Operations Officer and Executive Vice President, Greg Hart, in the room to assist with the Q&
A. And now, I'd like to call over to Oscar.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jonathan, and thank you all for joining us today. Although as we look the second quarter, we certainly made significant progress and as we continue to execute against our global operation better than our company has actually has ever seen and a
componenttext:
Thank you, Jonathan, and thank you all for joining us today. Although as we look the second quarter, we certainly made significant progress and as we continue to execute against our global operation better than our company has actually has ever seen and at the same time, delivering solid financial performance. 
As you can see on the chart for the second quarter, we recorded a pretax profit of $1.4 billion and achieved pretax margins of 14.5%, those are both excluding special items. 
For the quarter, we earned $2.61 in diluted earnings per share, which once adjusted for taxes, represent a 25% increase year-over-year.  We delivered this result while improving our initial expectations. 
So we've clearly accomplished a lot and I'm proud of the hard work of the United team. So let me give you -- I manage to thank all our employees for their continued dedication on to providing a positive, reliable experience for our customers.  This can be seen in our operation continue to perform at a high-level last quarter with on time performance, improving over 11 points year-over-year. And on the heels of our best ever 6 months run long time arrivals [indiscernible] we are now consistently performing at the level that we and our customers expect of us. Our focus is now shifted to maintaining this level of reliability, while doing so more efficiently. 
We also completed an important milestone and our labor negotiations by leveraging joint tender of agreement with our flight attendants. 
[indiscernible] If ratified, this agreement will bring our 20,000-plus flight attendants on to a single contract, leaving the inefficiencies we have experienced over the last several years and most importantly, this will be the important step in unifying our airline to one shared purpose to be the airline we know we can be. 
I want to extend a special thank you to the FAA for their dedication and effort in reaching this agreement. And as we speak, the flight attendants are participating in roadshows and submitting their votes, and we look forward to seeing the results in mid-August. 
Speaking of our flight attendants, training is already underway with them in many of our other employees in preparation for the December launch of our new United Polaris business class. Construction is already started on the first Polaris launch in Chicago, production has also started in our new suite life seats and the first wave of our [indiscernible] menus are being finalized. 
The experience we're creating, as you know, is exactly what our customers have asked for, and we can't wait for you to enjoy it yourselves, starting on the 1st of December. 
Now back to the quarter. Although we also continued repurchasing our stock, spending approximately $700 million, representing a little over 4% of our shares outstanding and as we announced yesterday, our Board has approved an additional acquisition for $2 billion. 
As many of you have heard me say, I believe in proof not promise. As you can see, this quarter, we had many proof points that we are continuing to build a greater airline. However, as we mentioned on our June investor call, this is not enough and we fully acknowledge we aren't yet performing in financial perspective to [indiscernible] to our and your expectations, and we're not standing still. As can be seen on Slide 5 in our June call, we laid out a description of initiatives we are currently implementing and are expected to drive over $3 billion in benefit by 2018. 
In our [indiscernible] presentation, I encourage you to go to our website and download it. 
We expect these initiatives to contribute to driving incremental value and shrinking our margin down to peers.  We'll keep you updated on the cost -- progress of these issues. 
And we're not stopping there. We're currently in the middle of a thorough self-evaluation of all assets of our business. 
In particular, as shown on Slide 6, we are working to identify ways to operate our airline more efficiently now than top tier reliability. 
We're also refining initiatives of each geographic region, hub and [indiscernible]. 
Additionally, we are implementing the profit maximizing product and segmentation strategy that best aligns with our customers. And finally, we have cost kept to our peers that we are identifying and addressing those cost control.  I'm looking forward to presenting this next chapter of United at our fourth quarter Investor Day. 
But before I turn it over the call over to Jim, I'd like to speak to our future capacity plans. 
Let me start by saying we have acknowledge, truly acknowledge the importance of returning to positive unit revenue and of course, we recognize that our future capacity plans join the impact of future positive performance. 
However, we must evaluate what our network is today and the evolution to ensure that long-term optimization and sustainable earnings we obtain. At times, this may include adding capacity to strengthen our best-performing markets and ensuring we remain competitive. However, we determined that certain flags will not generate sustained profitability. We will then carefully consider modifying that capacity. 
Proof of our result is seen in us, again, reducing full year capacity 0.25 points. We've now reduced our 2016 capacity growth plans by 0.75 points. This is a meaningful demonstration of our responsibility to the present demand environment, particularly given that our initial guidance has always been responsively and conservatively constructive. 
Our review and analysis wont stop here as we continue to closely evaluate future changes. 
Going forward, as we adjust our capacity, we tend to update shareowners on this modifications. 
So to wrap up, again, I want to thank our employees for another great quarter and their continued focus on our customers. I continue to spend a lot of time visiting stations and I can't be more proud of the work they're all doing. 
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Jim.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Oscar. As you can see on Slide 8, our second quarter unit revenue declined 6.6%, nearly a full point better than our initial expectations, primarily due to international  yields, 4th of July holiday timing and other initiatives. With respect to
componenttext:
Thanks, Oscar. As you can see on Slide 8, our second quarter unit revenue declined 6.6%, nearly a full point better than our initial expectations, primarily due to international  yields, 4th of July holiday timing and other initiatives. 
With respect to the third quarter, we expect our passenger unit revenue to decline approximately 5.5% to 7.5% year-over-year with domestic and international PRASM to be in both same ranges. 
On Slide 8, we define each of the major headwinds we anticipate for the third quarter, summing to approximately 3.5 points of drag on PRASM. 
I'd now like to explain what we are seeing in the current demand environment. Leisure bookings have been strong as travelers are taking advantage of attractive fair levels and the strong U.S. dollar. Corporate travel bookings in the second quarter were essentially flat with revenue down approximately 3% and corporate yields continue to be pressured. 
Looking forward towards the rest of the year, we expect to see further softening of corporate deals as summer leisure travel subsides. We will closely monitor this FX as they impact our close in yield high-yield revenue. 
On our April earnings call, we provided an outlook for fourth quarter PRASM, and I'd like to update you on that today. 
Due to downward revisions for fourth quarter GDP as well as a growing concern in the pace of corporate yield recovery, our fourth quarter estimates have been revised downward. 
In response, as you have seen from our announcement yesterday, we are reducing second half capacity to better align with demand. 
On Slide 9, we show specific actions we have taken in each geographic entity. I'll let you read through the details on your own, but rest assured, we are actively managing our network to optimize results in a challenging revenue environment and are seeing the results. 
For instance, as a result of our capacity reallocation, Houston had the best year-over-year PRASM of any hub in June, followed closely by San Francisco and Denver. 
Taking all these regional dynamics into account with respect to capacity as can be seen on Slide 10, we now anticipate full year capacity to grow between 1% and 1.5%. 
As Oscar mentioned, we are currently in the process of closely evaluating our capacity for the fourth quarter and 2017. 
As I wrap up, I want to reiterate our focus on maximizing profitability throughout our entire network. We are constantly evaluating the revenue and profitability landscape to ensure we have the proper plan in place. We continue to be committed to growing our capacity in line with demand, but remain willing and prepared to adjust when necessary. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Gerry.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. A summary of our financial performance can be seen on Slide 12 for GAAP financials and Slide 13 for non-GAAP financials. Excluding special items, pretax earnings were $1.4 billion, with a pretax margin of 14.5%. Importantly, our earnings
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. A summary of our financial performance can be seen on Slide 12 for GAAP financials and Slide 13 for non-GAAP financials. 
Excluding special items, pretax earnings were $1.4 billion, with a pretax margin of 14.5%. 
Importantly, our earnings per share were $2.61, a 25% improvement year-over-year when adjusted for taxes as we continue to repurchase shares. 
Moving to Slide 14. Nonfuel unit cost for the quarter were 2.5% when excluding special charges, profit sharing and third party expenses. 
For the third quarter, we expect nonfuel unit cost to grow 2.5% to 3.5% and for the full year, we continue to expect unit cost to grow 2% to 3% despite reducing capacity by almost 1 point versus initial expectations. 
This guidance includes the benefit of our annual efficiency savings initiatives from our 2013 cost-savings program as well as our recently announced 2016 program. 
In total, we expect these 2 programs to drive $400 million of cost benefit when compared to 2015. 
This [indiscernible] guidance also includes the impact from the 3 ratified labor agreements reached this year, but does not include any assumption associated with the sensitive agreement we recently reached with our flight attendants. Once ratified, we will provide more specifics on the impact our costs. 
Based on the guidance we have provided for revenue and cost, we expect our pretax margin to be between 13.5% and 15.5% for the third quarter. 
With respect to cash, in the second quarter, we generated approximately $2.5 billion of operating cash flow and $1.8 billion of free cash flow. 
As you can see on Slide 15, during the quarter, we invested approximately $770 million in the business and took delivery of 2 Boeing 787-9 aircraft and 2 737-800 aircraft. 
As Oscar mentioned, we repurchased approximately $700 million of our shares in the quarter.  As of the end of the second quarter, we still have approximately $255 million remaining on our prior $3 billion authorization. 
Additionally, as announced yesterday, our Board has approved a new $2 billion share authorization. 
Returning cash to our shareholders is a core element of our capital allocation strategy. However, this will not be done at the expense of the health of our balance sheet as maintaining manageable debt levels is critical to running the airlines through a variety of economic cycles. 
In conclusion, throughout the quarter, we have continue to demonstrate strong cost difference discipline, a commitment to invest in our business and a desire to reward our shareholders. We believe the plan we have in place position us well to continue these actions going forward, while allowing us to be nimble and responsive to changing economic environment. 
I'll now turn it back over to Oscar.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gerry. As you've heard, we've made substantial progress in the second quarter, but we know there's more work to do as already [indiscernible] paying off continue to be across your United as we work to set our next chapter. I look forward to sha
componenttext:
Thank you, Gerry. As you've heard, we've made substantial progress in the second quarter, but we know there's more work to do as already [indiscernible] paying off continue to be across your United as we work to set our next chapter. I look forward to sharing with more of this with you later in the year. 
I'd like to pause by thanking our customers [indiscernible] operations running are well, our schedules are adapting to meet your need and our airport onboard products continue to hold future flying experience. 
Thank you for choosing United. We look forward to seeing on the flights soon. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Jonathan for Q&A.

componenttextpreview: I'll surprise you with a non-RASM question. Gerry, if you some that the current fuel curve and the RASM environment continues into next year, and you plug in some new labor contracts and the step up in CapEx that it looks like you guys will have next year
componenttext: I'll surprise you with a non-RASM question. Gerry, if you some that the current fuel curve and the RASM environment continues into next year, and you plug in some new labor contracts and the step up in CapEx that it looks like you guys will have next year, that is the potential to consume most if not all of your free cash flow next year. So first of all, can you say whether you agree with that assessment? And could you put a finer point on what CapEx looks like next year and how much flexibility you have to manage that down if the RASM environment remains challenging?

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Gerald one thing I talked before about looking at free cash flow net of aircraft financing. We had this discussion at whether we choose the least aircraft or buy aircraft that's making sure difference in free cash flow. So we are now looking at cash
componenttext: Sure. Gerald one thing I talked before about looking at free cash flow net of aircraft financing. We had this discussion at whether we choose the least aircraft or buy aircraft that's making sure difference in free cash flow. So we are now looking at cash and cash allocation, I do take that into account. And we can to finalize our plan for financing closer to the start of the year, but just kind of looking at where our aircraft CapEx next year is and kind of what we did this year, I think it's reasonable to assume -- have the range of about 1/2 to 2/3 of our aircraft CapEx being financed year. So probably part of that it could be little bit less, it could be a little bit more depending on interest rates, but in the current interest rate environment, as you've seen us and others do, the capital markets are quite attractive. So that's one level we have, sort of depending on the environment, how much of our aircraft CapEx is financed. In terms of other levers, we can always dial down non-aircraft CapEx. We had reasonable experience doing that. Aircraft CapEx, the only comment I would make is that it tends to be the case that when a manufacturer is building an aircraft, they expect to take it, and they tend to start cutting that all, call it 18 months, 15 months [ph] ahead of schedule. So you clearly much walk in most of the years aircraft sort of not now within the next few months. But you can't do a lot with aircraft beyond that, and we've done that in the past when necessary.

componenttext: So Oscar, you mentioned that you're  undertaking a self-evaluation all on specs of the business and there's some headlines Bloomberg that says you guys are reviewing management hubs and operations. So this is good and this is I think what a lot of you have been waiting to see. So can you give us some color on this? Is this like a full scale what you referred to sort of like a top to bottom strategic review? And can you give us may be a sense of how to think about a timeline, when you have something to say about these things? What is potential set of outcomes? Or this more net like a finite I is going to last 6 months or something more just like an ongoing efforts new approach as to how you're thinking right about business. Just any color but this would be great.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think with regards to duration, I think companies have made the mistake of doing these near-term things and then stopping. It's a dynamic world and have to adjust accordingly, but you have to start with a full-blown trust and it's amazing how quick news
componenttext: I think with regards to duration, I think companies have made the mistake of doing these near-term things and then stopping. It's a dynamic world and have to adjust accordingly, but you have to start with a full-blown trust and it's amazing how quick news travels. I just issued  that note this morning to our employees. It is a top to bottom full sail view on everything that we do, it's something that we have the and acknowledge and that involves management structure, it was aligned. I've always said that structure follows strategy, and so developing in the near term what our Northstar is, I think the critical point. So we do have a finite time period that we'll work through over the summer. We have a board meeting with -- in September, where we've all talk about this, and you'll hear about it in our fourth quarter Investor Day. And then, again, it will change as dynamics of the competitive marketplace. We're excited. It is spanning the blow, if you will, with regards the conversation we're having with. More than a few work streams working around every little thing to product offerings, to the broader issues around capacity and network planning. And so I think it's exciting. So thank you for asking that.

componenttext: So Oscar, United's operating performance from both in on time and delay perspective has been steadily improving since last fall. But there's obviously been a lot of industry headwinds that have not allowed you, your PRASM to really show any benefit from this. I guess, one, what are some of the initiatives you believe help helped you get there the -- get the you are operationally? And then second, do you have an estimate of what kind of PRASM benefit that you have gotten this year from this improved performance?

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I was looking at Greg. I don't know that I have number specifically for the PRASM impact, but with regards to your question about what's generating this, first and foremost, it's the incredible passion of the professionals that run our business. They
componenttext: No. I was looking at Greg. I don't know that I have number specifically for the PRASM impact, but with regards to your question about what's generating this, first and foremost, it's the incredible passion of the professionals that run our business. They have reengaged in a way that we haven't seen in a long time and that's just not be talking. You can ask a lot of folks that are that benefit. They are just working hard and they're engaged and I think that's a big critical factor. In addition, over time, between Project Quality, along the process and procedures, investments that we've made in the business, which are substantial are all assisting those folks given the tools to properly do their job. And the benefits again, it's a good question, we should come up with a more quantitative answer, it is significant value. I say it running better is running cheaper. And we are seeing that, and we'll get you better number here over the course of time.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, I would just like to add just from a customer perspective what we're hearing in the marketplace, as Oscar said, the level of operation is really, really strong and the operations team has proven, it's sustainable and durable. We're hearing that back
componenttext: Hey, I would just like to add just from a customer perspective what we're hearing in the marketplace, as Oscar said, the level of operation is really, really strong and the operations team has proven, it's sustainable and durable. We're hearing that back from our customers. Our corporate sales force -- our team basis is very excited about, for instance, it going in and bring in the scorecard of our corporate guarantee.  And year-to-date, 6-plus months into it, we're not paying at it, which means we're meeting our commitment in terms of our operation. So that -- it's a hard PRASM on it. Those are the things that will be the PRASM. We're seeing our local share in our hubs rebounding back to levels that we saw before some of our integration issues, and so we're really, really excited about it. And lastly, on our call in June, we talked about $300 million of operational efficiency as well as some of the -- what I call choice as we get back in terms of being a carrier of choice among our corporate partners. That's a line item in there that does relate to PRASM. So a little bit specific number on it, but we're getting the right momentum.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Savi. This is Jim. I think as we look out and as I mentioned fourth quarter, our expectations given expectations of demand is measured by GDP declining, we expect, obviously, that to continue. But the corporate business, although we see the demand fl
componenttext: Hey, Savi. This is Jim. I think as we look out and as I mentioned fourth quarter, our expectations given expectations of demand is measured by GDP declining, we expect, obviously, that to continue. But the corporate business, although we see the demand flat, the revenue is down on lower yield, we expect that to continue that's core related to that expectations of GDP coming down, so that's part of it that's what's driving it. So that's domestic piece of our ability putting pressure on our ability that I talked about in our April call. Internationally, we did see weakness in trans-Atlantic PRASM in the second quarter. We're adjusting to that. On our slide we, talked about fourth quarter being down 1% to 2% capacity. So we r reacting to that. Our capacity was up about 2% in the second quarter. We are guiding to 0.6 to 1.6 in the third, and we're guiding to down 1 to 2, so we're addressing some of that demand on the trans-Atlantic side aligning that capacity with demand. Latin, we actually -- that's the one where we actually see the quarter-over-quarter improvement on a RASM basis stronger than the other entities, and so we feel good about where the RASM entities heading as we head into the fourth quarter. On the Pacific side, it's really from a demand perspective a lot of things we talked about in the past with capacity. I will say, our launches of our new markets are meeting or exceeding our expectations. We're securely proud. I would jump back in trans-Atlantic on this, but our San Fran-Tel Aviv play is doing exceptionally well. But our Asia flights are all meeting and exceeding our expectations. But the demand, there's still only capacity demand. We are starting -- we have an opportunity to San Fran-Shanghai in October, so we're seeing a little bit of capacity on that, but we think that over the long run, that's the right investment for us to make.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: From JPMorgan, we have Jamie Baker online.
componenttext: From JPMorgan, we have Jamie Baker online.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, you cited that GDP expectations are coming down, but GDP is still growing yet it's revenue is declining. So in other words, that long-term relationship between GDP and revenue appears to be decoupling, okay? And now, I understand why this happened wh
componenttext: Jim, you cited that GDP expectations are coming down, but GDP is still growing yet it's revenue is declining. So in other words, that long-term relationship between GDP and revenue appears to be decoupling, okay? And now, I understand why this happened when the Internet came along. I understand why it happened briefly during the financial crisis, but I can't point to a secular cause over the last 18 months. So this leaves us with the obvious conclusion that revenue weakness has to be self-inflicted. Do you share this view? Or can you identify something secular that's causing this decoupling? Because I'm -- if you're a rental car agency, and we're talking about Uber, okay, I can kind of figure it out. I can't cite what that secular change might be.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Jamie, I think, there's that one correlation with fuel rise that that that impact of revenue. We've talked about surcharges over time and so forth being down and that correlation in terms of how fuels affected revenue. So some of that -- because I do
componenttext: Hey, Jamie, I think, there's that one correlation with fuel rise that that that impact of revenue. We've talked about surcharges over time and so forth being down and that correlation in terms of how fuels affected revenue. So some of that -- because I do agree in 2015, you're right. Industry revenue as a percent of GDP was down and inflection point from previous years. And I expect that will continue, again, today. And so other than correlation, that fuel back to the other thing we've talked about, right? We have seen capacity grow faster than demand, and that's putting pressure on yields and corporate demand is not growing at the pace, the high corp yields, corporate demand is not growing at that pace of capacity. We're pretty consistent. I mean, we're back to our initial year guidance of capacity, and we're down from that initial year guidance of capacity, and that capacity even though we're guiding today will be less than what expectations of GDP today that we're talking to. So we're managing our plan in this environment, and we feel pretty good about it. The last thing I would say is that on the June call we talked about our [indiscernible] up gauge program. We have some modest growth in the third quarter. That capacity comes really margin accretive, and so where leisure bookings are strong, that will lead capacity to absorb that leisure bookings. Lower RASM but extremely lower cost CASM. So really about the plans we're rolling out.

componenttext: Jim, a question for you. On Slide 8, you did a good job of providing just color on PRASM and some of the drivers there. But it seems like explain about half of the weakness in your unit revenues, right? I mean, just to supplement, you got 3.5 out of that 6.5 points. What are some of the other drivers? What are we missing out there?

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think yes, the other drivers are a little bit of I mentioned capacity growing PRASM demand across the industry, and that's putting pressure on yields in an environment where corporate demand is not keeping up with that pace of capacity and that higher-y
componenttext: I think yes, the other drivers are a little bit of I mentioned capacity growing PRASM demand across the industry, and that's putting pressure on yields in an environment where corporate demand is not keeping up with that pace of capacity and that higher-yielding demand that's not there capacity puts pressure on PRASM. And the other piece is that modest -- in that modest capacity growth we have, if you look at our domestic, will actually be slightly down in departures in the third quarter to drive that large capacity growth. That said, margin-accretive initiatives that we talked about in June giving a little bit more whole as we go through the year, so that little line growth and the upgauge strategy becoming less dependent on the regional and more dependent on the mainline, again, it offers us product first class and the economy plus, but it does come in RASM that's lower than the average that are even lower CASM, which make it margin-accretive. Those are really the elements that are putting pressure on RASM.

componenttext: Again, we're not -- I don't think we have. We're really focused on profitability as Oscar mentioned in his comments, and so our initiatives out there are focused on doing that. componenttext: Hey, Jim, I want to go back to -- you talked about further softening of corporate yield and I just -- I couldn't tell if what that was just continuation of what we were seeing, or is that just noticeable deterioration from where we were a few months back. And the fact -- I mean, you mentioned that demand seems to be fine and yet yields were under pressure. How much of that is a function of some of the changes to the fair structures with respect to advance purchase restrictions may be going away or Saturday night days, some of the senses getting [indiscernible] sort of it lifted away. I mean it may be that speaks to the point that Jamie brought up about the fact that we sort of seeing a breakdown here between revenue and GDP. Is it -- some of it just related to the structure out there? And maybe the prevalent of a much more liberal fare [indiscernible] in place. What's your thoughts on that?

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Mike, thanks for the question. I say pricing actions always affect PRASM, but I think it's more continuation of what the demand that we're seeing or demands relatively flat on lower yield. The one thing -- as you move into a summer peak period and yo
componenttext: Hey, Mike, thanks for the question. I say pricing actions always affect PRASM, but I think it's more continuation of what the demand that we're seeing or demands relatively flat on lower yield. The one thing -- as you move into a summer peak period and you have that leisure demand strength, it actually -- with lack of better words, props up your inventory. And so the lower inventory buckets are not as open as much. One of the things we're watching as we move past that peak period of summer season and strong leisure demand and to your point, kind the corporate demand being relatively flat, that can put relatively more pressure on yields relative to the quarter where you had peak demand strong from the June, July, August months. But to answer your question, we're kind of seeing demand where would it was at. I would note that as energy sector continues to be down year-over-year. It's decelerating at a slower rate, so that's also putting pressure on a year-over-year basis as we go forward.

componenttext: Jim, I'm wondering, where are we at with respect to, I'll call it enhanced revenue management technology getting rolled out? So the entry-level fares product, I believe United in the past have been targeting the fourth quarter. I'm just wondering if that still the case. And what does that mean for United exactly here?

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Dan, entry level, yes, we're still targeting second half of this year a lot of work going on in that area to roll that product out into the marketplace. We're very excited and what it means for United, it's going to allow us to have a price point tha
componenttext: Hey, Dan, entry level, yes, we're still targeting second half of this year a lot of work going on in that area to roll that product out into the marketplace. We're very excited and what it means for United, it's going to allow us to have a price point that allows us to compete for sure against all the low-cost carriers, it allow us to move some of the dilution that we placed on ourselves today with our current fare structure. So very excited about that. We see that rolling out in the second half of the year. And so we look forward to updating you on that. In will be significant in our earnings call, we talked about revenue initiatives of strong customer choice revenue initiatives of $2.5 billion by 2018, that's entry-level fares is a piece of that, but also pieces of that as we upgauge become less reliable on the regional carriers and introduce more first class and Economy Plus, we'll drive other component sort of the revenue that we have out there today. And then finally on revenue management as I mentioned on the call in June, we're in the process of moving to a new forecasting model that we call it Gemini. We are in the market about 2% or 3% of our overall domestic revenue is affected by it, and we're getting good results. And so that is also part of our 2018 initiatives that we talked about that rolling out and we'll  update you as we go. But we're still in the very early testing phase of it, but getting good results from it.

componenttextpreview: Well, as I mentioned, the leisure period drives learn relatively better unit revenue in the peak summer months relative to other periods of the year. It's a little early for us to get a good handle at corporate demand as we move past the Labor Day weekend
componenttext: Well, as I mentioned, the leisure period drives learn relatively better unit revenue in the peak summer months relative to other periods of the year. It's a little early for us to get a good handle at corporate demand as we move past the Labor Day weekends, so we're very much focused on it. There are things we're lapping across our systems that we talked about since how it affects unit revenue. On the corporate side, we're seeing flattish demand on lower yield, and we're seeing GDP revisions walk -- step down so we're keeping a close eye on that. Again, that's why we've adjusted capacity for capacity adjustments that we've made to the rest of the year are across the system, both international and domestic, and we'll continue to do that as we launch demand going forward.

componenttext: Slimline program is a little bit over 50% rolled out right now. In terms of profitability, it comes at a lower RASM but a lower CASM, and we have flip numbers on volumes that hasn't worked yet. As we walk through the rest of the year, we update you folks on our initiatives, you can some more detail around that going forward. We did talk about that program still lining upgauge program driving $800 million of contribution by 2018, so we have to update you where we're at as we go forward.

componenttext: It puts some pressure on CASM. We've doubled this in the past. Last year, the situation is declining capacity versus our original guidance, we managed CASM down actually. So this is all part of the process we have of always looking at opportunity to run the business more efficiently and to drive the cost-savings at the various initiatives we have. It's not one thing, it's just all those little things that add up, our ability to manage CASM even in a declining capacity environment.

componenttext: Hey, just -- and this is for Gerry just with respect to strengthening the balance sheet, when I sort of look at later this year, it looks like there's some additional cash contributions to the pension. When I think about the amount of stock that you want to buy back and your CapEx even after that piece have been financed, how should we think about your debt levels going forward? Are they going to stay sort of relatively constant, or should we anticipate meaningful debt back pay down as we sort of move into '17 and '18? How should we think about that?

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Mike, the important point is that we need to maintain a healthy balance sheet. We're there, particularly when you talk -- when you add our pension obligation. And when I talk about healthy balance sheet, it's really about managing through a cycle
componenttext: Sure. So Mike, the important point is that we need to maintain a healthy balance sheet. We're there, particularly when you talk -- when you add our pension obligation. And when I talk about healthy balance sheet, it's really about managing through a cycle, and we're very comfortable that we will continue to have access to capital through a cycle. We have about $8 billion of unencumbered assets. So I'm comfortable with where our leverage today given our business and given what we're trying to do, so we don't need to significantly introduce leverage at all. And with the additional CapEx, I expect over the next few years I said when we raised our CapEx guidance back in March with the additional aircraft [indiscernible] about 50 seats issue as well as the early retirement of 747, all of those aircraft I would expect to finance. And with sort of the range that I put out early on the call on I expect to do next year, I think if you run the arithmetic, you would not see a decline in our gross debt number over the next year or 2.
