headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to United Continental Holdings Earnings Conference Call for the Second Quarter 2016. My name is Brandon, and I'll be your conference facilitator today. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded and is copyrighted. Pleas
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to United Continental Holdings Earnings Conference Call for the Second Quarter 2016. My name is Brandon, and I'll be your conference facilitator today. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded and is copyrighted. Please note that no portion of the call may be recorded, transcribed or rebroadcast without the company's permission. Your participation implies your consent to our recording of this call. If you do not agree with these terms, simply drop off the line. 
I will now turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Jonathan Ireland, Managing Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brandon. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to United's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Yesterday, we issued our earnings release and separate investor update. Additionally, this morning, we issued a presentation to accompany t
componenttext:
Thank you, Brandon. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to United's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. 
Yesterday, we issued our earnings release and separate investor update. Additionally, this morning, we issued a presentation to accompany this call. All 3 of these documents are available on our website at ir.united.com. 
Information on yesterday's release and investor update and remarks made during this conference call may contain forward-looking statements, which represent the company's current expectations or beliefs concerning future events and financial performance. All forward-looking statements are based upon information currently available to the company. A number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from our current expectations. Please refer to our press release, Form 10-K and other reports filed with the SEC by United Continental Holdings and United Airlines for a more thorough description of these factors. 
Also, during the course of our call, we will discuss several non-GAAP financial measures. For a reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures to GAAP measures, please refer to the tables at the end of our earnings release and investor update, copies of which are available on our website. 
Unless otherwise noted, special charges are excluded as we walk you through our numbers for the quarter. These items are detailed in our earnings release. 
Joining us here in Chicago to discuss our results are President and CEO, Oscar Munoz; Vice Chairman and Chief Revenue Officer, Jim Compton; and Senior Vice President, Finance and Acting Chief Financial Officer, Gerry Laderman. We also have Chief Operations Officer and Executive Vice President, Greg Hart, in the room to assist with the Q&A. 
And now I'd like to turn the call over to Oscar.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jonathan, and thank you all for joining us today. Although, as we look at the second quarter, we certainly made significant progress, and thus, we continue to execute against our global operations better than our company has actually ever see
componenttext:
Thank you, Jonathan, and thank you all for joining us today. 
Although, as we look at the second quarter, we certainly made significant progress, and thus, we continue to execute against our global operations better than our company has actually ever seen, and at the same time, delivering solid financial performance. 
As you can see on the chart for the second quarter, we recorded a pretax profit of $1.4 billion and achieved pretax margin of 14.5%. Those are both excluding special items. 
For the quarter, we earned $2.61 in diluted earnings per share, which, once adjusted for taxes, represent a 25% increase year-over-year.  And we delivered this result while improving on our initial expectations. 
So we've clearly accomplished a lot, and I'm proud of the hard work of the United team. So let me give you a -- give me a minute to thank all of our employees for their continued dedication to providing a positive, reliable experience for our customers. This can be seen as our operations continue to perform at a high-level last quarter with on-time performance, improving over 11 points year-over-year. And on the heels of our best ever 6-month run and on-time arrivals and [indiscernible], we are now consistently performing at the level that we and our customers expect of us. Our focus has now shifted to maintaining this level of reliability while doing so more efficiently. 
We also completed an important milestone in our labor negotiations by reaching a tentative joint agreement with our flight attendants. And if ratified, this agreement will bring our 20,000-plus flight attendants onto a single contract, relieving the inefficiencies we have experienced over the last several years. And most importantly, this will be an important step in unifying our airline to one shared purpose to be the airline we know we can be. I want to extend a special thank you to the AFA for their dedication and effort in reaching this agreement. As we speak, the flight attendants are participating in roadshows and submitting their votes, and we look forward to seeing the results in mid-August. 
Speaking of our flight attendants, training is already underway with them and many of our other employees in preparation for the December launch of our new United Polaris business class. Construction has already started on the first Polaris launch in Chicago. Production has also started on our new suite-like seats, and the first wave of our chef-inspired menus are being finalized. The experience we're creating, as you know, is exactly what our customers have asked for. And we can't wait for you to enjoy it yourselves, starting on the 1st of December. 
Now back to the quarter. We also continued repurchasing our stock, spending approximately $700 million, representing a little bit over 4% of our shares outstanding. And as we announced yesterday, our Board has approved an additional authorization for $2 billion. 
As many of you have heard me say, I believe in proof not promise. As you can see this quarter, we had many proof points that we are continuing to build a great airline. However, as we mentioned on our June investor call, this is not enough. And we fully acknowledge we aren't yet performing in the financial perspective to the level of our and your expectations, and we're not standing still. As can be seen on Slide 5 on our June call, we laid out a description of initiatives we are currently implementing and are expected to drive over $3 billion of benefit by 2018. 
Now it's in our June presentation. I encourage you to go to our website and download it. 
We expect these initiatives to contribute to driving incremental value and shrinking our margin down to peers. We'll keep you updated on the cost -- progress of these issues. 
And we're not stopping there. We are currently in the middle of a thorough self-evaluation of all assets of our business. In particular, as shown on Slide 6, we are working to identify ways to operate our airline more efficiently now than top tier reliability. We are also refining the mission of each geographic region, hub and spoke. Additionally, we are implementing the profit maximizing product and segmentation strategy that best aligns with our customers. And finally, we have a cost gap to our peers that we are identifying and addressing those costs under control.  I'm looking forward to presenting this next chapter of United at our fourth quarter Investor Day. 
But before I turn over the call over to Jim, I'd like to speak to our future capacity plans. 
Let me start by saying we acknowledge, truly acknowledge the importance of returning to positive unit revenue, and of course, we recognize that our future capacity plans join the impact of future process and performance. However, we must evaluate what our network is today and the evolution to ensure that long-term optimization and sustainability of earnings is maintained. At times, this may include adding capacity to strengthen our best-performing markets and ensuring we remain competitive. However, we determined that certain flags will not generate sustained profitability. We will then carefully consider modifying that capacity. 
Proof of our result is seen in us, again, reducing full year capacity, 0.25 points. We have now reduced our 2016 capacity growth plans by 0.75 points. This is a meaningful demonstration of our responsiveness to the present demand environment, particularly given that our initial guidance had always been responsively and conservatively been constructive. 
Our review and analysis won't stop here as we continue to closely evaluate future changes. Going forward, as we adjust our capacity, we tend to update share owners on these modifications. 
So to wrap up, again, I want to thank our employees for another great quarter and their continued focus on our customers. I continue to spend a lot of time visiting stations, and I can't be more proud of the work they're all doing. 
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Jim.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Oscar. As you can see on Slide 8, our second quarter unit revenue declined 6.6%, nearly a full point better than our initial expectations, primarily due to international yields, 4th of July holiday timing and other initiatives. With respect to
componenttext:
Thanks, Oscar. 
As you can see on Slide 8, our second quarter unit revenue declined 6.6%, nearly a full point better than our initial expectations, primarily due to international yields, 4th of July holiday timing and other initiatives. 
With respect to the third quarter, we expect our passenger unit revenue to decline approximately 5.5% to 7.5% year-over-year with domestic and international PRASM to be in both same ranges. 
On Slide 8, we define each of the major headwinds we anticipate for the third quarter, summing to approximately 3.5 points of drag on PRASM. 
I'd now like to explain what we are seeing in the current demand environment. Leisure bookings have been strong as travelers are taking advantage of attractive fair levels and a strong U.S. dollar. Corporate travel bookings in the second quarter were essentially flat with revenue down approximately 3%, and corporate yields continue to be pressured. Looking towards the rest of the year, we expect to see further softening of corporate yields as summer leisure travel subsides. We will closely monitor these effects as they impact our close-in yield/high-yield revenue. 
On our April earnings call, we provided an outlook for fourth quarter PRASM, and I'd like to update you on that today. Due to downward revisions for fourth quarter GDP as well as a growing concern in the pace of corporate yield recovery, our fourth quarter estimates have been revised downward. In response, as you have seen from our announcement yesterday, we are reducing the second half capacity to better align with demand. 
On Slide 9, we show specific actions we are taking in each geographic entity. I'll let you read through the details on your own, but rest assured, we are actively managing our network to optimize results in a challenging revenue environment and are seeing the results. For instance, as a result of our capacity reallocation, Houston had the best year-over-year PRASM of any hub in June, followed closely by San Francisco and Denver. 
Taking all these regional dynamics into account with respect to capacity, as can be seen on Slide 10, we now anticipate full year capacity to grow between 1% and 1.5%. 
As Oscar mentioned, we are currently in the process of closely evaluating our capacity for the fourth quarter and 2017. 
As I wrap up, I want to reiterate our focus on maximizing profitability throughout our entire network. We are constantly evaluating the revenue and profitability landscape to ensure we have the proper plan in place. We continue to be committed to growing our capacity in line with demand, but remain willing and prepared to adjust when necessary. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Gerry.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. A summary of our financial performance can be seen on Slide 12 for GAAP financials and Slide 13 for non-GAAP financials. Excluding special items, pretax earnings were $1.4 billion, with a pretax margin of 14.5%. Importantly, our earnings
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. 
A summary of our financial performance can be seen on Slide 12 for GAAP financials and Slide 13 for non-GAAP financials. 
Excluding special items, pretax earnings were $1.4 billion, with a pretax margin of 14.5%. Importantly, our earnings per share were $2.61, a 25% improvement year-over-year when adjusted for taxes as we continue to repurchase shares. 
Moving to Slide 14. Nonfuel unit costs for the quarter were 2.5% when excluding special charges, profit sharing and third party expenses. 
For the third quarter, we expect nonfuel unit cost to grow 2.5% to 3.5%. And for the full year, we continue to expect unit cost to grow 2% to 3% despite reducing capacity by almost 1 point versus initial expectations. 
This guidance includes the benefit of our annual efficiency savings initiatives from our 2013 cost-savings program as well as our recently announced 2016 program. In total, we expect these 2 programs to drive $400 million of cost benefit when compared to 2015. This CASM guidance also includes the impact from the 3 ratified labor agreements reached this year but does not include any assumptions associated with the tentative agreement we recently reached with our flight attendants. Once ratified, we will provide more specifics on the impact to our costs. 
Based on the guidance we have provided for revenue and cost, we expect our pretax margin to be between 13.5% and 15.5% for the third quarter. 
With respect to cash, in the second quarter, we generated approximately $2.5 billion of operating cash flow and $1.8 billion of free cash flow. 
As you can see on Slide 15, during the quarter, we invested approximately $770 million in the business and took delivery of 2 Boeing 787-9 aircraft and 2 737-800 aircraft. 
As Oscar mentioned, we repurchased approximately $700 million of our shares in the quarter.  As of the end of the second quarter, we still have approximately $255 million remaining on our prior $3 billion authorization. Additionally, as announced yesterday, our Board has approved a new $2 billion share repurchase authorization. 
Returning cash to our shareholders is a core element of our capital allocation strategy. However, this will not be done at the expense of the health of our balance sheet as maintaining manageable debt levels is critical to running the airline through a variety of economic cycles. 
In conclusion, throughout the quarter, we have continued to demonstrate strong cost discipline, a commitment to invest in our business and a desire to reward our shareholders. We believe the plan we have in place positions us well to continue these actions going forward while allowing us to be nimble and responsive to a changing economic environment. 
I'll now turn it back over to Oscar.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gerry. As you've heard, we've made substantial progress in the second quarter, but we know there's more work to do. It has already been quite a busy summer, and we continue to be up for us here at United as we work to set our next chapter. I
componenttext:
Thank you, Gerry. 
As you've heard, we've made substantial progress in the second quarter, but we know there's more work to do. It has already been quite a busy summer, and we continue to be up for us here at United as we work to set our next chapter. I look forward to sharing more of you -- more of this with you later in the year. 
I'd like to close by thanking our customers supplying United. Our operations is running well. Our schedules are adapting to meet your need, and our airport and onboard products continue to elevate your flying experience. Thank you for choosing United, and we look forward to seeing you on the flights soon. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Jonathan for Q&A.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Oscar. We will now take questions from the analyst community. [Operator Instructions] Brandon, please describe the procedure to ask a question.

componenttextpreview: Darryl, this is Jim. Hey, we're not -- we're  actually working on our 2017 plans as I speak right now and a lot of focus on that, so it's too early for us to comment specifically on that. I will say that, as we talked about this year and we talked about i
componenttext: Darryl, this is Jim. Hey, we're not -- we're  actually working on our 2017 plans as I speak right now and a lot of focus on that, so it's too early for us to comment specifically on that. I will say that, as we talked about this year and we talked about in the past years, we will -- we're focused on keeping capacity in line with demand. So we're working through that process now, and we plan to update you later in the year on what we're going to do on 2017.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Stifel, we have Joseph DeNardi.
componenttext: From Stifel, we have Joseph DeNardi.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll surprise you with a non-RASM question. Gerry, if you assume that the current fuel curve and as the RASM environment continues into next year and you plug in some new labor contracts and the step-up in CapEx that it looks like you guys will have next
componenttext: I'll surprise you with a non-RASM question. Gerry, if you assume that the current fuel curve and as the RASM environment continues into next year and you plug in some new labor contracts and the step-up in CapEx that it looks like you guys will have next year, that is the potential to consume most if not all of your free cash flow next year. So first of all, can you say whether you agree with that assessment? And could you put a finer point on what CapEx looks like next year and how much flexibility you have to manage that down if the RASM environment remains challenging?

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So one thing I talked before about looking at free cash flow, net of aircraft financing. We've had this discussion whether we choose to lease aircraft or buy aircraft. That can make them sure of difference in free cash flow, so we're now looking at
componenttext: Sure. So one thing I talked before about looking at free cash flow, net of aircraft financing. We've had this discussion whether we choose to lease aircraft or buy aircraft. That can make them sure of difference in free cash flow, so we're now looking at cash and cash allocation. I do take that into account, and we tend to finalize our plan for aircraft financing closer to the start of the year. But just kind of looking at where our aircraft CapEx next year is and kind of what we did this year, I think it's reasonable to assume, have a range of about 1/2 to 2/3 of our aircraft CapEx being financed year. So you could probably plug that into your -- and this could be a little bit less, it could be a little bit more depending on interest rates. But in the current interest rate environment, as you've seen us and others do, the capital markets are quite attractive. So that's one lever we have, sort of depending on the environment, how much of our aircraft CapEx is financed. Now in terms of other levers, we can always dial down non-aircraft CapEx. We had reasonable experience doing that. Aircraft CapEx, the only comment I would make is that it tends to be the case that when a manufacturer is building an aircraft, they expect you to take it. And they tend to start cutting that, call it 18 months, 15 months ahead of schedule. So you pretty much walk in most of the years of the aircraft, sort of not now, within the next few months. So -- but you can do a lot with aircraft beyond that, and we've done that in the past when necessary.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Wolfe Research, we have Hunter Keay online.
componenttext: From Wolfe Research, we have Hunter Keay online.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Oscar, you mentioned that you're undertaking a self-evaluation of all aspects of the business, and there's some headlines heading Bloomberg that says you guys are reviewing management hubs and operations. So this is good. And this is, I think, what a l
componenttext: So Oscar, you mentioned that you're undertaking a self-evaluation of all aspects of the business, and there's some headlines heading Bloomberg that says you guys are reviewing management hubs and operations. So this is good. And this is, I think, what a lot of people have been waiting to see. So can you give us some color on this? Is this like a full scale what you would refer to as sort of like a top-to-bottom strategic review? And can you give us maybe a sense of how to think about a timeline, when you have something to say about these things? What is the potential set of outcomes? Or is this more not like a finite thing that's going to last 6 months or something more of just like an ongoing new approach to how you're thinking about running the business? Just any color around this would be great.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think with regards to duration, I think companies made the mistake of doing these near-term things and then stopping. It is a dynamic world, and you have to adjust accordingly. But you have to start with a full-blown trust, and it's amazing how quick ne
componenttext: I think with regards to duration, I think companies made the mistake of doing these near-term things and then stopping. It is a dynamic world, and you have to adjust accordingly. But you have to start with a full-blown trust, and it's amazing how quick news travels. I just issued that note this morning to our employees. It is a top-to-bottom, full cell view on everything that we do. It's something that we have to do and acknowledge, and that involves management structure. It was aligned. I've always said that structure follows strategy, and so developing in the near term what our north star is, I think, in the critical point. So we do have a finite time period that we'll work through over the summer. We have a board meeting with -- on -- in September, where we'll sort of talk a lot about this. And you'll hear about it in our fourth quarter Investor Day. So -- and then, again, it will change as the dynamics of the competitive marketplace do. But yes, we're excited. It is spanning the blow, if you will, with regards to the conversations we're having. We have more than a few work streams working around every little thing to product offerings, to the broader issues around capacity and network planning. And so I think it's exciting, so thank you for asking that.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Bank of America, we have Andrew Didora online.
componenttext: From Bank of America, we have Andrew Didora online.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Oscar, United's operating performance from both in on-time and delay perspective has been steadily improving since last fall, but there has obviously been a lot of industry headwinds that have not allowed you -- your PRASM to really show any benefit fr
componenttext: So Oscar, United's operating performance from both in on-time and delay perspective has been steadily improving since last fall, but there has obviously been a lot of industry headwinds that have not allowed you -- your PRASM to really show any benefit from this. I guess, one, what are some of the initiatives you believe have helped you get there -- get where you are operationally? And then second, do you have an estimate of what kind of the PRASM benefit that you have gotten this year from this improved performance?

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I was looking at Greg. I don't know that I have a number specifically for the PRASM impact. But with regards to your question about what's generating this, first and foremost, it's the incredible passion of the professionals that run our business. The
componenttext: No. I was looking at Greg. I don't know that I have a number specifically for the PRASM impact. But with regards to your question about what's generating this, first and foremost, it's the incredible passion of the professionals that run our business. They have reengaged in a way that we haven't seen in a long time, and that's just not me talking. You can ask a lot of folks that are seeing that benefit. They are just working hard, and they're engaged. And I think that's a big critical factor. In addition, over time, between Project Quality a lot of the process and procedures, investments that we've made in the business, which are substantial are all assisting those folks, giving them the tools to properly do their job. And the benefits -- again, it's a good question, and we should come up with a more quantitative answer. It is a significant value, I say running -- [indiscernible] better is running cheaper. And as you know, we are seeing that, and we'll get you a better number here over the course of time.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, if I could add just from a customer perspective what we're hearing in the marketplace, as Oscar said, the level of operations is really, really strong. And its -- and the operations team has proven it sustainable and durable. We're hearing that ba
componenttext: Andrew, if I could add just from a customer perspective what we're hearing in the marketplace, as Oscar said, the level of operations is really, really strong. And its -- and the operations team has proven it sustainable and durable. We're hearing that back from our customers. Our corporate sales force -- our team basis is very excited about, for instance, going in and bringing in the scorecard of our corporate guarantee.  And year-to-date, 6-plus months into it, we're not paying on it, which means we're meeting our commitment on terms of our operation. So that -- it's -- as Oscar said, it's hard to put a PRASM on it. Those are the things that will lead to PRASM. We're seeing our local share in our hubs rebounding back to levels that we saw before some of our integration issues, and so we're really, really excited about it. And lastly, on our call in June, we talked about $300 million of operational efficiency as well as some of the -- what I call choice as we get back in terms of being a carrier of choice among our corporate partners. That's a line item in there that does relate to PRASM. So as Oscar said, a little bit to really put a specific number on it, but we're getting the right momentum.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: As we said to the head of the sales force, Jim and I, the notion that we can't sell anymore because we don't have a particularly good product, and excuse is no longer on the table, pushed it all away.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: From Raymond James, we have Savi Syth online.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the update on your thinking on the fourth quarter. Just wondering if you could provide a little bit more granularity as to which areas and maybe segments, international segments, are -- where you're feeling a little bit more concerned about and
componenttext: Thanks for the update on your thinking on the fourth quarter. Just wondering if you could provide a little bit more granularity as to which areas and maybe segments, international segments, are -- where you're feeling a little bit more concerned about and what you're thinking as on the -- kind of the progression here as you head into the end of the year.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Savi, this is Jim. I think as we look out and as I mentioned the fourth quarter, our expectations given -- expectations of demand is measured by GDP declining, we expect, obviously, that to continue. The corporate business, although we see the demand flat
componenttext: Savi, this is Jim. I think as we look out and as I mentioned the fourth quarter, our expectations given -- expectations of demand is measured by GDP declining, we expect, obviously, that to continue. The corporate business, although we see the demand flat, the revenue is down on lower yield, we expect that to continue. That's correlated to the expectations of GDP coming down so that's -- a part of it was driving it. So that's domestic piece of our ability, putting pressure on our ability that I talked about on our April call. Internationally, we did see weakness in trans-Atlantic PRASM in the second quarter. We're adjusting to that. And found on our slide, we talked about the fourth quarter being down 1% to 2% of capacity. So we're reacting to that. Our capacity was up about 2% in the second quarter. We're guiding to 0.6% to 1.6% in the third, and we're guiding to down 1% to 2%. So we're addressing some of that demand on the trans-Atlantic side, aligning in that capacity with demand. Latin, we actually -- that's the one where we actually see the quarter-over-quarter improvement on a RASM basis stronger than some of the other entities, and so we feel good about where the Latin entity is heading as we head into the fourth quarter. On the Pacific side, it's really from a demand perspective, a lot of the things we talked about in the past was OA capacity. I will say, our launches of our new markets are meeting or exceeding our expectations. We're particularly proud. I would jump back to the trans-Atlantic on this. But our San Fran-Tel Aviv play is doing exceptionally well. But our Asia flights are all meeting and exceeding our expectations. So -- but the demand, there is still OA capacity demand. We are starting -- we have an opportunity to start San Fran-Shanghai #2 in October, so we're seeing a little bit of capacity from on that. But we think that over the long run, that's the right investment for us to make.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: From JPMorgan, we have Jamie Baker online.
componenttext: From JPMorgan, we have Jamie Baker online.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, you cited that GDP expectations are coming down, but GDP is still growing, yet it's revenue that's declining. So in other words, that long-term relationship between GDP and revenue appears to be decoupling, okay? Now I understand why this happened wh
componenttext: Jim, you cited that GDP expectations are coming down, but GDP is still growing, yet it's revenue that's declining. So in other words, that long-term relationship between GDP and revenue appears to be decoupling, okay? Now I understand why this happened when the Internet came along. I understand why it happened briefly during the financial crisis, but I can't point to a secular cause over the last 18 months. So this leaves us with the obvious conclusion that revenue weakness has to be self-inflicted. Do you share this view? Or can you identify something secular that's causing this decoupling? Because I'm -- if you're a rental car agency, and we're talking about Uber, okay, I could kind of figure it out. I can't cite what that secular change might be.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, I think, there's that one correlation with fuel rise that have that impact on revenue. We talked about surcharges over time and so forth being down and the -- and that correlation in terms of how fuels affected revenue. So some of that -- because I
componenttext: Jamie, I think, there's that one correlation with fuel rise that have that impact on revenue. We talked about surcharges over time and so forth being down and the -- and that correlation in terms of how fuels affected revenue. So some of that -- because I do agree in 2015, you're right. Industry revenue as a percent of GDP was down, and it was in an inflection point from previous years. And I expect that will continue again today. And so other than that correlation, the fuel, back to the other thing we've talked about, right, we have seen capacity grow faster than demand. And that's putting pressure on yields, and corporate demand is not growing at the pace. The high corp yields, corporate demand is not growing at that pace of capacity. We're pretty consistent. I mean, you go back to our initial year guidance on capacity, and we're down from that initial year guidance on capacity. And that capacity, even though we're guiding today, will be less than what expectations of GDP today that we're talking to. So we're managing our plan in this environment, and we feel pretty good about it. The last thing I would say is that on the June call, we talked about our slimline and upgauge program. We have some modest growth in the third quarter. That capacity becomes really margin accretive. And so where leisure bookings are strong, that's a good capacity to absorb that leisure bookings. Lower RASM, but an extremely lower-cost CASM. So we really feel good about the plan we're rolling out.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, this is Oscar. Jamie?
componenttext: Jamie, this is Oscar. Jamie?

componenttext: You get one question, you got to put your back in line. I just want mine [indiscernible]. You initially -- by the way, it's a very thoughtful question, as all of them are. But the concept of this self-inflicted portion, I think, is a very interesting one. And somebody had asked earlier about the work that we're doing here over the summer. We have to explore that a little bit to make sure that we're not just following historical, conventional wisdom all the time. Because again, as I said, it's a dynamic marketplace, and we have to find either the secular impacts or things that we can generate or do better. So thanks. We'll go to the next caller.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, a question for you. On Slide 8, you did a good job of providing just color on PRASM and some of the drivers there. But it seems that only explained about half of the weakness in your unit revenues, right? I mean, just a simple math, you got 3.5 out o
componenttext: Jim, a question for you. On Slide 8, you did a good job of providing just color on PRASM and some of the drivers there. But it seems that only explained about half of the weakness in your unit revenues, right? I mean, just a simple math, you got 3.5 out of that 6.5 points. What are some of the other drivers? What are we missing out there?

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the other drivers are a little bit of -- I just mentioned, the capacity is growing faster than the demand across the industry, and that's putting pressure on yields in an environment where corporate demand is not keeping up with that pace of capac
componenttext: I think the other drivers are a little bit of -- I just mentioned, the capacity is growing faster than the demand across the industry, and that's putting pressure on yields in an environment where corporate demand is not keeping up with that pace of capacity. And that higher-yielding demand that's not there at that greater capacity puts pressure on PRASM. And the other piece is that modest -- in that modest capacity growth we have, if you look at our domestic, we'll actually be slightly down in departures in the third quarter to drive that modest capacity growth. That said, margin-accretive initiatives that we talked about in June, giving a little bit more hold as we go through the year, so that slimline growth and the upgauge strategy becoming less dependent on the regional and more dependent on the mainline. Again, it offers us some great product called first class and the Economy Plus. But it does come in a RASM that's lower than the average that are even lower CASM, which makes it margin-accretive. Those are really the elements that are putting pressure on RASM.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: From Crdit Suisse, we have Julie Yates online.

componenttextpreview: We're -- again, we're not -- I'm not -- I don't think it had -- we're really focused on profitability, as Oscar mentioned in his comment, and so our initiatives out there are focused on doing that. As we lay out that game plan, we're focused on optimizing
componenttext: We're -- again, we're not -- I'm not -- I don't think it had -- we're really focused on profitability, as Oscar mentioned in his comment, and so our initiatives out there are focused on doing that. As we lay out that game plan, we're focused on optimizing RASM every day and that -- and the importance of RASM. And so as we move through the rest of this quarter into the fourth quarter, we'll be able to give a little bit more insight and kind of continue to update you on where we think PRASM is and ultimately where that lands relative to positive RASM growth.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Deutsche Bank, we have Mike Linenberg.
componenttext: From Deutsche Bank, we have Mike Linenberg.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, I want to go back to -- you talked about further softening of corporate yield, and I just -- I couldn't tell if that was just a continuation of what we were seeing or is it just noticeable deterioration from where we were a few months back. And the f
componenttext: Jim, I want to go back to -- you talked about further softening of corporate yield, and I just -- I couldn't tell if that was just a continuation of what we were seeing or is it just noticeable deterioration from where we were a few months back. And the fact as you -- I mean, you mentioned that demand seems to be fine and yet yields were under pressure, how much of that is a function of some of the changes to the fair structures with respect to advanced purchase restrictions may be going away or Saturday nights/days, some of the expenses getting lifted off or sort of lifted away? I mean, and maybe that speaks to the point that Jamie brought up about the fact that we're sort of seeing a breakdown here between revenue and GDP. Is it -- some of it's related to just the structure out there and maybe the prevalent of a much more liberal fare regime in place. What's -- thoughts on that?

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, thanks for the question. I think pricing actions always affect PRASM, but I think it's more of a continuation of the -- what the demand that we're seeing or demands relatively flat on lower yield. The one thing -- as you move into a summer peak peri
componenttext: Mike, thanks for the question. I think pricing actions always affect PRASM, but I think it's more of a continuation of the -- what the demand that we're seeing or demands relatively flat on lower yield. The one thing -- as you move into a summer peak period and you have that leisure demand strength, it actually, with lack of better words, props up your inventory. And so your lower inventory buckets are not as open as much. One of the things we're watching as we move past that peak period of summer season and strong leisure demand, and to your point, kind the corporate demand being relatively flat, that can put more -- that can put relatively more pressure on yields relative to the quarter where you had peak demand strong from the June, July, August months. But to answer your question, we're kind of seeing demand where it was at. I would note that as energy sector continues to be down year-over-year, it's decelerating at a slower rate so that's also putting pressure on us on a year-over-year basis as we go forward.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: From Cowen and Company, we have Helane Becker online.

componenttext: It's a great question and one that we are in the process of developing what that specific public measure that we're going to be driving to and obviously keeping you updated on. They all had merit. We're going to pursue all of them, and certainly, it's more profitable. It's margin improvement. It's closing the margin gap to others and what are the main drivers. It's a great question, but we will certainly, definitely tell you at our fourth quarter investor day. That will be the culminating part of our conversation, I suspect.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: From Buckingham Research, we have Dan McKenzie.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, I'm wondering, where are we at with respect to -- I'll call it enhanced revenue management technology getting rolled out, so the entry-level fares product? I believe United in the past had been targeting the fourth quarter. I'm just wondering if that
componenttext: Jim, I'm wondering, where are we at with respect to -- I'll call it enhanced revenue management technology getting rolled out, so the entry-level fares product? I believe United in the past had been targeting the fourth quarter. I'm just wondering if that's still the case. And what does it mean for United exactly here?

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, on entry-level fares, yes, we're still targeting second half of this year, and a lot of work going on in that area to roll that product out into the marketplace. We're very excited. And when you ask what it means for United, it's going to allow us to
componenttext: Dan, on entry-level fares, yes, we're still targeting second half of this year, and a lot of work going on in that area to roll that product out into the marketplace. We're very excited. And when you ask what it means for United, it's going to allow us to have a price point that allows us to compete for sure against ultra low-cost carriers and allow us to move some of the dilution that we placed on ourselves today with our current fare structure. So we're very excited about that. We see that rolling out in the second half of the year, and so we look forward to updating you on that. It will be significant in our earnings call. We talked about revenue initiatives of -- strong customer choice revenue initiatives of $2.5 billion by 2018. That entry-level fares is a piece of that, but also pieces of that as we upgauge and become less reliable on the regional carriers and introduce more first class and Economy Plus. We'll drive other components of that sort of revenue that we have out there today. And then finally on revenue management, as I mentioned in -- on the call in June, we're in the process of moving to a new forecasting model that we call it Gemini. We are in the market. About 2% or 3% of our overall domestic revenue is affected by it, and we're getting good results. And so that in the -- that is also part of our 2018 initiatives that we talked about, that rolling out. And we'll update you as we go, but we're still in the very early testing phases of it but getting good results from it.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Could I get a second since I didn't get a bite on that? Jim, did you -- do you feel better about year-over-year unit revenue improvement during a peak leisure demand period or during a pure corporate demand period like September?

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as I mentioned, it's -- the leisure period drives relatively better unit revenue in the peak summer months relative to other periods of the year. It's a little early for us to get a good handle on corporate demand as we move past the Labor Day weeke
componenttext: Well, as I mentioned, it's -- the leisure period drives relatively better unit revenue in the peak summer months relative to other periods of the year. It's a little early for us to get a good handle on corporate demand as we move past the Labor Day weekends, so we're very much focused on it. There are things we're lapping across our systems that we talked about in terms of how it affects unit revenue. On the corporate side, we're seeing flattish demand on lower yield. And our -- we're seeing GDP revisions walk -- step down, and so we're keeping a close eye on that. Again, that's why we've adjusted capacity. Our capacity adjustments that we've made to the rest of the year are across the system, both international and domestic, and we'll continue to do that as we launch demand going forward.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: As it relates to the slimline seats, could you give us an update on how much of your domestic network has already been outfitted  with these slimline seats? And is there a way to sort of summarize the impact that could have in terms of profitability on a seat mile basis?

componenttext: Slimline program is a little bit over 50% rolled out right now. On our June call, we talked about it being 50%, so we're beyond that as we're into July now. So it's a little bit 50%-plus on the whole network, and so that program has to have flight [ph] point on the slimline side. In terms of profitability, it comes at a lower RASM but a lower CASM, and we have [indiscernible] numbers of volumes but [indiscernible] worked yet. As we walk get -- as we walk through the rest of the year, we update you folks on our initiatives, and you can put some more around that going forward. We did talk about that program, slimline and upgauge program, driving $800 million of contribution by 2018, so we'll be able to update you where we're at as we go forward.

componenttext: Gerry, just on the CASM outlook for the year. You took 50 bps or 25 bps, I guess, out of the full year capacity guidance. How much pressure did that put on CASM? Is the FX environment helping the CASM outlook now? I think there's -- if you could just help us understand the relationship between kind of capacity reductions and how much pressure that puts on CASM.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It puts some pressure on CASM. We've doubled this in the past. Last year, in the situation of declining capacity versus our original guidance, we managed CASM down, actually. So this is all part of the process we have of always looking at opportunity to r
componenttext: It puts some pressure on CASM. We've doubled this in the past. Last year, in the situation of declining capacity versus our original guidance, we managed CASM down, actually. So this is all part of the process we have of always looking at opportunity to run the business more efficiently and to drive the cost savings through the various initiatives we have. It's not one thing, it's just all those little things that add up, our ability to manage CASM even in a declining capacity environment.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: From Wolfe Research, we have Hunter Keay online.

componenttext: So Jim, you said that corporate bookings are about flat with revenues down about 3%. Is it fair to assume that, that entire gap is driven by the concept that you referred to in the past as dilution? And is it fair to assume that the main thrust -- or one of the main thrust of Gemini is to minimize dilution? And in that regard with -- as it relates to the small market that you rolled it out and you said you're seeing good results, is that effectively minimizing dilution or is it good results from other stuff that maybe we're not appreciating or that we know about?

There's limits to capacity growth based on the bilateral that's agreed between China and the U.S. government, and those bilaterals are almost to the point where they're -- they have been met. So that will have a natural kind of slowdown in capacity growth from the main U.S. to China. But I wouldn't want to comment on other industry capacity or other regions of the world.

componenttext: Just -- and this is to Gerry just with respect to strengthening the balance sheet. When I sort of look at later this year, it looks like there's some additional cash contributions to the pension. And when I think about the amount of stock that you want to buy back and your CapEx even after the piece has been financed, how should we think about your debt levels going forward? Are they going to stay sort of relatively constant? Or should we anticipate meaningful debt pay down as we sort of move into '17 and '18? How should we think about that?

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Mike, the important point is that we need to maintain a healthy balance sheet. We're there, particularly when you talk -- when you add our pension obligation. And when I talk about healthy balance sheet, it's really about managing through a cycle
componenttext: Sure. So Mike, the important point is that we need to maintain a healthy balance sheet. We're there, particularly when you talk -- when you add our pension obligation. And when I talk about healthy balance sheet, it's really about managing through a cycle, and we're very comfortable that we would continue to have access to capital through a cycle. We have about $8 billion of unencumbered assets. So I'm comfortable with where our leverage is today given our business and given what we're trying to do, so we don't need to significantly introduce leverage at all. And with the additional CapEx, I expect over the next few years, I said when we raised our CapEx guidance back in March with the additional aircraft, we saw about 50 seats issue as well as the early retirement of 747, all of those aircraft I would expect to finance. And with sort of the range I put out earlier on the call on what I expect to do next year, I think if you run the arithmetic, you would not see a decline in our gross debt number over the next year or 2.

componenttext: Dan, it's Jim. The international upgauging is a really, really small piece, and it's driven mainly by the 767-300 conversions of 2 class, the best driving a little bit of that upgauging. It's a really, really small piece of the upgauging that we talked about on our $3.1 billion initiative. In addition, as you think about 2018 when the A350s come, we'll definitely -- it will be a part of the international upgauging. But again, it's all a very small piece.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to United Continental Holdings Earnings Conference Call for the Second Quarter 2016. My name is Brandon, and I'll be your conference facilitator today. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded and is copyrighted. Pleas
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to United Continental Holdings Earnings Conference Call for the Second Quarter 2016. My name is Brandon, and I'll be your conference facilitator today. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded and is copyrighted. Please note that no portion of the call may be recorded, transcribed or rebroadcast without the company's permission. Your participation implies your consent to our recording of this call. If you do not agree with these terms, simply drop off the line. 
I will now turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Jonathan Ireland, Managing Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brandon. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to United's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Yesterday, we issued our earnings release and separate investor update. Additionally, this morning, we issued a presentation to accompany t
componenttext:
Thank you, Brandon. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to United's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. 
Yesterday, we issued our earnings release and separate investor update. Additionally, this morning, we issued a presentation to accompany this call. All 3 of these documents are available on our website at ir.united.com. 
Information on yesterday's release and investor update and remarks made during this conference call may contain forward-looking statements, which represent the company's current expectations or beliefs concerning future events and financial performance. All forward-looking statements are based upon information currently available to the company. A number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from our current expectations. Please refer to our press release, Form 10-K and other reports filed with the SEC by United Continental Holdings and United Airlines for a more thorough description of these factors. 
Also, during the course of our call, we will discuss several non-GAAP financial measures. For a reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures to GAAP measures, please refer to the tables at the end of our earnings release and investor update, copies of which are available on our website. 
Unless otherwise noted, special charges are excluded as we walk you through our numbers for the quarter. These items are detailed in our earnings release. 
Joining us here in Chicago to discuss our results are President and CEO, Oscar Munoz; Vice Chairman and Chief Revenue Officer, Jim Compton; and Senior Vice President, Finance and Acting Chief Financial Officer, Gerry Laderman. We also have Chief Operations Officer and Executive Vice President, Greg Hart, in the room to assist with the Q&A. 
And now I'd like to turn the call over to Oscar.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jonathan, and thank you all for joining us today. Although, as we look at the second quarter, we certainly made significant progress, and thus, we continue to execute against our global operations better than our company has actually ever see
componenttext:
Thank you, Jonathan, and thank you all for joining us today. 
Although, as we look at the second quarter, we certainly made significant progress, and thus, we continue to execute against our global operations better than our company has actually ever seen, and at the same time, delivering solid financial performance. 
As you can see on the chart for the second quarter, we recorded a pretax profit of $1.4 billion and achieved pretax margin of 14.5%. Those are both excluding special items. 
For the quarter, we earned $2.61 in diluted earnings per share, which, once adjusted for taxes, represent a 25% increase year-over-year.  And we delivered this result while improving on our initial expectations. 
So we've clearly accomplished a lot, and I'm proud of the hard work of the United team. So let me give you a -- give me a minute to thank all of our employees for their continued dedication to providing a positive, reliable experience for our customers. This can be seen as our operations continue to perform at a high-level last quarter with on-time performance, improving over 11 points year-over-year. And on the heels of our best ever 6-month run of on-time arrivals and [indiscernible], we are now consistently performing at the level that we and our customers expect of us. Our focus has now shifted to maintaining this level of reliability while doing so more efficiently. 
We also completed an important milestone in our labor negotiations by reaching a tentative joint agreement with our flight attendants. And if ratified, this agreement will bring our 20,000-plus flight attendants onto a single contract, relieving the inefficiencies we have experienced over the last several years. And most importantly, this will be an important step in unifying our airline to one shared purpose to be the airline we know we can be. I want to extend a special thank you to the AFA for their dedication and effort in reaching this agreement. As we speak, the flight attendants are participating in roadshows and submitting their votes, and we look forward to seeing the results in mid-August. 
Speaking of our flight attendants, training is already underway with them and many of our other employees in preparation for the December launch of our new United Polaris business class. Construction has already started on the first Polaris launch in Chicago. Production has also started on our new suite-like seats, and the first wave of our chef-inspired menus are being finalized. The experience we're creating, as you know, is exactly what our customers have asked for. And we can't wait for you to enjoy it yourselves, starting on the 1st of December. 
Now back to the quarter. We also continued repurchasing our stock, spending approximately $700 million, representing a little bit over 4% of our shares outstanding. And as we announced yesterday, our Board has approved an additional authorization for $2 billion. 
As many of you have heard me say, I believe in proof not promise. As you can see this quarter, we had many proof points that we are continuing to build a great airline. However, as we mentioned on our June investor call, this is not enough. And we fully acknowledge we aren't yet performing in the financial perspective to the level of our and your expectations, and we're not standing still. As can be seen on Slide 5 on our June call, we laid out a description of initiatives we are currently implementing and are expected to drive over $3 billion of benefit by 2018. 
Now to see our June presentation, I encourage you to go to our website and download it. 
We expect these initiatives to contribute to driving incremental value and shrinking our margin down to peers. We'll keep you updated on the cost -- progress of these issues. 
And we're not stopping there. We are currently in the middle of a thorough self-evaluation of all assets of our business. In particular, as shown on Slide 6, we are working to identify ways to operate our airline more efficiently now than top tier reliability. We are also refining the mission of each geographic region, hub and spoke. Additionally, we are implementing the profit maximizing product and segmentation strategy that best aligns with our customers. And finally, we have a cost gap to our peers that we are identifying and addressing those costs under control.  I'm looking forward to presenting this next chapter of United at our fourth quarter Investor Day. 
But before I turn over the call over to Jim, I'd like to speak to our future capacity plans. 
Let me start by saying we acknowledge, truly acknowledge the importance of returning to positive unit revenue, and of course, we recognize that our future capacity plans directly impact of future process and performance. However, we must evaluate what our network is today and the evolution to ensure that long-term optimization and sustainability of earnings is maintained. At times, this may include adding capacity to strengthen our best-performing markets and ensuring we remain competitive. However, if we determine that certain flags will not generate sustained profitability. We will then carefully consider modifying that capacity. 
Proof of our resolve is seen in us, again, reducing full year capacity, 0.25 points. We have now reduced our 2016 capacity growth plans by 0.75 points. This is a meaningful demonstration of our responsiveness to the present demand environment, particularly given that our initial guidance had always been responsibly and conservatively been constructed. 
Our review and analysis won't stop here as we continue to closely evaluate future changes. Going forward, as we adjust our capacity, we tend to update share owners on these modifications. 
So to wrap up, again, I want to thank our employees for another great quarter and their continued focus on our customers. I continue to spend a lot of time visiting stations, and I can't be more proud of the work they're all doing. 
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Jim.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Oscar. As you can see on Slide 8, our second quarter unit revenue declined 6.6%, nearly a full point better than our initial expectations, primarily due to international yields, 4th of July holiday timing and other initiatives. With respect to
componenttext:
Thanks, Oscar. 
As you can see on Slide 8, our second quarter unit revenue declined 6.6%, nearly a full point better than our initial expectations, primarily due to international yields, 4th of July holiday timing and other initiatives. 
With respect to the third quarter, we expect our passenger unit revenue to decline approximately 5.5% to 7.5% year-over-year with domestic and international PRASM to be in both same ranges. 
On Slide 8, we define each of the major headwinds we anticipate for the third quarter, summing to approximately 3.5 points of drag on PRASM. 
I'd now like to explain what we are seeing in the current demand environment. Leisure bookings have been strong as travelers are taking advantage of attractive fair levels and a strong U.S. dollar. Corporate travel bookings in the second quarter were essentially flat with revenue down approximately 3%, and corporate yields continue to be pressured. Looking towards the rest of the year, we expect to see further softening of corporate yields as summer leisure travel subsides. We will closely monitor these effects as they impact our close-in yield/high-yield revenue. 
On our April earnings call, we provided an outlook for fourth quarter PRASM, and I'd like to update you on that today. Due to downward revisions for fourth quarter GDP as well as a growing concern in the pace of corporate yield recovery, our fourth quarter estimates have been revised downward. In response, as you have seen from our announcement yesterday, we are reducing the second half capacity to better align with demand. 
On Slide 9, we show specific actions we are taking in each geographic entity. I'll let you read through the details on your own, but rest assured, we are actively managing our network to optimize results in a challenging revenue environment and are seeing the results. For instance, as a result of our capacity reallocation, Houston had the best year-over-year PRASM of any hub in June, followed closely by San Francisco and Denver. 
Taking all these regional dynamics into account with respect to capacity, as can be seen on Slide 10, we now anticipate full year capacity to grow between 1% and 1.5%. 
As Oscar mentioned, we are currently in the process of closely evaluating our capacity for the fourth quarter and 2017. 
As I wrap up, I want to reiterate our focus on maximizing profitability throughout our entire network. We are constantly evaluating the revenue and profitability landscape to ensure we have the proper plan in place. We continue to be committed to growing our capacity in line with demand, but remain willing and prepared to adjust when necessary. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Gerry.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. A summary of our financial performance can be seen on Slide 12 for GAAP financials and Slide 13 for non-GAAP financials. Excluding special items, pretax earnings were $1.4 billion, with a pretax margin of 14.5%. Importantly, our earnings
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. 
A summary of our financial performance can be seen on Slide 12 for GAAP financials and Slide 13 for non-GAAP financials. 
Excluding special items, pretax earnings were $1.4 billion, with a pretax margin of 14.5%. Importantly, our earnings per share were $2.61, a 25% improvement year-over-year when adjusted for taxes as we continue to repurchase shares. 
Moving to Slide 14. Nonfuel unit costs for the quarter were 2.5% when excluding special charges, profit sharing and third party expenses. 
For the third quarter, we expect nonfuel unit cost to grow 2.5% to 3.5%. And for the full year, we continue to expect unit cost to grow 2% to 3% despite reducing capacity by almost 1 point versus initial expectations. 
This guidance includes the benefit of our annual efficiency savings initiatives from our 2013 cost-savings program as well as our recently announced 2016 program. In total, we expect these 2 programs to drive $400 million of cost benefit when compared to 2015. This CASM guidance also includes the impact from the 3 ratified labor agreements reached this year but does not include any assumptions associated with the tentative agreement we recently reached with our flight attendants. Once ratified, we will provide more specifics on the impact to our costs. 
Based on the guidance we have provided for revenue and costs, we expect our pretax margin to be between 13.5% and 15.5% for the third quarter. 
With respect to cash, in the second quarter, we generated approximately $2.5 billion of operating cash flow and $1.8 billion of free cash flow. 
As you can see on Slide 15, during the quarter, we invested approximately $770 million in the business and took delivery of 2 Boeing 787-9 aircraft and 2 737-800 aircraft. 
As Oscar mentioned, we repurchased approximately $700 million of our shares in the quarter.  As of the end of the second quarter, we still have approximately $255 million remaining on our prior $3 billion authorization. Additionally, as announced yesterday, our Board has approved a new $2 billion share repurchase authorization. 
Returning cash to our shareholders is a core element of our capital allocation strategy. However, this will not be done at the expense of the health of our balance sheet as maintaining manageable debt levels is critical to running the airline through a variety of economic cycles. 
In conclusion, throughout the quarter, we have continued to demonstrate strong cost discipline, a commitment to invest in our business and a desire to reward our shareholders. We believe the plan we have in place positions us well to continue these actions going forward while allowing us to be nimble and responsive to a changing economic environment. 
I'll now turn it back over to Oscar.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gerry. As you've heard, we've made substantial progress in the second quarter, but we know there's more work to do. It has already been quite a busy summer, and we continue to be up for us here at United as we work to set our next chapter. I
componenttext:
Thank you, Gerry. 
As you've heard, we've made substantial progress in the second quarter, but we know there's more work to do. It has already been quite a busy summer, and we continue to be up for us here at United as we work to set our next chapter. I look forward to sharing more of you -- more of this with you later in the year. 
I'd like to close by thanking our customers supplying United. Our operations is running well. Our schedules are adapting to meet your need, and our airport and onboard products continue to elevate your flying experience. Thank you for choosing United, and we look forward to seeing you on the flights soon. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Jonathan for Q&A.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttextpreview: Darryl, this is Jim. Hey, we're not -- we're  actually working on our 2017 plans as I speak right now and a lot of focus on that, so it's too early for us to comment specifically on that. I will say that, as we talked about this year and we talked about i
componenttext: Darryl, this is Jim. Hey, we're not -- we're  actually working on our 2017 plans as I speak right now and a lot of focus on that, so it's too early for us to comment specifically on that. I will say that, as we talked about this year and we talked about in the past years, we will -- we're focused on keeping capacity in line with demand. So we're working through that process now, and we plan to update you later in the year on what we're going to do on 2017.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Stifel, we have Joseph DeNardi.
componenttext: From Stifel, we have Joseph DeNardi.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll surprise you with a non-RASM question. Gerry, if you assume that the current fuel curve and as the RASM environment continues into next year and you plug in some new labor contracts and the step-up in CapEx that it looks like you guys will have next
componenttext: I'll surprise you with a non-RASM question. Gerry, if you assume that the current fuel curve and as the RASM environment continues into next year and you plug in some new labor contracts and the step-up in CapEx that it looks like you guys will have next year, that is the potential to consume most if not all of your free cash flow next year. So first of all, can you say whether you agree with that assessment? And could you put a finer point on what CapEx looks like next year and how much flexibility you have to manage that down if the RASM environment remains challenging?

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So one thing I talked before about looking at free cash flow, net of aircraft financing. We've had this discussion whether we choose to lease aircraft or buy aircraft. That can make a material difference in free cash flow, so when I'm looking at cas
componenttext: Sure. So one thing I talked before about looking at free cash flow, net of aircraft financing. We've had this discussion whether we choose to lease aircraft or buy aircraft. That can make a material difference in free cash flow, so when I'm looking at cash and cash allocation. I do take that into account, and we tend to finalize our plans for aircraft financing closer to the start of the year. But just kind of looking at where our aircraft CapEx next year is and kind of what we did this year, I think it's reasonable to assume, kind of a range of about 1/2 to 2/3 of our aircraft CapEx being financed year. So you could probably plug that into your -- and this could be a little bit less, it could be a little bit more depending on interest rates. But in the current interest rate environment, as you've seen us and others do, the capital markets are quite attractive. So that's one lever we have, sort of depending on the environment, how much of our aircraft CapEx is financed. Now in terms of other levers, we can always dial down non-aircraft CapEx. We had reasonable experience doing that. Aircraft CapEx, the only comment I would make is that it tends to be the case that when a manufacturer is building an aircraft, they expect you to take it. And they tend to start cutting that, call it 18 months, 15 months ahead of schedule. So you pretty much lock in most of the years of the aircraft, sort of, if not now, within the next few months. So -- but you can do a lot with aircraft beyond that, and we've done that in the past when necessary.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
