componenttext: Oscar, as we look ahead to your business over the next, say, 2 to 5 years and during this time period of the revenue improvement that you outlined last month, is there an earnings per share target we should be thinking about that you're thinking about managing to? Or should we not be looking at it as an EPS target? Should we be looking at it as an operating margin target?

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a great question and one that we are in the process of developing what that specific public measure that we're going to be driving to and obviously keeping you updated on. They all have merit. We're going to pursue all of them, and certainly, it's mo
componenttext: It's a great question and one that we are in the process of developing what that specific public measure that we're going to be driving to and obviously keeping you updated on. They all have merit. We're going to pursue all of them, and certainly, it's more profitable. It's margin improvement. It's closing the margin gap to others and what are the main drivers. It's a great question, but we will certainly, definitely tell you at our fourth quarter investor day. That will be the culminating part of our conversation, I suspect.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Buckingham Research, we have Dan McKenzie.
componenttext: From Buckingham Research, we have Dan McKenzie.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, I'm wondering, where are we at with respect to -- I'll call it enhanced revenue management technology getting rolled out, so the entry-level fares product? I believe United in the past had been targeting the fourth quarter. I'm just wondering if that
componenttext: Jim, I'm wondering, where are we at with respect to -- I'll call it enhanced revenue management technology getting rolled out, so the entry-level fares product? I believe United in the past had been targeting the fourth quarter. I'm just wondering if that's still the case. And what does it mean for United exactly here?

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, on entry-level fares, yes, we're still targeting second half of this year, and a lot of work going on in that area to roll that product out into the marketplace. We're very excited. And when you ask what it means for United, it's going to allow us to
componenttext: Dan, on entry-level fares, yes, we're still targeting second half of this year, and a lot of work going on in that area to roll that product out into the marketplace. We're very excited. And when you ask what it means for United, it's going to allow us to have a price point that allows us to compete for sure against ultra low-cost carriers and allow us to remove some of the dilution that we placed on ourselves today with our current fare structure. So we're very excited about that. We see that rolling out in the second half of the year, and so we look forward to updating you on that. It will be significant in our earnings call. We talked about revenue initiatives of -- strong customer choice revenue initiatives of $2.5 billion by 2018. That entry-level fares is a piece of that, but also pieces of that as we upgauge and become less reliable on the regional carriers and introduce more first class and Economy Plus will drive other components of that sort of revenue that we have out there today. And then finally on revenue management, as I mentioned in -- on the call in June, we're in the process of moving to a new forecasting model that we call it Gemini. We are in the market. About 2% or 3% of our overall domestic revenue is affected by it, and we're getting good results. And so that in the -- that is also part of our 2018 initiatives that we talked about, that rolling out. And we'll update you as we go, but we're still in the very early testing phases of it but getting good results from it.

componenttext: Okay. Could I get a second since I didn't get a bite on that? Jim, did you -- do you feel better about year-over-year unit revenue improvement during a peak leisure demand period or during a pure corporate demand period like September?

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as I mentioned, it's -- the leisure period drives relatively better unit revenue in the peak summer months relative to other periods of the year. It's a little early for us to get a good handle on corporate demand as we move past the Labor Day weeke
componenttext: Well, as I mentioned, it's -- the leisure period drives relatively better unit revenue in the peak summer months relative to other periods of the year. It's a little early for us to get a good handle on corporate demand as we move past the Labor Day weekends, so we're very much focused on it. There are things we're lapping across our system that we talked about in terms of how it affects unit revenue. On the corporate side, we're seeing flattish demand on lower yield. And our -- we're seeing GDP revisions walk -- step down, and so we're keeping a close eye on that. Again, that's why we've adjusted capacity. Our capacity adjustments that we've made to the rest of the year are across the system, both international and domestic, and we'll continue to do that as we launch demand going forward.

componenttextpreview: Slimline program is a little bit over 50% rolled out right now. On our June call, we talked about it being 50%, so we're beyond that as we're into July now. So it's a little bit 50%-plus on the whole network, and so that program is past the halfway point
componenttext: Slimline program is a little bit over 50% rolled out right now. On our June call, we talked about it being 50%, so we're beyond that as we're into July now. So it's a little bit 50%-plus on the whole network, and so that program is past the halfway point on the slimline side. In terms of profitability, it comes at a lower RASM but a lower CASM, and we haven't put numbers around what that's worth yet. As we walk get -- as we walk through the rest of the year, we update you folks on our initiatives, hopefully we can put some more color around that going forward. We did talk about that program, slimline and upgauge program, driving $800 million of contribution by 2018, so we'll be able to update you where we're at as we go forward.

componenttext: Gerry, just on the CASM outlook for the year. You took 50 bps or 25 bps, I guess, out of the full year capacity guidance. How much pressure did that put on CASM? Is the FX environment helping the CASM outlook now? headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It puts some pressure on CASM. We've doubled this in the past. Last year, in the situation of declining capacity versus our original guidance, we managed CASM down, actually. So this is all part of the process we have of always looking at opportunity to r
componenttext: It puts some pressure on CASM. We've doubled this in the past. Last year, in the situation of declining capacity versus our original guidance, we managed CASM down, actually. So this is all part of the process we have of always looking at opportunity to run the business more efficiently and to drive the cost savings through the various initiatives we have. It's not one thing, it's just all those little things that add up, our ability to manage CASM even in a declining capacity environment.

componenttext: Savi, this is Jim. As it -- you broke up a little bit on the question. In terms of Newark, the removal of the slots. Yes, I think, so we've seen -- we're working really, really closely with the FAA. And other carriers, the FAA would say they're over subscribing the peak slot periods. They're level 2. They work with the carriers to make sure that we don't deteriorate the operations at Newark, and so we're hopeful and in very close contact with the FAA on that, working with them to do that. Outside of that, we're not seeing that much in terms of OA growing capacity. And so as it relates to -- that's not what we're seeing that's happening in Newark right now.

componenttext: Yes, this is Jim. Again, we'll focus on United's capacity. The one piece I'll point out is in Asia, on the China capacity. There's limits to capacity growth based on the bilateral that's agreed between China and the U.S. government, and those bilaterals are almost to the point where they're -- they have been met. So that will have a natural kind of slowdown in capacity growth from the main U.S. to China. But I wouldn't want to comment on other industry capacity or other regions of the world.

componenttext: Just -- and this is to Gerry just with respect to strengthening the balance sheet. When I sort of look at later this year, it looks like there's some additional cash contributions to the pension. And when I think about the amount of stock that you want to buy back and your CapEx even after the piece has been financed, how should we think about your debt levels going forward? Are they going to stay sort of relatively constant? Or should we anticipate meaningful debt pay down as we sort of move into '17 and '18? How should we think about that?

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Mike, the important point is that we need to maintain a healthy balance sheet. We're there, particularly when you talk -- when you add our pension obligation. And when I talk about healthy balance sheet, it's really about managing through a cycle
componenttext: Sure. So Mike, the important point is that we need to maintain a healthy balance sheet. We're there, particularly when you talk -- when you add our pension obligation. And when I talk about healthy balance sheet, it's really about managing through a cycle, and we're very comfortable that we would continue to have access to capital through a cycle. We have about $8 billion of unencumbered assets. So I'm comfortable with where our leverage is today given our business and given what we're trying to do, so we don't need to significantly introduce leverage at all. And with the additional CapEx, I expect over the next few years, I said when we raised our CapEx guidance back in March with the additional aircraft, we saw about 50 seats issued as well as the early retirement of 747s, all of those aircraft I would expect to finance. And with sort of the range I put out earlier on the call on what I expect to do next year, I think if you run the arithmetic, you would not see a decline in our gross debt number over the next year or 2.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: Jim, another question on the $3.1 billion in initiatives underway. I think a big part of the story is improving efficiency via upgauging, and I think the domestic upgauging is pretty well understood. But if I'm not mistaken, there's also a wide-body upgauging that is just beginning which should aid 8 margins on the international part of the network, and I'm just wondering if you could elaborate a little bit further on that.

headline: United Airlines, Inc., United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, it's Jim. The international upgauging is a really, really small piece, and it's driven mainly by the 767-300 conversions of 2 class, that's driving a little bit of that upgauging. It's a really, really small piece of the upgauging that we talked abou
componenttext: Dan, it's Jim. The international upgauging is a really, really small piece, and it's driven mainly by the 767-300 conversions of 2 class, that's driving a little bit of that upgauging. It's a really, really small piece of the upgauging that we talked about on our $3.1 billion initiative. In addition, as you think about 2018 when the A350s come, that fleet will be a part of the international upgauging. But again, it's all a very small piece.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to United Continental Holdings' Earnings Conference Call for the Third Quarter 2016. My name is Brandon, and I'll be your conference facilitator today. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded and is copyrighted. Pleas
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to United Continental Holdings' Earnings Conference Call for the Third Quarter 2016. My name is Brandon, and I'll be your conference facilitator today. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded and is copyrighted. Please note that no portion of the call may be recorded, transcribed or rebroadcast without the company's permission. Your participation implies your consent to our recording of this call. If you do not agree with these terms, simply drop off the line. 
I will now turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Jonathan Ireland, Managing Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brandon. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to United's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Yesterday, we issued our earnings release and separate investor update. Additionally, this morning, we issued a presentation to accompany this
componenttext:
Thank you, Brandon. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to United's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Yesterday, we issued our earnings release and separate investor update. Additionally, this morning, we issued a presentation to accompany this call. All 3 of these documents are available on our website at ir.united.com.
Information on yesterday's release and investor update and remarks made during this conference call may contain forward-looking statements, which represent the company's current expectations or beliefs concerning future events and financial performance. All forward-looking statements are based upon information currently available to the company. A number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from our current expectations. Please refer to our press release, Form 10-K and other reports filed with the SEC by United Continental Holdings and United Airlines for a more thorough description of these factors.
Also, during the course of our call, we will discuss several non-GAAP financial measures. For reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures to GAAP measures, please refer to the tables at the end of our earnings release and investor update. Copies of which are available on our website.
Joining us here in Chicago to discuss our results are Chief Executive Officer, Oscar Munoz; President, Scott Kirby; Executive Vice President and Chief Commercial Officer, Julia Haywood; and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Andrew Levy. We also have Executive Vice President and Chief Operations Officer, Greg Hart, in the room to assist with Q&A.
And now I'd like to turn the call over to Oscar.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jonathan. Good morning, everybody. This quarter marked another period in which United took meaningful steps forward in transforming the direction of this company. Notably, we saw our 25,000 flight attendants ratify new contract, our over 9,000
componenttext:
Thank you, Jonathan. Good morning, everybody. This quarter marked another period in which United took meaningful steps forward in transforming the direction of this company. Notably, we saw our 25,000 flight attendants ratify new contract, our over 9,000 technicians reach a tentative agreement for a joint contract and we're excited to have that ratified soon. Additionally, in the quarter, as most of you know, I solidified my leadership team. This team has deep industry experience, incredible talent, in my opinion, and a very focused dedication to bring United into its next chapter, realizing the full potential of our great people and the great network [ph] and our assets. 
On the business side, we also continued to run a solid operation in the quarter. In fact, we achieved the best third quarter on-time performance in our history. I want to take this opportunity to thank dedicated and professional United employees that make all of this happened. Thanks to your commitment and determined efforts, we delivered a company best performance for arrivals during the busy July 4th holiday travel period and we also earned a first or second place ranking in key arrival and departure measures in the 3 months between Memorial Day and September 1 and culminated a great summer [ph] performance with delivering the best Labor Day weekend [ph] numbers on record. So it's great to have our operating program and people back in a good, consistent application of their work.
On the financial side, we continue to record strong financial results, including a pretax profit of $1.6 billion and a pretax margin of 15.7%, both excluding special items.
As many of you know, we will host an Investor Day on November 15. With that in mind, today we will focus on our discussion on our recent performance and near-term outlook and wait until November for a discussion of our plans for beyond 2017, including our outlook for both CASM and capacity.
So with that said, I'd like to turn the call over. This is the maiden voyage of Mr. Kirby, Ms. Haywood and Mr. Levy. But before I do that, just let me say to them all, we were incredibly thrilled to have each of you join the United family and very much looking forward to share our future with you. With that, Scott?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Oscar. Before turning to the slides, I just want to start by saying that I'm very excited to have joined the United team, and there are just fantastic opportunities ahead of us. This really is an exciting time for United. It's true that the las
componenttext:
Thank you, Oscar. Before turning to the slides, I just want to start by saying that I'm very excited to have joined the United team, and there are just fantastic opportunities ahead of us. This really is an exciting time for United. It's true that the last several years have been challenging with an integration that took longer and was more complex than anticipated, which created cultural, operating and commercial challenges. But now with the integration largely in the past, we can all turn our focus to realizing the full potential of United for employees, customers and investors. The foundation of a great airline is its people. And under Oscar's leadership, United has made tremendous progress in creating an integrated united United.
Achieving our full potential require lots of hard work. But with great people, the best network potential, the right plan and a focus and solid execution, we can deliver a great network operations and customer service, which, in turn, will lead to financial results that reflect the full potential of this airline. Julia will touch on some of the high-level opportunities in a moment. But before she does, I'd like to take the time to run through the quarter's performance.
On Slide 6, you can see that we've made meaningful strides in improving the operation over the past couple of years. On-time departures, arrivals, completion factor and mishandled baggage performance have all seen meaningful improvement. Going forward, we expect we'll continue to improve our operational results through better processes, more investments and equipment [ph] efficiencies. As we've talked about here in the past, at United, running a reliable airline is the key to winning with our customers. And we're gaining customers that we've lost during some of the operational challenges that we had with integration from 2012 through 2014.
Turning to revenue. Slide 7 shows consolidated [ph] revenue performance for the past quarter, which declined 5.8%. This was slightly better than initial expectations due in part to better close-in bookings and yields at end of the quarter. For the fourth quarter, we forecast consolidated PRASM will decline between 4% and 6%. As you can see on the slide, we continue to see sequential second [ph] of unit revenue improvement as we're lapping many of the headwinds we've experienced over the past few quarters. For now at least, it appears that we are mostly -- most of the big onetime issues that have been affecting PRASM are in the past.  One of the stories of this slide is that issues like currency, energy, et cetera, aren't really having a meaningful impact year-over-year any longer.  We continue to see the sequential improvement in unit revenues despite the fact that there's a meaningful calendar shift of revenues out of fourth quarter and into the third and first quarters. Getting back to positive PRASM is now about a balanced supply-demand environment, advancements in product segmentation as well as many United-specific opportunities that we'll talk in more detail about at Investor Day in a few weeks.
Slide 8 has some additional detail on each of the geographic regions. Domestically, we're seeing positive close-in corporate booking trends and a better alignment of supply and demand. Additionally, the domestic pricing environment is beginning to feel more rational. We expect the Atlantic to remain the weakest region in the world. Overall capacity continues to grow at high rates. At the same time, demand is growing more slowly, putting pressure on unit revenues.
In the Pacific, we expect to see a continuation of recent trends with modest unit revenues declines, modest as [ph] compared to the Atlantic. And we expect Latin America to be the first region to return to positive year-over-year PRASM driven by good results across the region and particularly strong results in Brazil.
In summary, I think the revenue environment has bottomed, and we're starting to see signs of recovery in all regions with the possible exception of the Atlantic.
At this time, I'd like to now turn the call over to Julia to share with you our high-level thoughts on commercial opportunities we've identified at United, each of which we'll discuss in greater detail next month's Investor Day.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Scott. I'm also very proud to join the United team. Ever since I began working with United, I can see the potential of our company, and I'm excited to be part of the team that unlock that potential. We see a number of opportunities througho
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Scott. I'm also very proud to join the United team. Ever since I began working with United, I can see the potential of our company, and I'm excited to be part of the team that unlock that potential. We see a number of opportunities throughout our commercial landscape to improve earnings over the next several years, with the largest opportunities being in revenue management, network optimization, product segmentation and product improvement. I will provide some high-level thoughts on each today, and we look forward to our upcoming Investor Day where we will provide more details on these opportunities, including actions that we are taking and the associated financial impacts.
So first, with respect to revenue management. We believe there are a variety of both near-term and longer-term opportunity to improve here at United. Solutions to these opportunities can range from small but meaningful tweaks to our revenue management system to making more wholesale changes to our strategies for managing both pricing and inventory. And while much of this work has been delayed during United's integration, we are now moving quickly ahead
Second with respect to our network. Let me start by echoing Scott's earlier comment. United has the best network potential of any U.S. carrier, but we are not utilizing it fully today. We have spent the summer working to refine the mission of [ph] each of our hubs, and we look forward to sharing some of our thoughts with you at Investor Day. But as an important note, the full details of our network playbook won't be fully revealed in order to protect competitively sensitive information.
The third area of opportunity we will discuss is product segmentation. As you know, the work being done in this area signals a meaningful step change for our customers. And I believe that over time, it will have an even larger financial impact in the introduction of bag fees. We will use the time at our Investor Day to describe in more detail our entry-level fare product while also providing further plan to advance the segmentation progress [ph] in other areas here at United.
Finally, we will discuss the changes we are making with respect to our product and travel experience for our customers. In particular, we are now investing in the premium experience, rolling out United Polaris, our all new business-class service, transforming United Club and elevating our food and beverage offering.
In summary, we are looking forward to this day and sharing with you the hard work we have been doing to establish our commercial plans for the organization. Like Scott, I am thrilled to be part of this team and could not be more excited about the opportunities I see ahead for United.
So as I wrap up, I'd like to take a moment to thank our customers. In my past life, I spent more hours than I'd like to recount on planes and in airports. And I understand how important it is that we deliver to you the travel experience that you expect. The team here has made great strides over the past year, and I know that there are even more opportunities to come.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Andrew.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Julia. I, too, am excited to be part of the United team. We have a lot of work ahead of us, but I'm confident we'll be successful in making United the best airline in the world.Yesterday afternoon, we released our third quarter earnings and four
componenttext:
Thanks, Julia. I, too, am excited to be part of the United team. We have a lot of work ahead of us, but I'm confident we'll be successful in making United the best airline in the world.
Yesterday afternoon, we released our third quarter earnings and fourth quarter investor update. While I will discuss both our results and outlook today at a high level, please refer to both of these documents for additional details. With that said, let's review the company's third quarter financial performance and fourth quarter outlook.
Slide 12 shows the summary of our GAAP financials and Slide 13 has our non-GAAP results. The company generated pretax income, including special items, of $1.6 billion with a pretax margin of 15.7%. Net income was $1 billion, a decline from $1.7 billion in the third quarter of '15 due almost entirely to a higher book tax rate in 2015. Adjusting for book taxes, net income was down 9%, but earnings per share increased 7% due to the 15% reduction in share count as compared with 3Q '15.
Moving to Slide 14. Nonfuel unit costs in the third quarter increased 3.4%, excluding special items, profit sharing and third-party business expenses. Approximately 2 percentage points of this increase was due to the impact of labor agreements ratified in 2015 for our pilots, flight attendants, dispatchers and IAM-represented employees. We expect fourth quarter nonfuel unit costs, excluding special items, profit sharing and third party business expenses, to increase between 4.75% and 5.75%. Approximately 4 percentage points of this increase is due to the impact of these new labor agreements. Our projections, however, do not include the effects of a recently ratified tentative agreement with our maintenance technicians since this has not yet been ratified.
As you can see on Slide 15, we expect full year 2016 nonfuel CASM to increase between 2.75% and 3.25%, with 2.3 percentage points of this increase due to the new labor agreements. However, in 2017, the year-over-year effect of these agreements is only expected to be between 1.5 and 2 percentage points.
As provided in yesterday's investor update, we currently expect our fourth quarter pretax margin, excluding special items, to be between 5% and 7%.
Turning to Slide 16 and capital allocation. Let me start by saying that we believe a healthy balance sheet and adequate liquidity is critical. We ended the quarter with $6.2 billion of unrestricted liquidity, including our $1.35 billion revolver, which remains untapped. Adjusted CapEx, including aircraft, nonaircraft and aircraft purchase deposits, was roughly $680 million in the third quarter. In the fourth quarter, we plan to take delivery of 18 new line [ph] aircraft, which contributes to CapEx of between $935 million and $955 million. We have already secured financing for these deliveries through last month's EETC transaction. For the full year, we expect approximately $3.2 billion of capital expenditures.
We also contributed $240 million for our pension plan this quarter, bringing our year-to-date contributions to $400 million. We do not plan any additional contributions this year.
With respect to the share repurchase, we returned $255 million to shareholders, purchasing 5.2 million shares during the quarter. That brings the total amount of cash returned to shareholders to $2.4 billion year-to-date. And since the inception of our share repurchase program in 2014, we spent $4 billion to repurchase roughly 20% of shares outstanding. We currently have $2 billion remaining under our repurchase authority.
At our upcoming Investor Day, we will talk in detail about our plans for the capital structure of the business, including our views on liquidity, CapEx, debt, pension funding and shareholder returns. We will continue to be focused on finding ways to invest efficiently in our business. This quarter, we added our second used A319 to our fleet and plan to take a total of 11 of these aircraft by the end of 2017. In addition, we are reviewing our long-term CapEx needs including the fleet, and we will give you a more in-depth update next month. Returning excess cash to shareholders will continue to be an important part of the United capital allocation strategy, and we plan to provide you the context for our plans going forward.
In closing, this is a very good quarter for United, and I'm excited about many good quarters to come. I look speaking -- I look forward to speaking to each of you again in the next few weeks as we lay out our strategic plan for the company.
I'll turn it back over to Oscar now.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Thanks, Andrew. As you've heard from the team, there's a lot of energy about the future, and we do have a great day planned for you on November 15. In addition to what Scott and Julia, Andrew have suggested with regards to the outline of that
componenttext:
Okay, great. Thanks, Andrew. As you've heard from the team, there's a lot of energy about the future, and we do have a great day planned for you on November 15. In addition to what Scott and Julia, Andrew have suggested with regards to the outline of that agenda, we're also going to have Linda Jojo and Greg Hart discuss improvement in both our IT systems and operations broadly, so that you can better understand the great work we have done in those areas to make United more efficient and nimble; also understand the importance of establishing goals by which you, as shareholders, can hold us accountable in order to ensure the execution of our plans. We will use the Investor Day to provide financial metrics and targets by which we are managing our business, so that you can also track our progress as we execute on this plan.
Let me close [ph] again by thanking our customers for flying United. We're focused every on continuing to find the opportunities to improve your travel experience, and we thank you for your business and look forward to seeing you on a flight soon.
With that, let me turn over the call to Jonathan.

componenttext: A question on domestic RASM. So your peer noted that on a combined basis, domestic RASM for the November to January time period should be flattish, trying to normalize for some of that  holiday shift. Do you agree with this assessment? And if not, what are you seeing that would suggest otherwise?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: [ph] I'm not sure I would get all the way to flattish. We do see continued improvement in the domestic environment. I think it's also right to kind of look at it as November to January to account for all the calendar shifts. I'm not sure if it will be t
componenttext:
[ph] 
I'm not sure I would get all the way to flattish. We do see continued improvement in the domestic environment. I think it's also right to kind of look at it as November to January to account for all the calendar shifts. I'm not sure if it will be the [ph], but it's certainly trending in that direction. I think we started actually -- actually, if you go to where we were in the third quarter compared to our competitor, we start from a better position. So I suspect we will get to positive domestic RASM before they do. I think we also have more opportunity and more levers that are all the way [ph] United specific. But we are certainly trending in that direction. And whether it's going to get there in November to January or thereafter, it's hard to say for certain at this point. But we are trending in that direction and we feel pretty good about the domestic environment. Certainly feels better than it has in a couple of years. Now acknowledge that's an easy comparison because we've [indiscernible] a couple of years, but it feels better than it has for quite some time.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: There is -- there are some offsets, certainly on profit sharing. And I think that each agreement kind of stands on its own, and I don't think we're ready to go to the individual detail in each one. But as one example, we see flight attendant deals today a
componenttext: There is -- there are some offsets, certainly on profit sharing. And I think that each agreement kind of stands on its own, and I don't think we're ready to go to the individual detail in each one. But as one example, we see flight attendant deals today at 15% profit sharing. And it's going to drop down to, I think it's a tiered approach, which will be from 10 to 20 depending on the level of profitability. That's one example, but we have to kind of look at each one on its merit to kind of go through the puts and takes. But look, I mean for the most part, we're going to see an increase in labor expense, and it's not completely offset by the profit sharing or productivity. so we're going to find ways to drive revenue and cut expense to continue to grow margins.

Can you just help us understand how you're thinking about the timing of the potential RASM improvement across the Pacific? looks like the fourth quarter doesn't look great, but as you look out into early next year, how do you see the changes in the bilateral sort of impact the capacity growth rate over time? And I guess looking little further out with the new airport in Beijing, if there's a strong possibility that, that bilateral gets to include more capacity in both sides.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you look at our third and fourth quarter PRASM forecast for the Pacific, all things considered, I think that's actually a quite strong performance. Particularly for us where in the fourth quarter, we're starting the second San Francisco to Shanghai,
componenttext: So if you look at our third and fourth quarter PRASM forecast for the Pacific, all things considered, I think that's actually a quite strong performance. Particularly for us where in the fourth quarter, we're starting the second San Francisco to Shanghai, so we'll have, for United at least, a fair amount of capacity growth. So for that environment, I think we're [indiscernible] doing pretty well. There is a lot of capacity growth out of China in particular, but as you pointed out, the bilateral almost cap [indiscernible]. And so that's going to slow down dramatically in 2017 and beyond. The opposite is happening in Japan where capacity is starting to be reduced, and we see strong performance in Japan. So across the board, we feel pretty good about the trans-Pacific environment. Looking further out once the new airport opens, it takes a long time to change bilaterals and there's more than just changing route authority. The complication with flight to China is route authorities. Being able to get slots at commercially viable times has been really difficult. And so I expect that, that will be part of the next set of negotiations. And so that's difficult. I mean, it's difficult. I suspect it will take quite a bit of time to get results.

componenttext: Scott, one of the things I think you did at American well was reduced forecast error in the revenue management tools, so -- over the last year or 2 particularly. So how is forecast there within UAL's RM tool suite? Where do you want to get it? And do you think you have the IT in place to improve it?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So thanks, Hunter. I think there's a lot of opportunity there. we're going to actually spend a fair a bit of time at Investor Day talking about that, but I'll give a little bit of preview and just I like to use one example from the summer. I mean, July is
componenttext: So thanks, Hunter. I think there's a lot of opportunity there. we're going to actually spend a fair a bit of time at Investor Day talking about that, but I'll give a little bit of preview and just I like to use one example from the summer. I mean, July is as United seeing stronger demand and bookings were coming in strong on the domestic entity, try to boost the demand and increase the amount of demand. And so we took set of markets didn't do anything. we took another set of markets and increased the local demand by 100% in the forecast. Another set of markets have increased both the local and the demand by 20%. Those are massive, massive changes in demand, and you would expect that to at least must match the changes in output. And at the end of the experiment, those 3, those 3 sets of entities, 3 groups were 0.2% different in outcomes. What that tells you is and what it really is, is we have a big complicated system. We don't even have a process to measure forecast versus actual [indiscernible] so big and complicated. And the team's done a fantastic job of managing on the back end, but we're [indiscernible] managing a lot of markets on the back end. And as great as people are, we can't do that as well as a robust system with thousands and millions of data points. [indiscernible] Even things like this year coming into Christmas, the demand pattern is dramatically different with Christmas on a Sunday sort of Christmas on a Friday, and we don't have any history that goes back to a time when Christmas was last on a Sunday. So we're trying to handle that. All of that, the team is doing a great job of managing in that environment, but it is a significant opportunity. It's going to require a lot of work. It's not going to happen overnight. it is going to require some changes to our system. fundamental architecture, the system we're built on, can handle it. There's no issues there. We're just going to have to -- do the work to build on top of that in management. It will take time and we'll talk more about this at Investor Day, but we think it is a significant opportunity that's unique to United airlines.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll add, if I can just add real quickly, over the years, people with characterized the United network in very rather in positive terms. But yet, we've never been able to realize the full potential of that. I think you heard another example of what are th
componenttext: I'll add, if I can just add real quickly, over the years, people with characterized the United network in very rather in positive terms. But yet, we've never been able to realize the full potential of that. I think you heard another example of what are the things that have been sort of missing and take it to [indiscernible]. again, a level of energy and excitement in our company based upon, predicated on the fact that we have some very, very, very good people on this now, and you're going to see great output over time, as Scott says. Thanks.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's -- I look forward to hearing more about this at the analyst day, that's actually good segue to my next question. When you guys actually split the VP [indiscernible] into 2 roles recently. you're going to have one person overseeing domestic net
componenttext: Yes, that's -- I look forward to hearing more about this at the analyst day, that's actually good segue to my next question. When you guys actually split the VP [indiscernible] into 2 roles recently. you're going to have one person overseeing domestic network and one person overseeing the international network. So to me, that says that you feel like one of those 2 is particularly underperforming. So is that a fair characterization? And if so, which do you think is underperforming more relative to where it should be, domestic or international?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we have a very strong international network. I think we have for many years. I think there's more we can do on that side for sure. On the domestic side, outside coming in, I think we thought there was a lot of opportunity there, and I think that's
componenttext: I think we have a very strong international network. I think we have for many years. I think there's more we can do on that side for sure. On the domestic side, outside coming in, I think we thought there was a lot of opportunity there, and I think that's only been confirmed from the inside now. So Scott and I are working together with the team to understand the full potential of the domestic network, and I think we see significant upside in there.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I would just say, you're reading a little too much into the org work structure, and people are anything like that. [ph] But we do, we have the best international network, certainly of any U.S. carrier. [indiscernible] no argue with that. But we d
componenttext: Yes, and I would just say, you're reading a little too much into the org work structure, and people are anything like that. [ph] But we do, we have the best international network, certainly of any U.S. carrier. [indiscernible] no argue with that. But we do not have the same kind of margins domestically or have the same kind of success domestically as American and Delta do. And we can get there. It's another area that I think we have more upside than the others because there's a whole bunch of stuff. It's in yield management. it's in sales. it's in the way the schedule is done, all kinds of stuff, but the company has been very focused on international, and -- But without losing any of that, I think we can improve the results in the domestic network.

componenttext: From JPMorgan, we have Jamie Baker.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: This first one, I'll throw out there to whomever would like to take it. So in stand-alone United incurred significant labor cost escalation back in 1999, it isn't clear that any return on that investment was ever achieved. So here we are, whatever, 17 yea
componenttext: This first one, I'll throw out there to whomever would like to take it. So in stand-alone United incurred significant labor cost escalation back in 1999, it isn't clear that any return on that investment was ever achieved. So here we are, whatever, 17 years later. Labor costs are once again rising at material rate. Is there anything different about the industry today that gives you the confidence that your owners actually witness a return on these recent investments?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, this is Oscar. Let me start and I think I'll let Scott finish, given that he's had deeper, broader, long-term experience here. I understand the history of this. It's been told to me repeatedly as we finished our labor contracts. And I completely re
componenttext: Jamie, this is Oscar. Let me start and I think I'll let Scott finish, given that he's had deeper, broader, long-term experience here. I understand the history of this. It's been told to me repeatedly as we finished our labor contracts. And I completely reject the notion you we can't have efficiency and productivity while also having customer service. [indiscernible] and to that end in order to get customer service and that productivity, we have to invest in these folks. And our employees are great core to product and customer experience. These costs, labor cost are market based and costs [indiscernible] to your point. Where the difference, we are counting on is that over time, this collaborative relationship we are building with our labor workforce, we can drive productivity. In fact, we're in this together. And some will call that nave. Some will call that history doesn't prove that, but I think we're already seeing green shoots as we say. That's been my focus now that I have experts. [ph] Scott, would you add something to that?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I agree with everything Oscar said. And we are a service business and our people make the airlines run successfully every day how they interact with our customers, most important thing that we do. one of the things that I am proud of as having been
componenttext: Sure. I agree with everything Oscar said. And we are a service business and our people make the airlines run successfully every day how they interact with our customers, most important thing that we do. one of the things that I am proud of as having been a part of in the industry is getting to the point where we can start giving back to our people and do great things to our people in contact after the 15 years that they've been through the close to 9/11 era of furloughs, the concessions and moving. So it's rewarding to be able to actually give the kinds of raises and economic benefits back to people after all that they've endured. I do think the industry is different today. And I think it's important that not only do great things for our people, but for our customers and our shareholders. All of those things happen to go together. I think 1999 is probably not the best example of time to use, because we all know what happened in 2001. And that's really triggered all the negative things for airlines over the next 15 years. We're past that and we're moving forward. I think we can do the kinds of things we've done with these contracts for our people, which is fantastic, and get to a world where we have margins that are higher than they are today and do great things for our shareholders as well. So we'll talk some more about some of those targets at Investor Day, but we're looking forward to that. But we are all genuinely happy for our people that we can offer them these kinds of [indiscernible]

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Scott, a follow-up and this touches on I guess question before. If you were to rank order the catalysts that are driving domestic RASM improvement, how would that look? Is it tighter aggregate supply followed by better fare fencing, followed by inc
componenttext: Great. Scott, a follow-up and this touches on I guess question before. If you were to rank order the catalysts that are driving domestic RASM improvement, how would that look? Is it tighter aggregate supply followed by better fare fencing, followed by increases to base fares? Or is it cessation of advantage fares, revisions to requirements, that sort of thing? I mean, we all know what the various levers are, and I'm not asking you to name names. I'm just wondering at the industry level, what's really driving the improvement?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: so I'm going to break it down exactly the way you described it, but -- I'll take a step back and say what's happened really started with deregulation and came to a head a few years ago that the way knew we pitched the product, sell the product, differenti
componenttext: so I'm going to break it down exactly the way you described it, but -- I'll take a step back and say what's happened really started with deregulation and came to a head a few years ago that the way knew we pitched the product, sell the product, differentiated the product changed. it used to be that we could use [indiscernible] Saturday nights to segment product between business travelers and leisure travelers, and we can't anymore. And the growth of low-cost carriers forever changed that part of the business. We have gotten -- we are getting better even in that world at figuring out segmentation. And we're doing more on segmentation here certainly at United. But across the industry, we're doing better at that. Capacity is still growing faster than demand, but we are making real improvements in our pricing and yield management strategy that are helping counteract some of that. And then as Julia mentioned and we'll talk more about at Investor Day, product segmentation is forward. I think it is a smooth structural change that we're going to go through here at United and will be good for our customers, to allow us to offer fairs peers to people that care about getting the lowest price. And it will allow us to offer a better product to care about other aspects of the products. And so we're excited about that. But really, this has been with an industry a journey of how do we change this and how do we segment our product for our various customers. And we're just I think mostly getting better at that it, right now, it's price management stuff that we're doing better, and product segmentation is going to kick off in earnest next year.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: But those are sort of long tailed observations. The sense that I get is that kind of mid-August, something really started to take place. Something incremental occurred. Is that understanding of mine simply flawed, which is fine? You've never hesitated tel
componenttext: But those are sort of long tailed observations. The sense that I get is that kind of mid-August, something really started to take place. Something incremental occurred. Is that understanding of mine simply flawed, which is fine? You've never hesitated telling me in the past when I've been wrong.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, they're not all long tailed. But when I talk about changes to yield management, those are pretty short tailed. And those are things we've gotten better at in the last 2 years. Sort of mid-August, there was a time that there were some changes going o
componenttext: Look, they're not all long tailed. But when I talk about changes to yield management, those are pretty short tailed. And those are things we've gotten better at in the last 2 years. Sort of mid-August, there was a time that there were some changes going on in the pricing environment, which I'm not going to talk about in detail on the call. It did happen that I think are contributing to -- look, it feels like an inflection point in domestic revenue. There probably was an inflection point in mid-August as some of the pricing environment started to change at a number of airlines in the country.

componenttext: We kind of have to go through the region by region. I'll start with the best, the Latin America. Latin America is going to be positive in yield and RASM in the fourth quarter. we feel really good about that market. Again, the Pacific, I think the capacity story can get better [indiscernible] 2017. So what I don't have specific forecast, if I just had to make my best guess yesterday, we will get to positive yields across the Pacific at some point in 2017. And across the Atlantic, it's still going to be a struggle. depends what happens with capacity in that entity, lots uncertainty still around Brexit and what's going to happen there. So I think that will get a positive in 2 or 3 entities, and the third one is really a question mark based on what happens to capacity.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think some of the -- and we look everything as in opportunity and we look at everything. Everything that hasn't been, let's call it committed. Clearly we have plans. We've made commitments. But as an example on the fleet side, there is a window opp
componenttext: Yes, I think some of the -- and we look everything as in opportunity and we look at everything. Everything that hasn't been, let's call it committed. Clearly we have plans. We've made commitments. But as an example on the fleet side, there is a window opportunity to be able to make some changes. Once you get within what's called a year of delivery, then you're kind of stuck. But we're certainly looking at fleet plan. We're looking a lot of our CapEx projects that we're making, plan to make or think about making. And just kind of reviewing it from top to bottom to see if we like what we've got coming down the pipe. And we make changes where we think it's appropriate. I think one example would be mix of new and used aircraft. We already started bringing in some used A319 at attractive rates. going to continue to keep an eye out for a high quality used aircraft to blend into the next fleet here. So there we can find these types of opportunities to reduce capital intensity we're going to try to take advantage of that. So nothing specific to talk about at the moment. We'll talk to you again in November 15. And if there's changes to be made, we'll discuss it at that time.

componenttextpreview: to stay with you Scott. sorry to the others. I look forward to spending with your in November. With respect regional aircraft strategy, you had a captive region at American. with respect to your early impressions, is it fair to say that United has not bee
componenttext: to stay with you Scott. sorry to the others. I look forward to spending with your in November. With respect regional aircraft strategy, you had a captive region at American. with respect to your early impressions, is it fair to say that United has not been as proactive as it could have been for regional aircraft strategy? If we look back over the last few quarters, regional capacity is down materially and you're growing on the mainline. I'm just wondering is this optimal/ideal? Or has this been a function of supply constraints on the regional site?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our constraints on the regional side at United are about the contract and the scope. And we are growing it, but we would be getting to the scope maximum. I think it's fair to also say that one of the things we will likely do over time is use our regional
componenttext: Our constraints on the regional side at United are about the contract and the scope. And we are growing it, but we would be getting to the scope maximum. I think it's fair to also say that one of the things we will likely do over time is use our regional supply and more of what you would think at a traditional regional markets and less in big markets. today we fly hub to hub between Dallas and Chicago, and between Denver and Dallas. We fly regional jets, and that's something that is unique about United. That will likely change and in hub to hub markets [indiscernible] quite bigger airplanes. And we'll use regionals to go fly into places that are smaller cities but [indiscernible] higher-yielding domestic revenues for the network. I think it's an opportunity at United.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I add? This is Andrew. Let me add we, , there's been a plan in place for a while to reduce number of 50 seaters for economic reasons. And so I think part of what you're seeing is just that plan continue to play itself out, as 50-seaters are reduced. I
componenttext: Can I add? This is Andrew. Let me add we, , there's been a plan in place for a while to reduce number of 50 seaters for economic reasons. And so I think part of what you're seeing is just that plan continue to play itself out, as 50-seaters are reduced. I don't know if it's fair to say that we've been less proactive. I think there is a plan. We're in the middle of reshaping the regional fleet, and that'll continue as we look forward in the next several quarters.

I guess the shape of their capacity is a little bit different than the shape of yours. But I wonder if you could comment what your RASM was up in Brazil? And specifically how much of that was in August Olympics spike versus a steady trend over the course of the quarter?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, not that I focus on trying to beat the guys in Atlanta. I do, by the way. But [indiscernible] up 31%, and a big chunk of that was -- would have been the Olympics. I don't know the exact number here at United. But if we look out to the fourth quarter
componenttext: Well, not that I focus on trying to beat the guys in Atlanta. I do, by the way. But [indiscernible] up 31%, and a big chunk of that was -- would have been the Olympics. I don't know the exact number here at United. But if we look out to the fourth quarter at least, we expect yields to be up somewhere between 20% and 30%. So I think that's a real recovery. The Olympics gave it a kick start, but it also led because of the Olympics lead into the pricing changes. the pricing environment in Brazil is far, far better than it was just a few months ago. And that happened sort of around the time that kind of Olympics. Maybe that's what caused it, but it stopped. Brazil is much improved.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: All of my questions have been answered, but I just wanted to touch on capital allocation a little bit. Obviously the buybacks slowed dramatically in 3Q, but you did reiterate focus on capital returns in your prepared remarks. I guess when we look at 2017,
componenttext: All of my questions have been answered, but I just wanted to touch on capital allocation a little bit. Obviously the buybacks slowed dramatically in 3Q, but you did reiterate focus on capital returns in your prepared remarks. I guess when we look at 2017, have higher labor costs and new fuel curve increasing your expenses. Free cash flow takes a hit as CapEx steps up. how do you balance this capital return strategy with much lower free cash flow next year? And you feel comfortable with higher leverage from here? or what is the leverage to keep this strategy going?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: At the moment, we're not considering adding leverage to the balance sheet. That being said, we are going to be reviewing it in more detail in the coming quarters with our board and look at that where we think it makes sense. But at the moment, we think ha
componenttext: At the moment, we're not considering adding leverage to the balance sheet. That being said, we are going to be reviewing it in more detail in the coming quarters with our board and look at that where we think it makes sense. But at the moment, we think having a very strong balance sheet is critical. We are very comfortable with our debt levels at the moment and our liquidity. As you noted, we do have some issues that we need to get comfortable with as we look into 2017. Higher labor expenses, higher fuel curve are certainly the 2 important things. And as such, I think that it's likely that the pace of any buyback is going to be probably a little more similar to what we've seen in the last quarter, certainly than what we saw the first quarter where we repurchased 1.5 billion of shares. [ph] So stay tuned. I think we look at that as excess cash, and when we have excess cash, how do we return to our shareholders. And we'll take into account all the drivers in the business to look forward and first and foremost make sure that we maintain a very, very strong balance sheet, which we think is a huge competitive advantage that we care deeply about.

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So with I guess with the earnings inflection next year, would we expect additional debt paydown to keep occurring at United?
componenttext: So with I guess with the earnings inflection next year, would we expect additional debt paydown to keep occurring at United?

headline: United Continental Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have -- I don't believe we have any opportunities to reduce our debt next year, other than that just simply making payments. We have some unsecured that's due in I think '18 and '19. We have a number of WTC transactions paydown according to the i
componenttext: Well, we have -- I don't believe we have any opportunities to reduce our debt next year, other than that just simply making payments. We have some unsecured that's due in I think '18 and '19. We have a number of WTC transactions paydown according to the initial schedule. So I think at the moment, we don't see any big opportunities to just reduce the debt levels, but we're very comfortable with where they are. we certainly are going to be mindful and keep it conservative. it doesn't mean we won't look at more leverage. But as we sit here right now getting our arms around the business and trying to come up with the game plan as we go forward, which we'll share a lot of that in a month from now, I don't expect any significant changes in at least in the next quarter.
